29953870.review:
Absolutely amazing.  Cross Code offers the very best one can expect from an ARPG.  The game is Early Access, but the 10+ hours of content currently included are already more than worth the asking price.

Combat is both challenging and stimulating.  Each new foe has an entirely unique attack pattern, and some come with unusual abilities I would not have expected.  For example when you knock most enemies into the water, it counts as out-of-bounds forcing them to respawn nearby and take a hit to their health.  Penguins, however, will leap back up out of the water and perform a special diving attack instead!  Some enemies can only be hit from the rear, others need to be baited into charging a wall, some must first be set on fire to be defeated... it really mixes up the combat and provides some entertaining contests.

Puzzles and Platforming go hand in hand, and are given a lot of focus in Cross Code.  Using your projectile to break objects and throw switches is a basic feature included right from the start.  This is particularly interesting due to the fact that your projectiles can bounce off walls, allowing for intruiging setups.  There are walls that block player movement but not projectiles, and walls that block both.  Movable blocks are included as well as iced floors, moving platforms, timing sensitive puzzles, explosives.  Again a wide variety that will keep you coming back for more.

Add on to all this, an extremely well written and vibrant world.  The characters are alive and interesting, the setting feels like a living breathing MMO made more convincing by the many "players" that populate the cities and pass you by in the open world.  

Beautiful and emmerisive, a true delight to experience.  There are few games I would recommend more highly than this one.

29912862.review:
(Note: I played mostly offline, so the hrs on record is inaccurate)

The game is truly great, but what I found truly cool about this game in its Early Access stage is that the meta is broken in a satisfying way to incorporate the fact that it's Early Access right now into the world itself. When the game is fully developed, I'm hoping that they'll keep in a few aspects of the world that are supposedly unimplemented just to maintain this.

On to typical review parameters though, what do we have... 10/10 art, 10/10 music itself (but probably 7/10 for music usage, it can get repetitive), 10/10 plot (with decent character development even in Early Access), 10/10 action gameplay, 9/10 puzzle gameplay, 7/10 pacing. Overall, 9.5/10. Easily worth the $20 price.

It's extremely satisfying to go on a rampage to build up your combat rank (a combo counter that spans the entire battle, essentially). I will say though, I never personally used any traders at all (the purpose of the combat rank seems to be to increase your chances of monster drops, to trade in), so perhaps their importance should be stressed. It's also quite satisfying to solve the puzzles, which integrate nicely into the combat environment. In fact, everything is satisfying, except the abrupt end of the Early Access -- but hey, it's Early Access.

I am quite glad that I listened to the reviews and just as glad that I'm adding to them now. It's overwhelmingly positive, if the genre interests you *at all* you have no reason not to get the game.

29866932.review:
[h1]So muss Early-Access funktionieren![/h1]
Dieses Spiel ist ein hervorragendes Beispiel dafür wie Early Access [b]eigentlich[/b] funktionieren sollte (Wir wissen alle es gibt auch hervoragende Negativbeispiele, aber darum gehts hier nicht). Man hat schon mal ein Klasse gerüst um das herum die Entwickler immer mehr tolle Sachen bauen und fixen und neuen Content kreiren. Einfach Klasse. Macht weiter so!
Ich habe bisher schonmal etwas Zeit im Spiel verbracht (ca. 12 Stunden) bisher. Hier noch mein kleines Fazit:

Das Kampfsystem finde ich wirklich ziemlich toll. Close Combat mit einer Mischung aus Baseball, nur mit dem Unterschied, dass diese "Bälle" wehtun. Sehr schnell ziemlich flüssig und hochspannend. Durch die Bälle ergeben sich auch außerhalb der Kämpfe echt tolle Möglichkeiten für Rätsel (Was die Entwickler scheinbar auch gerne zu Nutzen scheinen). Man muss manchmal schon etwas "um die Ecke denken" um die Rätsel, was bei mir etwas Zeit braucht, da ich nicht so gut mit Rätseln bin. Dann wird einfach probiert bis es klappt. 
Dabei ist mir auch aufgefallen was man in diesem Spiel auch viel braucht sind [b]Zeit und Ausdauer[/b], die Rätsel sind teilweise echt gut und schwer gemacht, jedoch kann es auch koordinativen Fähigkeiten scheitern, ich erinnere mich an ein Rätsel wo man echt wie der Blitz Schalter drücken musste, das hat bei mir gedauert (sogar bsteimmt mehr als 30x ^^") An sich aber sehr spannend was die Entwickler sich haben einfallen lassen. 

Die Endbosse auch Ihre Weise gut gemacht, den alle (die ich bisher gesehen habe) waren auch sehr knackig im Schwierigkeitsgrad, was mir jetzt auch nicht missfällt und haben Ihre Eigenarten, die es zu durchschauen gilt. Wann kann ich angreifen?, wann muss ich blocken? Sachen die man nur herausfindet, indem man es immer wieder probiert. Einem Casual Gamer der mal eben so was einfaches für Zwischendurch braucht ist hier wohl eher falsch (Wobei dies vielleicht auch nicht die Absicht der Entwickler ist wer weiß?)

Der Look gefällt mir auch sehr gut. Ich spiele es derzeit auf einem kleinen 24" Monitor auf Full-HD. Hat man erst die richtigen Einstellungen gesetzt sieht das Spiel wunderbar aus trotz (oder gerade wegen) Pixelgrafik. Die Animationen sind flüssig und nett anzusehen. Man merkt wirklich dass die Liebe der Entwickler auch in viele kleine Details geflossen ist. Man findet immer wieder kleine Dinge über die man schmunzeln kann. (Hmm, wie war das mit dem Avatar und dem Herrn der 4 Elemente ;) ) Auch das immer wieder neuer Content geliefert, zeigt die Liebe und Hingabe zu diesem Spiel. 

Ein wenig was möchte ich noch zur technischen Seite sagen. Mir war gar nicht klar was mit HTML5 und Impact.js(was die Game-Engine für HTML5 stellt) alles möglich ist. :o Toll finde ich, dass das Spiel dadurch eigentlich nicht Platfomgebunden ist, ich könnte es sogar noch auf meinem Linux-Rechner spielen, was Linux als Spieleplattform fehlt sind tolle Spiele wie dieses hier. Dank HTML5 könnte man es sogar im Browser spielen, was die Entwickler mit der Demo auf Ihrer Seite bewiesen haben. Was mir auch gut gefällt ist die hervorragende Controller-Unterstützung, ich spiele mit einem Xbox-360-Controller und es spielt sich klasse. Keine Ahnung wie es sich mit Maus und Tastatur spielt, da kann mich vielleicht mal wer aufklären. 

Alles in Allem ein runder Early Access Titel, der mir bisher sehr gut gefällt und mich so ein wenig daran erinnert, wie ich als kleines Kind immer mal wieder Zelda gespielt habe. (was ja auch ähnlich war mit echt krassen Bossen und klasse Rätseln) Das Geld war auf jeden gut angelegt, von diesem Spiel könnten sich ein AAA-Titel ne Scheibe abschneiden. 

Macht auf jeden Fall weiter so Radical Fish Games.

29816246.review:
I write this recommend on the note that the game is incomplete and as of the current update ends ubruptly (0.8). While I do recommend this game you may also wish to wait for it to be released before playing it. Unless they break the current play style I expect the rest of the game to be very good.

The game is based off of the idea your playing in an MMO. Other characters and just in general seeing random characters running around has a MMO-ish feel, I would say a world like .HACK.  It would be cool to ocasonally see other random characters fighting mobs but that might require a lot of work.

The game is also very unforgiving. Unlike other games of "You died 4 times in a row, we are bumping the dificulty down a bit", Crosscode keeps a very classic console game dificulty. The few boss fights in the game will kill you, many times. The patterns are simple and easy to pick up. I have been babied by most modern games telling you where to go and providing a compas and pointer. Crosscode does not do this. This means some quests are completly hit or miss as to if you figure them out. I have 1 or 2 I stopped trying on as I could not figure out where to go next.

The game does have some grind and repetition.  Killing tons of the same creature over an over for a single drop. Finding and breaking plants for the 4% drop rate so you can catalog that plant.  Overall this isn't required to complete the game and if you just destroy every plant you see you will probably only need minimal backtracking to complete the catalogs.

29772021.review:
I want to start by saying that I REALLY want to like this game. The combat is addictive and fluid, the skilltree and movesets allow for varied playstyles, and the sprites are just beautiful. Part of the fun of combat is that it just LOOKS SO GREAT. 

But holy F R I C K THE DUNGEONS ARE ENDLESS. It's safe to say that I have spent roughly 1/3 of my total playtime in the first dungeon, and that is a huge deterrent for me. I understand that this is a great thing for many players, but if you are a player such as myself, and love combat more than puzzle solving, you might want to at least wait for a bit of a sale for this game. The dungeons are long and a tad tedious; the puzzles (at least in the first dungeon) are reduced to "push these blocks here," "set up these mirrors to reflect your shots in a certain sequence here," wash, rinse, repeat. And this isn't where the atmosphere of the game and the devs' commitment to detail shines; it's the outside world brimming with life and bustling with NPCs. Not to mention the lack of quest marker/helpful HUD map, which makes finding certain events or items a bit of a pain. FOR ME, these deterrents were a deal breaker. I just became tired of trying to make my way out of THE FIRST DUNGEON after hours of play. Talk about trial by fire.

TL;DR  I'm going to thumbs up this game because I believe that many people will enjoy the challenge it presents, and it'll be GREAT on its official release, but be warned, this game is heavy into puzzle solving, and will test you in the gauntlet.

29718337.review:
Игра, которая действительно затягивает, почему?

CrossCode это сочетание в себе лампового пиксель-арта, приятных персонажей, интересного сюжета и качественной боёвки.

Начинаем игру мы в вымешленном ММО-мире , за персонажа с амнезией по имени Лея, которая хочет вернуть свои воспоминания. Одно но - говорить она из-за бага виртуального тела может только несколько слов, но зато ей помогает погроммист Сергей и внутриигровая подружка Эмили.

Графика
Представляет собой изометрический вид, с закосом на 16-битные игры. Окружение в игре очень яркое, сочное и при этом красиво нарисованое. При этом стилистика по сути футуристичная с элементами средневековья( как Lineage 2 но с лазерными мостами, голограмами и т.п.).
Анимация в игре плавная и радует глаз.

Музкальная составляющая
В игре весёленькая музыка, меняющаяся от ситуации и того, в каком месте вы находитесь, но при этом она всё-таки поднаедает. Не хватает разнообразия. Звуковые эффекты присутствуют, но при этом возникает чувство, что чего-то не хватает. Наверное под релиз добавят. В целом - годно.

Геймплей
Битвы в игре представляют собой слешер, где используя очень гибкую систему прокачки скиллов, можно знатно пофаниться, ведь управление очень отзывчивое и битвы динамичные. Нужно тактически обдумывать свои ходы, ведь монстры уникальные и имеют свои уязвимые и защищенные точки. В системе прокачки скиллов, в которой есть(будет) 4 стихии, надо думать куда тратишь очки. Очень необдуманый выбор может осложнить прохождение, но скиллы можно сбросить.

Мир не закрытый, можно исследовать как угодно, но порой нужно по заданию, или ради секретки попасть в зону, в которую ну никак не запрыгнуть. Нужно искать подходы, порой даже переходя из одной локации в другую. Игра за исследование мира вознаграждает ништяками.

Сама прокачка в игре ММО-шная. Тоесть: выполняем квесты, бьём мобов.
Если вам лень выполнять квесты, то можно погриндить. Гринда не очень много, на каждый уровень нужно одно и тоже кол-во очков , просто нужно продвигаться дальше по карте и бить более высокоуровневых монстров.
Как и в любой ММО, есть меню персонажа, где можно посмотреть статы, инвентарь, карту, меню общения. 

Боссы
Если вы хардкорный игрок и играли в игры Souls, то вам они не покажутся сильно сложными,  умерев пару раз, можно выучить поведение босса и прикончить его, ну или закупиться бутыльками и шмотом по-лучше. Самое главное - это не быть жадным и действовать по таймингам.

В игре так-же есть пазлы, которые вы никак не пройдете стороной, ибо они сюжетные. В основном это подземелья, где вы должны подвигать ящики, пострелять рикошетами. Сразу пробежать их нельзя, надо подумать,но они не настолько сложные, чтобы гуглить прохождение в интернете. От вас требуется понять, как работает тут механика.
Сюжет
Сюжета в игра пока-что мало,но много геймплея. Игра продвигается поэтапно - немного приключений, подземелье, потом ещё приключения. Разработчики на данный момент (6 февраля 2017) добавляют геймплей, сюжет обещают позже.
Хотя игра интригует и хочется продолжение.

Не понравилось:
Не очень удобный паркур
Маловато музыки.
Использовать скиллы неудобно, болят руки после потной битвы.

В целом
Игра сильно затягивает, быстро погружаешься в её атмосферу с богатым лором. Если вы любители игр инди подобного рода, то советую попробовать демо. И если понравится, то даже приобрести. Геймплея в игре на данный момент на 8-12 часов.

29538762.review:
In general I am not a fan of Early Access since there are many examples in which people spent money on games that later got cancelled or that didn’t live up to the promises the developers made beforehand. Yet with CrossCode I am confident that this won’t be the case. Not only are we given regular updates for the game here on steam but the developers also have a game dev stream in which you can see how the game is progressing on a weekly basis. Something that also can be seen in these streams is the passion and the determination that the developers are putting into the making of CrossCode. A game that strives to mix modern gameplay mechanics with the charming looks of the games that I grew up with and from what I have seen so far, flawlessly succeeds in this endeavor.

That being said I would never advise you to buy this game if you are rightfully skeptical about it being in the state of Early Access. But I would highly recommend that you keep an eye on this one! Because I am certain that once CrossCode sees its final release, it will be an entry in the list of games in which Early Access turned out to be good.

29537790.review:
好久没有玩到这么好玩的游戏了。可能它的价格看起来有点高，尤其是对于一款还没做完的复古游戏来说，但是带来的游戏体验真的是太值太值这个价了。

游戏场景大概分成两类：大地图和迷宫，对应的分别是慢节奏和快节奏的体验。

大地图上的强制战斗非常少，即便挑起战斗也能够轻易逃跑，同时可以召唤同伴一起打，轻松练级；大地图的解谜要素就是仔细寻找可以利用的地形和机关，去到达宝箱所在的地方（基本上宝箱都放在一眼就能看到的地方，但是想要找到通路就不简单了）。我经常为了得到个宝箱把地图绕上好几圈。

迷宫是由很多房间组成的，房间又分为战斗房间和解谜房间两类。这里面的战斗都是强制的，而且多半需要你利用这个迷宫的“主题元素”才能有效击败敌人；解谜房间则要利用该迷宫的“主题元素”发动一系列机关打开前进的门。

从个人经验来看，每次在大地图的时候我都会慢慢悠悠地边走边找宝箱花上好几天，而到了迷宫密集的机关和战斗则会赶着你往前走，基本在1～2天之内解决掉。这种节奏我觉得非常好，很适合周中走地图，周末打迷宫。

游戏场景的制作非常用心，目前开放的四个“主题迷宫”，每个里面的机关设计和敌人战斗方式都截然不同，每次都是从易到难慢慢教你学习新元素的特点，之后通过一场小boss战考验，再把新元素赐予你。拿到新元素之后，面对之前很多强敌都变得砍瓜切菜一般容易，但是到了迷宫尽头又会出来一个超强的大boss……每次通迷宫之后都很有成就感。

战斗很有趣。除非等级差距太大，否则基本不能无脑砍，那样的结果就是刚出城就被门口的小刺猬滚成渣。每次碰到新的敌人，都得绕场跑几圈看看它的攻击模式，然后决定如何出手。游戏初期主角的战斗方式比较单一，但是在获得战技之后就丰富多了，战斗效果也更华丽。可能由于低分辨率的画面和发色数，战斗非常流畅，很有动感。

很多人说游戏（战斗）难度大，我觉得平心而论在ACT里面实在不算。我小时候从来没打通过任何一款FC上的动作游戏，基本上都会卡在第二关。然而这个游戏里我发现只要仔细观察敌人的套路，再难的boss有个10次总能打过去。加上游戏对死亡的惩罚基本就是零，因此打起来的心情是比较轻松的。

然后说一下剧情，制作组特意把剧情停滞在了一个较早的阶段，而把迷宫往后多做了一些。根据他们发布的消息，他们准备在最后几个月把剧情一起放出。这是因为当前看起来比较轻松愉快的剧情不久之后就要急转直下，因此如果一点一点放剧情，就会在很长一段时间内让大家苦等下面那一点剧情。剧情的转折其实不难预料到，因为相比于（目前为止）正章中轻松的日常，序章的剧情非常黑暗。我喜欢目前剧情的发展，也非常期待之后的“黑化”。

最后提一下音乐。虽然我大部分时间不得不关闭声音，但是在不关的时候，还是很喜欢里面的音乐的。感觉有点像比较老的日式RPG，比如Falcom的卡卡布三部曲里的音乐，怀旧的感觉很好。但是似乎wave dungeon里面的关底音乐跟之前的一个关底音乐重复了？希望正式版中会有新的音乐。

总之一句话，太值了！

Loved it.

Fun and exciting yet challenging combat, interesting enemies with unique mechanics, insanely great bosses, thrilling and tempting dungeons that you wish would never end, meninges-squeezing puzzles that hardly become frustrating and are never annoying, good story so far, and the "game in the game" theme is great especially if you've been a MMORPG player before.

My favourite game of all time is Golden Sun for the GameBoy Advance and I've got the same vibe as its with CrossCode, I'd like to know if the devs took some ispiration from that one too!

Recommended at full price.

29362974.review:
A lovely little gem of a game. A .hackish setting, gameplay that's like a somewhat faster-paced and more in-depth Secret of Mana, and plenty of charm. The worst thing I can say about it is that the perspective kind of screws with the auto-jumping puzzles on occasion - gauging the height of some platforms isn't always easy - but overall this is shaping up to be a great package. With the version number sitting somewhere around the 0.8 mark, I have little reason to think this won't be done.

EDIT: Having put in more time,I'm going to re-word that sole criticism more strongly, and add an additional one: the perspective absolutely skewers the platforming segments by dint of being completely unsuitable for it. Very poor design decision. Destroys any ability to accurately gauge distance/height in a LOT of cases - almost every jump feels like a gamble.
In addition, evasion isn't nearly as effective as it should be. While it works fine against projectile attacks, the majority of the enemies have melee attacks that either have turn-on-a-dime tracking, tells that are too quick/subtle to reliably spot in the middle of a busy combat encounter, or some combination of these. By and large, an enemy that goes in for a melee attack isn't going to care how many pirouettes you pull trying to slip away, or in what direction you do them in. They're just going to turn around and kick you in the face anyway.

Considering these are two significant flaws that affect two of the games most significant facets of gameplay - combat and platforming - I'm tempted to flip that thumb downwards. I'm still charmed enough - and frankly, at this point, invested enough - to give it a pass and keep trying to work with these problems. I would think carefully about these aspects of gameplay before picking it up, though. They can quite easily cause frustration.

29297130.review: 听说中文正在路上，非常欢心鼓舞，这个游戏有一种玩小时候塞尔达的感觉,剧情还没完整玩过不好说什么不过觉得还算是有趣的，战斗手感很好，难度适中（个人而言），推荐给怀旧动作玩家们。

29289178.review:
Tja wie soll man das beschreiben ? Am Anfang war es Liebe, dann Frust, dann finsterster Hass.
So in etwa ist die Gefühlskurve bei CrossCode und seiner Prodagonistin Lea.
Das Spiel beginnt großartig !, ein Feuerwerk der Emotionen und die Einführung der Charaktere könnte herziger nicht sein.
Auch das Setting, die Rätsel, einfach alles ist stimmig... tja bis auf den Schwierigkeitsgrad den der zieht von Quest zu Quest und besonders von Tempel zu Tempel ganz gewaltig an, und führt letztendlich zu Frustration und Aufgabe des Spielers.
Sind die ersten Minibosse nach 5 6 Anläufen besiegt, und frisst auch der erste echte Bossgegner nach 20 Versuchen den wohlverdienten Staub, sieht es danach zunehmend düsterer um unsere Heldin aus. Sie mutiert zu einer Glaskanone die ihres gleichen sucht, und das Spiel bestraft jeden noch so kleinen Movement Fehler mit der Tötungskeule.
Ebenso sind die Rätsel, welche zwar auch wunderbar erdacht und gestaltet sind, in ihrer Art zu schwer.
Es macht (mir) keinen Spass wenn man die Lösung erkannt hat, es dennoch 80x mal zu versuchen und immer wieder zu scheitern weil der zu treffende Schalter halt nach 500 Millisekunden wieder deaktiviert wird.  Und man (ich) eben nicht der super pro gamer bin der über so eine Reaktion und Zielsicherheit verfügt, um blitzschnell ganz genau einen Punkt zu treffen.

Als Fazit sei gesagt, das Spiel an sich ist super, aber für den Otto normal Spieler der nach der Arbeit bissel enstpannt etwas spielen möchte ist der Schwierigkeitsgrad einfach mal weit weit so sehr weit übertrieben, das man schnell in Frust kommt. 
Anders sieht es bei Spielern aus, welche es mögen hunderte von anläufen zu brauchen nur um einen Raum oder Gegner zu töten, sich eben richtig daran festbeißen können, für solche ist dieses Spiel wie gemacht.

UPDATE:
Es kann so schön sein, Lea und ich haben uns ausgesprochen wobei sie da iwi etwas wortkarg war (ein Mädchen welches wenig spricht, Wunder oh Wunder) und sind zu dem Entschluss gekommen es nocheinmal miteinander zu versuchen.

Im Ernst, das Problem mit der Schwierigkeit besteht nach wie vor aber !, und das ist der Punkt für meine Abwandlung ins Positive : es wird gepatcht, gefixt, angepasst... die Devs haben mehr als nur beide Ohren offen für ihre Spieler und das verlangt nach höchstem Lob ( kann man in den Kommentaren hier bei dem Review schön sehen), da können sich die großen Entwickler aber mal ne ganz dicke Scheibe von abschneiden. Wer sich so um sein Projekt und das daraus resultierende Feedback kümmert, hat es nicht verdient schlecht bewertet zu werden, und schon gar nciht im Early Access.
 
Ich schaffe es zwar immer noch nicht weiter aber ich weis das der Tag kommen wird an dem dieses Spiel soweit gebalanced und eingestellt ist, das auch ich Otto normal Spieler weiter mit Lea reisen darf, und darauf freue ich mich sehr.
Bis dahin, HI! und BYE!

29263524.review:
[h1] Intro [/h1]

Hi everyball!

I'm going to start off by simply stating that this game is awesome. I'm a huge fan of the pixel art style, so if you are too, this game is a must. I bought this game knowing it was in early access because I just couldn't pass up on the art style and the slew of positive reviews.

[h1] Overview [/h1]

[b]Gorgeous pixel art[/b] - This was actually the selling point for me. I love the art. I love, love, LOVEEEEE the art. Developers, I believe you made a great decision reworking the portraits of the characters within the game, as they made for an excellent presentation.

[b]Soundtrack[/b] - Really immerses you into the world of CrossCode.

[b]Butter-smooth physics[/b] - And boy is the physics butter-smooth. The physics is great in that when I make a mistake, I know it was of my own accord and not the fault of the game itself.

[b]Fast-paced combat[/b] - The combat in this game is quick. Once you get into the later areas of the game, standing still while you're in combat for even a split second means certain demise, and the game teaches you this right from the get-go.

[b]Great level-design[/b] - The level designs are outstanding and feel like a lot of care was put into them. I enjoyed all of the areas I explored in the game.

[b]Creative puzzles[/b] - The type that makes you go: "Yeah, I did that! Feels good!" when you beat it! I really love how some of the puzzles revolve around a certain element and start off easy, then progressively get harder as you progress, which makes it twice as rewarding when you beat them.

[b]Remarkable story & characters[/b] - I literally clapped when I reached the end of the story implemented. I adore the characters in this game oh so much! I need plushies!

[h1]Personal Experience[/h1]

Now that we're past the overview, I'll offer a more personal perspective. The way I'm going to format this is by having two sections; story run, and 100% run. The difference between the two is that a player only doing the story most likely won't encounter the same things a player doing a 100% run will. In doing this, I will be offering two different perspectives on the game.

A 100% run for those of you who don't know, is basically exploring all areas, obtaining every item, and completing every side-quest alongside the story quests and many other things. I kept this explanation brief, but I hope it's clear and get's the point across.

[h1] Story Run [/h1]

[b]Soundtrack[/b] - Soundtrack will be pretty enjoyable since you usually don't stick around some areas for too long.

[b]Level design[/b] - Looks pretty neat, fun to traverse in.

[h1] 100% Run [/h1]

[b]Soundtrack[/b] - It's going to get really repetitive, really fast. You're going to be hearing the same soundtrack for the area you're in over and over and over, and it get's to the point where you just want to get to another area as quickly as possible, just to get a new soundtrack playing.

[b]Level design[/b] - Sometimes I can't tell when a platform is above the character, so a lot of the time you're going to think "Oh I'm on a high platform, I bet I can reach the one across from me." until you try to do so and you smack face first into a stone pillar and drown.

I actually had to devise a strategy in order to tell if I can jump on a platform or not; throw a ball. If it looks like I'm above a platform I try to make sure by throwing a ball at the platform I want to get to. If the ball flies over it, I'm in the green, If it doesn't then no-go.

[h1]Personal Experience Conclusion[/h1]

For now this will be all. I know the 100% run review above may seem unfair, since it's the price you pay for going for a 100%, but I feel it's worth noting regardless since different people play games differently.

[h1] End [/h1]

Thank you everyball, and thank you especially to the developers for such an endearing and fantastic game! CrossCode holds a special place in my heart.

[i]May be revised in the future.[/i]

29240286.review:
I went from Atari to Commodore 64, then PC gaming. So I don't have nostalgic memories of sitting in front of a Nintendo, although sometimes we'd rent one or I'd play one at a friend's house. I can see the appeal, and people who would pick this game up obviously know what they're getting into.

I got this game as part of a bundle for next to nothing. If not for that, I would have left this one alone. In fact, I had it marked "Not Interested" after it coming up in my discovery queue. Anyhow, it's just like what you'd expect. Dicey chiptune music, quick zooms after battles, a bit of camera shake, and tons of dialogue. This game is one of the highest rated RPGs on Steam right now, but make no mistake, this is more of an action game than an RPG game. After an hour of playing I didn't see a single piece of loot or stat screen. Combat requires twitch reflexes as you block, dodge, and aim your attacks.

I can see the appeal. I totally get why so many people love this game. Personally, I just don't care for the style. I left this stuff behind in the 80s and I was anxious to move on even then. Bring on the polygons, pixel shaders, and texture maps!

29234825.review:
This game is totally worth the price tag. I've been playing for about 12 hours, my play time is a bit skewed as I left it on when I went to work one day, but I love every hour I've spent.

The level up system is really good too. There are different branches you eventually unlock and when you do, you get upgrade points for it equal to your level, to balance out the ones you've had for longer. It really balances how you level Lea up as you don't have to choose which branch to take.

The parkour/platforming in this game is also really well made. You don't have to worry about timing your jumps at a platform as she jumps on her own. Making it so you can focus more on maneuvering than timing your jumps well to get the most length.

I also really like the way the game is set up. They made it so you play in a real life mmo, meaning you're in the real world on a secluded island and players control avatars that are basically real people. It's a really cool concept imo. The npcs in the CrossCode are (mostly) npcs in the mmo or "other players" that are playing too.

There are things that make this game challenging though. When they give you a quest there isn't a whole lot direction of where to go when you get quests.

29219770.review:
This is a great game with fantastic character design and -development. I just love the graphics and the overall presentation, as well as the controls. Although they are a bit hard to master at first.
It is one of those "you are stuck in an MMORPG"-animes or -games, but done right this time!
I am not an avid player on very hard games myself. And CrossCode is indeed very challenging at times. I personally have to give it my best or try challenges multiple times before succeeding, but I never feel the need to grind or feel overly frustrated.
Same goes for some jumping puzzles with not so obvious solutions at times. This goes especially for situations where the height of platforms is not really distinguishable due to the representation.

But the devs themselves said that some of the hardness comes from their bias of testing the game over and over and they are constantly improving the game through patches.

+ lovely design
+ great characters
+ interesting story
+ mostly balanced difficulty
+ challenging puzzles

- sometimes a bit too hard
- visual puzzles, such as jumping over platforms, are sometimes needlessly hard to figure out

9/10

29210361.review:
Over 30 hours on an early access game should tell you something about this gem. 

While I feel some of my enjoyment can be attributed to nostalgia for the immersive RPG/JRPGs of my childhood, this feels like a classic in the making. I have reservations about how the team is going to wrap up the game as the beginning sections feel so densely packed with layers of quests and exploartion, but the bones laid here are sturdy. I find myself going back to this game frequently to find more treasure chest and other hidden alcoves in each area

Gameplay:
Smooth, fast paced battle system. Perhaps the most enjoyable action RPG system I've played to date. Enemy attack patterns are easy to decipher (with token example to the contrary) 

Puzzles are the perfect balance of logic and skill. I can't recall a game where I've had more "AWW YISSS" moments when hitting a puzzle perfectly

16 bit era bliss. I will say that discerning the altitude of jumps isn't intuitive, but the easy projectile firing makes this more or less negliable

Story and World:
Love where this is going, but having a hard time seeing how the devs will wrap up the story and add content to the still-in-development areas of the game that will make the content of the game feel deep from beginning to end

I usually don't bother posting reviews of games (this is actually my very first time posting a review), however, this game deserves all the positive reviews it gets. It's just so rare, at least for me, to see an Early Access game that is this enjoyable and shows so much promise. The story in the game so far is fun and interesting and the characters are likable (*NOTE*: keep in mind that the story is not entirely finished yet, so take that in to consideration when you decide whether or not to purchase this game right now). The puzzles and dungeons are challenging, but not "bang your head against a brick wall" challenging. 

The gameplay is VERY fun, and the battles actually require skill and some strategy; I've found quickly that if you try to "hack and slash" your way through everything in this game, you will die very quickly and very often. Even the regular monsters can wreck you if you aren't careful. For those interested in this game for the RPG elements, they don't appear right off the bat. However, shortly after the "tutorial" section, things like loot, gear, skill trees, stats, etc. will appear, so keep that in mind.

I typically don't trust Early Access games because they, more often than not, end up ranging somewhere between horrible trash to painfully mediocre and doomed to be abandoned by their developers. This game, from what I've heard, has regular updates, and seems to be expected to release fully sometime in 2017.

This game is defintely worth it, I've enjoyed every minute of it  and I really hope it gets more attention. To the developers of CrossCode: Thank you very much for making such a great game and I can't wait to play more!

29091936.review:
这是一款非常优秀的ARPG，值得任何喜欢动作RPG以及喜欢冒险解谜的玩家购买。
游戏最大的亮点是优秀的地图和迷宫设计，和精彩的战斗系统+敌人设计。

探索部分：

制作团队将整个游戏过程分为了大地图探索和迷宫探索两个部分。大地图的每个部分是有机结合的，散布着大量的谜题机关，而且形式多样，层次丰富，回报合理让玩家保持兴趣，相邻地图区域之间也存在很多互相影响的机关和密道，绝对不会让人有审美疲劳感。我在探索大地图上花费的时间远远超过了迷宫。

迷宫的设计也非常出色，迷宫的构成有明显的2d塞尔达的特征，也有寻找钥匙打开通路的核心设计。如果说遍布大地图的谜题像是甜而不腻的点心，那么迷宫里的谜题就好比豪华大餐。你会沉迷于解开迷宫里的每个房间的秘密，又不会有在某个地方卡半天的窘迫感。难度，回报和趣味性非常平衡，体现了制作团队高超的设计水平。

这样的散布于大地图的谜题+迷宫里的主线谜题的结构正是塞尔达传说的典型特征，遗憾的是迷宫这部分的谜题没有较多的房间之间的互动，立体感层次感稍有欠缺（这方面最好的例子是塞尔达时之笛的水之神殿迷宫，不过这很大程度上得益于它的3d属性），但仍瑕不掩瑜。

战斗部分：

除了家门狗之外，每一个大地图和迷宫里的敌人都没有丝毫的重复，包括形象设计，行为模式和由此形成的合适打法，没有一个重样的。光是这一点就使这个游戏将相当一部分同类游戏甩开了一个身位。而且玩家总能有足够的机会学习和了解每一个新敌人的特征，当多种敌人同时出现的时候也总能根据之前的经验及时想到合理的战术，以及以敌制敌的办法，难度曲线非常合理。

BOSS战更是精彩，每个阶段的特色都表现得非常好，也与玩家在对应迷宫里获得的经验相对应。

缺点：

在玩家进入主世界后的初期阶段，游戏的节奏没有控制好，这一阶段的大片地图色调缺乏变化，敌人仅有家门狗，鼹鼠及其变种和牛等几种，如果玩家没能坚持过这一段很可能会因为疲劳感而放弃游戏。这可能是游戏开发初期阶段遗留的问题，之后的流程则渐入佳境。

결론은 맨 밑에있습니다.

[레벨링]
압도적으로 좋은 평가를 받아서 기대하고 해봤는데 대부분의 사람들을 위한 게임이 아닐수도 있었습니다.

그래서 레벨링 시스템이 존재하는데 영어를 모르시면 약간 하드할수있습니다.

29059006.review:
Crosscode is a really good RPG-style game with an intriguing setting and a very polished world. Im quite surprised this game is in early access, as it's so polished and well-done already. 

Pros:
-Unique real-time combat system
-Fun NPCs
-Very large game world
-Simple fast travel system
-Comedic dialogue
-Runs very well on potato PCs.
-Preset save file function. They don't have steam cloud in this game, but the preset save file function makes this unneccesary. Its a list of save files at certain points of the game, including one immediatly after the long and unskippable (though enjoyable!) tutorial.

Cons:
-Enemies, for the most part, will not engage you unless you engage them. This means you can easily get far into the game without many fights. I've made it to the temple dungeon (level 18) while being only level six. More agressive enemies would fix this.


Overall, I highly recommend this game and it is well worth the price. 9/10
(If you didn't read the early access page, it reads that the game is currently much shorter than it will be upon release.)

29015190.review:
I don’t normally write video game reviews, but I felt obligated to write one for Crosscode considering just how much I’m enjoying it, and the fact that it’s still in early access.

Story-wise, this game is kind of generic. But that’s kind of to be expected from an RPG. I’ve heard that the lore gets a lot deeper once you get a bit further in the game (I’m still working on the first temple), but as of now, I’d say that’s the game’s biggest short-coming.

All of the characters so far have been wonderful. The main character is engaging, and all of the side characters have their own interesting traits that make them both entertaining and lovable in their own ways. One of the things that originally hooked me about the game was the fact that half of the NPCs are total a**holes. It’s kinda surreal walking up to an NPC and hearing some condescending side-comment instead of the usual helpful NPC dialogue.

The art is absolutely stunning, while still remaining simple enough to not drag attention away from the gameplay. I really loved this fact because I’ve played a lot of games where the art was absolutely beautiful, but that’s all the game really was – pretty – and it was painfully obvious that the art was being used to make up for the terrible gameplay mechanics. However this game chooses to be beautiful in the background, giving you the choice of being lost in the art or the gameplay. Think Ori and the Blind Forest. 

Speaking of, the gameplay mechanics are fantastic. Most of combat boils down to two attack moves and two defense moves: Melee, Ranged, Dodge, Block. Each move has its own special “arts” that can be unlocked in the skill tree. Using these moves, and the massive skill tree, players can easily develop their own specific play style, instead of having one style forced on them. For example, up until now, I’ve yet to use the block move in a fight. Not because it’s bad or anything; I just prefer to dodge, and so far my dodging hasn’t noticeably hindered me. Also, on a more mental level, the combat just feels right. I can’t really put my finger on why, but even when I’m grinding away at enemies to get a specific item for a quest, boredom doesn’t even cross my mind. How they managed to make grinding (which is entirely optional, don’t worry) fun is beyond me, but they did it, so that’s worth noting. 

The enemies are another great thing about the game. New enemies are hard, but not too hard, and have weaknesses that can be exploited if figured out. None of them punish you in bull**** ways that just make you angry; everything is completely balanced. Plus they’re all fun and interesting looking, with unique attacks that keep combat fresh and entertaining. Some even switch move-sets when at low health, which is pretty cool. Bosses in this game feel a lot like old Legend of Zelda bosses, and that’s not a claim I make lightly. I grew up playing Zelda, and for years I’ve watched people try and fail to copy their dungeons, and their bosses. Crosscode succeeds at both.

Like I just said, the level design in this game is flawless. Build around a parkour system that honestly should not be as fun as it is, Crosscode manages to create the perfect mix of combat, puzzles, parkour, and secrets in every area. Most of the parkour starts with you seeing a chest in some strange park of the map and wondering “how the heck am I supposed to get up there?”, and then spending the next five minutes failing over and over again until you eventually figure out what you’re supposed to do. And that feeling is always rewarding. On top of that, the game is full of little hidden riddles and events, some of which remind me of the ones in FEZ. For example (kinda spoiler), somewhere in the first dungeon there’s a specific room where, if you do a specific action, it spawns something. I have no idea which room that is or what I’m supposed to do to figure it out. All I know is that the secret exists, and so does the answer, somewhere. 

Honestly, I could go on and on about how great this game is. But the best part is that there’s still more on the way. Unless the developers really mess something up somehow, or start putting out sub-par content to speed up their full release, what we have here is a game that feels more like The Legend of Zelda, than the last three Legend of Zelda games. Every once and a while, a new indie Steam game becomes a classic. As of right now, this game is on track to join the ranks of The Binding of Isaac, Super Meat Boy, FEZ, Terraria, Undertale, and the many others that have become something like household names in the PC gaming community. I cannot recommend this game enough, even at full price. 

10/10

28994872.review:
Absolutely spectacular!
I honestly didn't want to stop playing.

Cross Code manages to execute a beautiful combination of genres in a single game with confidence. Very smooth gameplay with easy controls but differing levels of mastery. The story was very straight forward and easy to follow but didn't restrict your gameplay and allowed you to explore and work on what you wanted to at the time.

There is a some challenge in the puzzles, but they're very creative and with enough time and effort, they're passable for everyone. The game has a lot of safe guards installed so that you can't get stuck and can change locales at any time and point, so you can even take a break from a hard puzzle and do something else for awhile.

More so than anything though, credit should be pointed towards the overwhelming charm that the game presents itself with. The environments are easy to get yourself immersed in, the characters are unique and relatable, the dialogue is down right hilarious, and the music is pleasant enough to listen to for hours.

This is a game I could recommend to anyone who enjoys 2D gaming, and I would encourage even those that don't to try out for themselves.

28926303.review:
Even if this game is $20 for early access, it is well worth it. The game has quite an interesting story that keeps you going with a satisfactory fast pace combat. Just imagine a Zelda game that is more difficult, faster pace, and a "Sphere Grid" System for stats and skills. Throw in some .hack// elements and you have this awesome entity known as Cross Code. There is some "cons" but there not really "cons" but more of a quality of life fix(s) that the developers can adjust before full game release.

Story - The story as far as early access goes is you take the role of an amnesiac Player name Lea in a fictional game call Cross World. Thinking that Cross World can help her regain her memory, she takes on the Plot of Cross World. However, Lea had her speech "module" corrupted so she becomes a silent protagonist. But Wait! unlike most silent protagonist, Lea still "talks" in the game. You start out with basic words but its quite comical to see her interact with other characters and see her limited choice of words. Of course she still nods up and down or left and right to let the other characters know her decision.

Pros:
Combat - The combat of this game is, in my opinion a pretty face pace game for a top down Action RPG. You have a basic combo, a dash/dodge button that is shared with guard. The game punishes you pretty heavily with amount of damage you take so dodging or guarding is key to surviving. The idea of "chaining" battles by constantly initiating a battle by attacking a monster is pretty cool. The higher you rank up your battle by constantly being in battle, the more EXP you will get and a pretty high item drop boost at the end. The developers were able to incorporate skills in a way where it does not "interrupt" combat. For example, you do not have to "pause" the game during combat to initiate a skill but rather the player can just hit the dedicated skill button. It is up to the player to charge the skill or not but charging the skill does slow down everything around you. Pretty Nice if you trying to aim a Range skill. The usable item menu though, will be a "pause" in combat. There is elemental(s) in this game. The elements provide advantages to monsters that are weak against an element or is key to exposing enemies weakspot/breaking armor. What is nice though is the developers has made it easy to switch elements on the fly with the D-pad. So unlike Zelda, the items or abilities you earn through temples are reusable elsewhere. The amount of fluidity of the combat controls in this game makes the combat system pretty fun and satisfactory.

Puzzles - So far from what I have played, the puzzles are really well designed. Though they are not over the top hard but at the same time, they are not really that simple either and will make you "step back" and assess the situation. While some of the puzzles now and days in games requires you to find a button, key, or moving blocks to help you get a cross a platform, most of the puzzles here requires you to set up what you think will work and execute it by using the a bouncing charge shot that Lea can do use. Some puzzle will require you set up and also move fast. For example, You can set up a ball to bounce corner to corner, however one corner is blocked by an ice block, You then have to Shoot a charge bounce ball and run over to melt that ice block with a fire element before the ball is blocked by the said ice block. Yes, the elements you learn from the previous temples will be useful and will reuse for some puzzles which is nice. Some of the mechanics of the puzzles are pretty unique. For example changing the elevation of the charge bounce ball or melting an ice ball with a fire ball to create steam to turn windmills. All these requiring setups, execution, and following up with the execution to ensure the execution goes smoothly.

Visuals and Audio - Not much to be said here but the visuals of this game is that of 16 bit. The game is 16 bit with a top down camera angle. So if you really enjoyed these type of games from the PS1 and NES era, than the visuals here is a plus for you. A lot of my friends said the game looks like the zelda series and Ys series. The Soundtrack so far has been pretty good. Each song seems to fit each setting or background.

Notable Mechanics- There is some sort of jump "quest" in each map to get treasure. The player is freely to attack breakable objects to collect or gather items for side quest. On the topic of side quest, there are quite a bit of side quest that has me doing the first set of side quest for 8 hours even though they are technically within the first 1-2 hours of the story. There is fast travel, so backtracking for some side quest won't be an issue. Inviting people to join your party is similar to the .hack// games. You open up a friends list, and call them up to join your party. Though at this time of early access you have only 1 contact in your friends list. Each element has their own "sphere grid" and does not share skill points with other "sphere grids" which is a blessing. Being a spheremancer you can equip 2 one handed weapons, so maybe we'll get to see a mix and match of weapons in full game release.

Cons (not really cons but QoL changes):

Difficulty - Not really a con to me because I like challenging games but to some, it maybe difficult at first. You are heavily punished for not dodging or guarding successfully so it makes it feel like even though you are 10 levels higher than the monster, that monster that is 10 levels lower than you still have a chance to knock out 1/3 - 1/2 of your health if you are not careful. It can give off a feeling that you are not actually getting "stronger" per level. The player can also be interrupted while using an item and might not get the healing effect of items. At the same time, this difficulty can be a Pro for some, thus not really a con but a potential QoL change.

Drop rate/gathering rate- Though the idea of using a rank system to determine higher drop rate is a good idea in my opinion, the rate(s) can get some players frustrated. For example, if players need to find "Raw Meat" from a cow, players may need to preemptively initiate other battles before engaging the cow to boost the drop rate for the said quest item. Some of the drop rates from breakable gathering objects are pretty low. I took about 2 hours to find 4 Bear Cicada from breakable gathering objects for a "beginners" quest. 

Determining Height - Since this game is a top down view, determining if a platform is in the same elevation as the player can be quite confusing, especially with the amount of plants and other objects that are displayed in each map.

Summary:
Overall This game is an amazing game that can be come a masterpiece here on steam. With a very satisfactory combat system and have puzzles that will give players a sense of a achievement, this game is in good hands. The Developers have done so far a very fine job. Just maybe adjust some rates here and there. I will probably add more to this post as I delve deeper in to the Early Access Version.  

8.7/10 Will and already has Recommend. Good Luck to the developers and really looking forward to Full Release.

28856111.review:
Now, this is one of those games where if it were made and published around 10 - 15 years ago it would be a world renowned classic. Where do I even begin? Well, for starters this game has a really great sense of humor that more than a couple times made me burst into laughter with it's witty puns and sarcastic jokes. I don't know how but this game has intense levels of irony that can only be rivaled by it's character development. It also tends to be faintly self aware at times and has you going into some comical situations that you would not even expect in a game like this.

For the record: I did try out the demo around a year back and I saw mega potential in this game to grow into what it has become today, and with that I am happy to say I was not dissapointed.

There are a lot of things remeniscent of early 2000's classics like Zelda: A Link To The Past and Metal Slug; more specifically the art style, of course, which is one of my all time favorites. All of the sprites look wonderful. When I play Cross Code [b]it feels[/b] like I'm reliving my childhood through a spiritual successor to all those games I once loved to play.

[u]MUSIC[/u]
Had I never seen, nor experienced anything about this game besides the music and I didn't know any better I'd have thought this game was made by nintendo. Every track in this game is simply brilliant, and  they make every area feel as diverse as ever. The instruments used in each track match up very well with scenery and give you a peculiar sense of wonder every time you discover a new town or come across an ancient monument. Whenever I hear a new song it leaves me with a strong urge to start exploring the new places I've found.

[u]STORY[/u]
As stated in the game description, this story is gripping and very sci-fi. I was drawn to the characters in multiple ways. Partially because of their bubbly over-the-top personalities and partly because of how well I can imagine their voice/accent. That's also part of the reason why I love games with silent protagonists because it's part of the fun to assert your perceptions onto them. The story telling is divided meticulously through certain interactions Lea (Main character) has with others, through dream-like flash back sequences, and through catagories upon categories of plot scattered about the Encyclopedia (which won't help you all that much if you aren't willing to take the time to read the entries)

[u]LEVEL DESIGN[/u]
All of the sprites and environments look so nice with the various animations. The enemies, although they aren't perfect, are unique and stylish aswell. All of the areas are nice and detailed although there can be a few minor inconveniences that, otherwise could be tweaked with small fixes. What I'm talking about in particular are the ledges. Alot of times it's hard for me to distinguish the verticality on some ledges I want to hop to so I end up jumping towards a platform that was one level above me. Or, when enemies fly just above you when you try to shoot them but you can't tell because the only thing indicating their altitude is a tiny shadow underneath them. It would be better if it were more clear whether or not something was below or above you. Some subtle details could be added to make it a little easier on the eyes.

[u]GAMEPLAY[/u]
Overall, the gameplay is truly engaging with some captivating challenges and puzzles that will test your reaction time and accuracy. Playing with some type of gamepad is recommended for an optimal experience, but I recall the game playing rather well with a mouse and keyboard too if that is all you can use.

[i]Conclusion[/i]
Honestly, this game is a dream come true for me because you can tell that some proper time was taken to polish and optimize it. The sheer quality of all of the content is something that is worth cherishing given that this is an indie game that's currently in beta. Kudos to the developers since I can tell that they had a blast creating and designing this awesome game. You may have a blast investing some time into this one.

28848500.review:
Please be aware, when I originally wrote this review, I had played the game for around 1.3 hours. I will update my thoughts and impressions as the game continues to be updated and as I continue to experience it. 
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

CrossCode is by far one of the most charming games I have played since Stardew Valley. From the very beginning, it is easy to see that the devlopers poured their hearts into the game. 

Here is a short list of things that I like about the game:

-The developers have done an exellent job of easing the player into the games various mechanics. There is some hand holding in the beginning, but it isn't overbearing. 
-The combat is very engaging. This is due in no small part to the obvious amount of thought that went into the different combat mechanics.
-The controls are very fluid and responsive. 
-The art is beutifully drawn, and does an incredibly job of conveying the characters emotions. 
-The level design is thoughtful and engaging. 
-There is just the right amount of dialogue. Enough that you can understand what is happening and appreciate the story, but you don't have to spend an eternity reading it. 

So far, CrossCode appears to be far more than the sum of its parts. I am incredibly excited to see how the game continues to evolve and change as it is being developed. I haven't been this happy, or pleasantly surprised by a game purchase in a really long time. 

I encourage everyone who reads this to try the free demo on Steam. I am sure that you'll be glad you did.

Every second I spent playing this game, I felt so attached to it and to me it's become a necessary drug. CrossCode is a Retro 2D RPG 16-bit game with SNES-style graphics as said in the summary. CrossCode comes with a leveling up system with skills, items, equipment, and quests so you can waste your valuable time on them. CrossCode also has many fun puzzles to enjoy while fighting in dungeons with cool bosses to defeat as you play through the story. CrossCode is the best videogame I have ever played. The game makes me feel so relaxed, happy and nostalgic... very nostalgic. Never has any video game made me feel the way CrossCode has to me. What I love about this game is the story, gameplay, puzzles, music, art, battle mechanics, and the characters. I can't think of anything to complain about this game. 28742479.review:
Allow me to tell you a little story.
On Sunday, December 25, 2016, I was browsing the Steam Winter Sale and had CrossCode appear in the recommended section. I thought it looked interesting, so I clicked on it. [strike]Yeah, okay, it was partially because there was a girl on the product banner, but don't tell anyone...[/strike]

That night, in the hotel we were staying at for the holidays, I downloaded the demo for the game, slowly but surely, at a blazing 500 KB/s. Once it was done, I proceeded to stay up until 2:00 AM to finish the entire 60-70 minute demo. I have never finished a game demo in my life, mind you.

That right there should tell you plenty about the game's awesomeness.
The following Tuesday, I talked my dad into buying the game for me (as I had no other way of purchasing the product). I've already invested at least 3 hours into the game, and have loved every second of it.

The game's storyline and premise are very interesting, and I wouldn't mind seeing them expanded upon in a sequel, if the devs get there.
The graphics and audio just scream Gameboy Advance era, only they're much better quality than such a console could have produced.
The characters, even though we don't know a ton about them, seem very developed and realistic for the setting. You'll see what I mean when you play it.
I think my favorite part of the entire game is the combat, though. The game has crossed all of the best RPGs into one game, in a sense, with its own spin.

This is the game I have, almost literally, dreamed of playing all my life. The only real issue now is going to be getting myself to finish Final Fantasy VII before this, as I don't want to run into issues with the game being incomplete.
Obviously, I'll be playing it again, but you know what I'm saying.

Speaking of, I'd even go so far as to say that this game gives even FF7 a run for its money, in a sense. FF7 is known as one of the best RPGs of all time, but somehow I feel that it just doesn't quite have the charm that CrossCode does.

Anyway, what the heck are you waiting for?! Screw food and other necessities...use that $20 on this instead!

[b]UPDATE Wednesday, December 28, 2016:[/b] I made it to the first "real" dungeon in the game, and boy oh boy, is it impressive. I've seriously been in the dungeon for 3 hours and now I'm going to bed because I don't want to stay up any later (it's almost 12:30 AM). 
The dungeons appear to be like Zelda dungeons, with some almost Metroid-vania-like elements in them. It's an interesting design concept, and I'm legitimately impressed with the amount of fun I've had so far.

Nice Sonic reference, btw. And don't think I missed the Back To The Future reference or the vague Final Fantasy VII reference, either.

28738025.review:
Straight to the point; Absolutely fantastic. 9.5/10

     Great graphics, good dialogue, AWESOME talent tree(s), cool attacks, extemely diverse enemies, puns galore (ie The Goatfather), Saitama in a Santa outfit, nice soundtrack, challenging puzzles, game isn't even completed yet (review being written as of patch 0.8.5-4) and it took me about 40 hours to "complete" (have like 95% of all treasures, Encyclopedia filled out, best gear, highest level without grinding out monsters for 1 XP each), which is more than a lot of AAA games these days can boast. An encyclopedia in game that fills out as you kill monsters/destroy nodes, and will give you drop rates after you loot X amount from each specific monster/node. AN INDEX OF SHOPS SO YOU CAN LOOK AT WHERE YOU SAW A SHOP SELLING A SPECIFIC ITEM.

     Trading system in game, where you don't just straight up buy a new set of armor/weapons every time you reach a new town, but you actually collect materials and trade them in for pieces. Equipment also makes you think about what you want. Increased Focus (crits) in exchange for less HP and defence? More HP and HP regen in exchange for damage and Balance (lets you use elemental attacks more, which is required against some enemies)? To go with that are huge talent trees, think Final Fantasy X, where you have Neutral and the four Elements (Fire, Cold, Shock, and Wave), which each get their own talent trees and points every time you level up, each offering different Melee, Ranged, Guard and Dash Arts, plus all the passives you'd expect like Max HP, elemental resists, Attack Power, etc.

     Variation in characters is really nice, too. Your best friend is French, and her friend [spoiler] who becomes your guildmate [/spoiler] is German. Your own character is a mute so-to-speak, but the different facial expressions she makes are very well done, so you're able to communicate through that. You also have the aforementioned Saitama dressed as Santa, there's a dandy on a hunt for a stylish tophat, a character who somehow is using armor from every class, the nerdy guy that needs your help with research, etc. No two characters are alike.

     The Dungeons are just amazing. After having completed the four Dungeons for all of the Elements, every single one of them posed a challenge to me, and I would have to stop, take my hands off my keyboard, and think about how to solve the puzzles. They really make you think outside the box. In Fajro, there's even a puzzle that you start it by shooting a ball, then as the ball travels around the "track" of the puzzle, you have to interact with the course, moving blocks, freezing/melting water pillars, lowering barriers, to change it's path, and the puzzle is roughly the size of two screens. Absolutely loved it. Each of the four Dungeons has a specific theme to it, to match the element it is for. As an example, in the Shock dungeon, you create big balls of energy and shoot them off, maneuvering them around to get them to power up circuits. The late Dungeons also utilize the previous Dungeons elements, so it's not like you go get the Fire element first, and then never use those mechanics/methods again.

     The only things that were sort of downers for me, was that equipment doesnt change the look of your sprite at all (save the santa hat, which I think looks really nice). You always look the same. Even recolors and a slight amount of detail would be kinda nice. Maybe add on some cool effects to attacks for some higher level weaponry, or effects based on what Modifiers are on your weapon/armor. Also some of the areas got very confusing because from my experience, the map does not accurately portray your position in the current map, and there are A LOT of treasures that I can't seem to get to. A lot of them require you to enter an area from the previous/next map from a vantage point. But maybe that's just because I'm stupid. I dunno. Also, some of the puzzles annoyed me, because there are pillars you have to move around, but you can only push them forward/backward, not side-to-side. Not a big deal, but just annoying. There are also some spots that are like landform bridges, but I can't tell, and I just think it's a wall, so I don't even go in that direction.

(Edit in after more gameplay; After actually going through and finding the treasures, it is definitely possible, but they can be very challenging! And in regards to the landform bridges making me think they are walls, the developers DEFINITELY did that on purpose, which I understand a lot more now. They make you consider all possibilities when trying to solve puzzles, maybe try going from this way, well how do I get there, maybe enter in through the previous area, well maybe that "wall" there isn't a wall, etc. I quite like it.)

     Small sidenote; even has the cocky rival that you just love to hate, and you get to duel him. But he's kind of cheap, basically if he hits you with a melee attack, he's gonna take like 2/3 of your HP bar. Despite that, it is very possible to beat him as long as you utilize your guard and dodge mechanics, and if/when you do, it really feels good to beat him.

     Basically, amazing game. One of the best that I have played in recent years. Very much looking forward to the full release.

28582145.review:
As of the current moment, Crosscode is definitely a game to keep an eye on, if not purchase immediately. While Early Access is definitely a giant red flag to most steam users (and for honestly good reason), I believe that this game is fairly trustworthy. The devs are quite transparent, with each of their updates noting issues yet to be fixed, delays in release dates, and what's going on in general. There is also livestreams which I have yet to check out, which likely go into much more detail of upcomng content.

Pros
-Fluid gameplay and combat
While it definitely takes a bit of getting used to in the beginning, within a few hours I was dashing all over the place firing shots and using specials with ease. On keyboard the game is quite easy to use, haven't used any other medians as of the moment though. The management of special attacks and dodging and using weak spots creates a very hectic and high pressure atmosphere, while still being very fun.

-Story and Dialogue
The story is, as of now, unfinished. However, what is here is still a fairly hefty amount and has been good so far. The main character, Lea, is unable to speak except for certain phrases (largely consisting of "Hi!" "Bye!" and "Lea!" for a good bit early on). Upon hearing finding this, I assumed dialogues would mainly be between other characters with her sitting on the side listening, but she does seem to input quit often through the use of "..." "...!" or "...?" and a facial expression. The facial expressions are quite good, often relaying her inputs quite well alone. You do gain a few more words as time goes on, and I assume the story will continue adding more as it progresses.
The dialogue itself between characters or NPCs often poke fun at other MMOs or make somewhat referential humor. I wouldn't necessarily call it subtle, but it definitely isn't blatant enough to seem like it was fishing for laughs. The dialogue seems rather real between the team characters you get and also between the players NPCs.* I often pause to read the dialogue because it is entertaining, although because it is chat bubbles above their head you can continue running by while reading. As a quick example, the boss of the demo can be found in the bestiary under "Behemoth Hostile Crab" I believe. 
*To help clarify things a bit, there are sort of multiple levels of NPCs to explain. As you run around, there are NPCs that are NPCs. These are people running shops and giving quests like those in an MMO. Next, there are player NPCs. They are NPCs running around in game as if they were players playing the MMO. They often use more aware terms (patches, updates, raids, etc.) when chilling at 'player' hubs, and can be seen running around in the fields as you are fighting monsters. On a side note, when lost it can be beneficial to follow the player NPCs because they run between areas and can lead you to exits if you get lost. Lastly, there are party member or story character NPCs. These NPCs are much more present and converse much more with you, the rest you can find out. As strange as it is, being aware that certain characters are NPCs along with the other characters actually helps build immersion, since they think a person welcoming you to town with the same line 800 times is as stupid as you do.

-Tutorializing
I think this game does tutorials fairly well. It is somewhat hands on in the beginning when it initially teaches you all your moves, but it gives you a lot more freedom as you enter the full game. Even early on it is more of telling you and letting you experiment compared to making you watch it over and over. After leaving the initial zone, about when the demo ends,s all questions and tutorializing is basically optional from then on.

-Difficulty (Bosses)
I personally think it does a very good job of creating a rewarding difficulty. When I fight the bosses of the game, it is often very hectic and challanging, and contains a few deaths while doing so. However, when I do die, I generally retry with more knowledge of the bosses patterns and what to avoid or take advantage of. Instead of feeling like I'm playing a very biased game of russian roulette, I actually do see myself progressing each time I fight a boss, and not because of stats. Also death puts you directly at the beginning of the room when you die, so failure doesn't stop you from diving right back into the action.

-Difficulty (General Battles)
The game seems to prefer actual fights compared to grinding, so any enemies you fight in the field that are worth their time in EXP will put up a fight. I find this enjoyable, as new areas aren't bogged down with annoyances but instead full of actual danger even without a boss. Plus, when high enough level and traveling through fields they often don't bother you if they wouldn't be worth your time.

-Difficulty (Dungeons)
I'm just going to say I love the dungeons. They are often large maps with multiple rooms filled with puzzles, enemies, or both at once. However, the pacing is often done quite well on them. Instead of telling you what everything in a room does, it will often give it to you in a puzzle room first. You get to spend time playing around, finding out what your abilities do to whatever object is given to you. Next, it often gives you some enemies that are affected by whatever you just learned, so you can try it out on them. Later, it mixes the two by including one of the puzzle objects that can be used to inflict bonus damage on the enemy or open up breaks for massive damage. Later, the boss combos this by making you use the mechanics you learned by using the puzzle objects on the enemies to open up the weak spots on the boss and attack it. Overall, I thoroughly enjoyed the dungeons I've played.


-Cons
Yes, even though I love this game a lot, it still has some issues.
-Lack of Story (Likely to be fixed)
At the current moment, the story is rather unfinished and cliffhangery, and leaves a good bit to be desired. This is definitely on the list to be added obviously, but this is just a warning as of now. I personally think this is a solid dev team that will add more, but you never know.

-Lack of PvP (Likely to be fixed)
There is one point in the game where you have a battle against another 'Player' in game, and it is 5 out of 9 battle of hectic, chaotic fun. When I played through it I was basically sweating by the end of it through the careful spacing, dodging, and use of specials. But there is the issue. As of my knowledge, this only appears one time early game and it doesn't happen again for the rest of it. Again, I believe this will likely be added in the future, but just in case this game doesn't get updated anymore (which, again, I highly doubt) I'll leave it here for now.

-Bugs/Glitches (Might be fixed?)
This is almost a pro based on how few I ran into, but I did have one issue that recurred a few times. At random points (I run the game full screen) it would basically freeze the frame onto the screen and reformat it to roughly windowed size, and only update that corner, which left about 40% of my screen a frozen frame. Even after it resized it, the mouse acted like it was still in full screen so the center of what I saw wasn't what the center was to me. I posted this issue to the forums and got a response within a day or two (yay) that said it was fairly hard to replicate so may be difficult to patch (boo). This wasn't common, but it didn't recur enough to make the game unplayable. So while it may be a bit to get this issue fixed, possibly even never, it was nice to get a dev response quickly and it isn't enough to deter me from the game. 

TL:DR Good combat, good story (albeit unfinished), good dialogue, good controls, good devs, good fun. Try the demo if you are unsure, but it should be noted that while the core gameplay remains the same, you get some additional abilities and the difficulty ramps up over time. (Also I should stop trying to write reviews after midnight)

28573866.review:
CrossCode is wonderful isometric action RPG.  Though it is in early access, the game is incredibly polished in virtually all aspects.  The controls are fluid and the combat and plaforming elements are very satisfying to say the least.  On top of the core gameplay, the world is vibrant and the characters are memorable.  

So far I've played around six hours or so without moving very far beyond the first major area, mostly doing the various sidequests and exploring, so I already feel that I'm getting a good value even if the game were to remain in its current state.

That said, the developers are some of the most transparent I've seen, and they do a great job of communicating their progress to the community.  They even hold livestreams on a semi-regular basis during which you're free to ask questions and sometimes get to watch them implement different features/ideas as well.

Overall this game encapsulates everything I love about the genre while still feeling fresh and refined.  I wish the best of luck to the developers as they continue to work on this wonderful project.

If you still have reservations, you can do what I did and try out the free demo.  You can download it on Steam, but it is also available to play in a web-browser (Chrome/Firefox) since the game is coded in Javascript/HTML5 via the ImpactJS engine.

28524509.review:
Within a few minutes, Cross Code takes you back to the days of you sitting in front of your CRT reliving your favourite action RPGs on the SNES: [b]Secret of Mana[/b], [b]Terranigma[/b], [b]Chrono Trigger[/b].
 
Using a combination of charming, classic hand-drawn environments and characters, a soundtrack that makes you remember it days after you last played, expressive and likeable (N)PCs, an interesting setting that keeps you intrigued, mind-boggling puzzles that require brains AND timing and a battle system built around throwing balls that simply doesn't get boring or tedious, delivers enough challenges for you to improve and trumps with epic boss fights.

[b]This review is based on the current version 0.8.5, released in December 2016.[/b]
 
You take the role of Lea, a Spheromancer-class character in the fictional MMOG [i]CrossWorlds[/i]. For unknown reasons, Lea lost her memory and logs into CrossWorlds as an attempt to recover it, but due to a problem her speech module isn't working properly, resulting in her ingame avatar being mute. Only with the help of a programmer called Sergey, she is able to express simple words like "Hi", "Bye" or "Lea".
 
To find the answers to her questions and to her memories, she keeps playing the game in order to not make the system identify her as an intruder or bot and kick her out. With the help of various other players from other classes and the crew of the MS Solar, she dives into the world of CrossWorlds.
 
[h1]Visuals[/h1]
Cross Code is visually resembling the 16-bit titles from the SNES and Playstation 1 era using a flat top-down-perspective to make the riocheting and ball throwing natural. It mixes classic medieval RPG environments with futuristic elements like laser bridges, energy walls and teleport devices. Every area or city has its own look which is defined by the area it is built in:
Rookie Harbor, with its western medieval style, Bergen Village, where snow-covered houses are built around cliffs, Ba'kii Kum, resembling a desert town that was built around a large oasis, Basin Keep, a rainy, modern skyscraper city in the midst of a fairytail-like jungle. The world is full of little details and filled with NPCs talking or running around the areas and towns making the game appear lively and populated at all times.
 
[h1]Audio[/h1]
The game features a rich playlist for all kinds of situations and environments and never seems to be out of place. On top of that, has a very enganging battle and boss theme. Style reminds of early PSX-themes. Especially atmospheric in puzzle rooms where concentration is required, rhythmic beats keep your mind focused.
 
The sound effects are natural and a mixture of sounds that fit the medieval setting as well as the MMO type futuristic sounds. Explosions are loud, wind is soft. When you use skills, they will impact with force and sound and landing every hit feels great.
 
[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
Controllable with both mouse and keyboard and gamepad, the gameplay is responsive and easy to pick up. However, you will learn early that precision and skill are still required to be effective in this game; [i]you can not simply run up to opponents and start beating them up[/i]: they have more than one way to deal with you.

That brings me to the three main gameplay elements of Cross Code. But first,
[b]Mechanics[/b].
[i]Because[/i] of the puzzles, it is [i]impossible[/i] to miss a mechanic as you have to understand and use it to proceed. Every puzzle is a tutorial so to speak.
The formula is mostly like this:
- Introduction of new element/mechanic tied to it
- Very simple introduction puzzle/battle for comprehension
- Several puzzles and battles with advanced usage
- Boss battle that requires advanced usage and timing

[b]Puzzles[/b]
Puzzles make use of all logic you pick up in the game. If a new element or mechanic is introduced, [i]the following puzzles will evolve around that[/i]. For example, the [i]Faj'ro temple[/i] makes use of both your [b]ice[/b] and [b]fire[/b] element by introducing walls that are made of [b]water[/b]. Based on the element you use on them, they become ice blocks or vaporate for a limited time.
[b]The puzzles themselves are never hard:[/b] They are easy to comprehend and you always know what you have to do to solve it. The only factor that makes you fail the puzzle is [b]yourself[/b]. Either you are not used to mechanics yet, or you missed the timing.

[b]Parkour[/b]
[i]This game does not have a jump button by design[/i]. Lea will automatically jump once you run off a ledge or gap. Using that, every single area has parkour and free running elements. They either lead to hidden chests, secrets or new areas. You will spend a majority of the time wondering [b]"How the [i]fuck[/i] do I get up there?"[/b]
Most parkours span [i]through the entire area[/i], some even [i]across multiple areas[/i].
As you can imagine, puzzles and battles will also make use of platforming which adds a third dimension into the game.

[b]Battle[/b]
Lea will be fighting a lot. Using her balls for ranged attack, melee attacks and defensive options like blocking and dodging, she is quick on the battlefield and you always have control over her. Every action type (Range, Melee, Defend, Dodge) comes with their own set of special skills which you can unlock in massive skill trees.
As the game features 4 prominent elements (Fire, Ice, Wave, Shock), on-the-fly switch between elements is possible and necessary in the later midgame. For that, every element has its own key assigned which lets you switch to it instantly. Hitting the same key again will return you to your normal state.
Based on the element you currently have equipped/selected, they have impact on Lea's statistics. Fire increases offense, ice defense etc.
Enemies have strengths and weaknesses. Obviously, using fire against a fire golem won't do much. The solution is to use ice. But [i]in what way[/i]? Finding out weaknesses, breaking enemy defense and hail attacks on them while they are broken/stunned is the key to success in battle.

But Lea cannot only attack, but defend. Lea can dodge 3 times in a row, then needs a brief moment until she can dodge again.
This makes you aware of positioning, as especially in groups, enemy attack patterns can get relatively lethal.

Cross Code provides Lea with non-playable party members. As of version 0.8.5, only Emilie, your french Pentafist sidekick, will accompany you. Emilie will support you in close-combat.

[h1]RPG[/h1]
The game has a lot of statistics that synergy with skills, elements and equipment. There are a lot of ways to minmax and to create new builds, which increases the replayability a lot. A whole botanics and glossary system provides you with info you need. A lot of detail has been put into the background story and lore around the MMO CrossWorlds. It is quite worth the read.

[h1]Story[/h1]
As of 0.8.5, the story is currently in development. It promises to have depth as the ingame lore is already massive.

[h1]Summary[/h1]
Cross Code is the potential next big hit on Steam. It has very few flaws that are easily overshadowed by its strengths. Give the demo a try.

28496602.review:
This is one of the most unique indie games that I've ever played. The story is interesting, with fun quests and an interesting item system. The creators of Cross Code have really taken the time to balance the game well between the multiple genres it spans, including puzzles, RPG, platforming, etc. The game is first and foremost an RPG, with puzzles and platforming spicing things up every so often. The puzzles vary in type, with some being purely difficult to figure out, to some requiring good timing. None of the puzzles/dungeons feel repetitive, and each boss has it's own unique method to take it out, similar to games like Dark Souls, where you'll get nowhere unless you figure out the trick. 

Speaking of combat, the combat is extremely unique and very different from other RPGs, often requiring timing and rewarding skill.

All in all, a great game that, while still an early release, is still worth grabbing.
