[h1]English review version[/h1]
Review from Version 9.0, supported on Indigogo with a lot more than the retail price of 19,99€ (and also a lot more than 19,99$).
Transparency information: I am a moderator in the CrossCode-wiki and maybe a fanboy

[h1]What is CrossCode?[/h1]
CrossCode is an 2D or 2.5D action RPG with gorgeous pixelart like old 16-Bit classic games. The game combine as real time combat system with engaging Zelda-like puzzles and a gripping story

Developer: Radical Fish Games — [url]www.radicalfishgames.com[/url]
Publisher: Deck13 — [url]www.deck13.com[/url]

CrossCode - Website: [url]cross-code.com[/url]
CrossCode - wiki: [url]crosscode.gamepedia.com[/url]
Web-Demo (English and German): [url]cross-code.com/en/start[/url] (needs an webbrowser with HTML5 support)

Difficulty: moderate

[h1]Graphics[/h1]
Similar to old SNES games and a stickler for details with Parallax und cutscenes

[b]Rating: 10 von 10[/b]

[h1]Controls[/h1]
The game allows to switch between melee and ranged combat, dodge, special attacks, Guard und Element attacks, to fight different enemies with there matching tactic. The default controls are set for a smooth and fast switching between those tactics. In my option the Controls pefect match the game and are unique. You can try the [url=cross-code.com/en/start]Online Demo[/url] (Playable with any X-Input controller or Mouse and Keyboard; needs an Browser with HTML5 support)

[b]Rating: 10 von 10[/b]

[h1]Music[/h1]
The Music was composed by [url=http://steamcommunity.com/id/Intero]Intero[/url], which perfectly match the Game and Environment. In my opinion CrossCode contains some of the best pieces you can get in video games. You can listen the music on Soundcloud: https://soundcloud.com/interovgm/sets/crosscode-original-soundtrack

[b]Rating: 10 von 10[/b]

[h1]Story[/h1]
The main story of this action RPG is about the [spoiler]female player and protagonist Lea[/spoiler]. With her [spoiler]real Avatar[/spoiler] she is part of an [spoiler]MMORPG called CrossWorlds[/spoiler]. She [spoiler]has lost her Memory and tries to recover them by retracing her steps in CrossWorlds[/spoiler]. Also her [spoiler]Avatar[/spoiler] is due to an [spoiler]technical problem (a little bit) mute.[/spoiler]

[b]Rating: ---------[/b]

[h1]Size[/h1]
This game is in Early Access and has not the size of the finished game. Nevertheless it can played many hours

Playtime - main story: ~8h
Playtime - Quests and details: +40h

[b]Rating: ---------[/b]

[h1]Rating[/h1]

Controls: 10 out of 10 "perfect"
Music: 10 out of 10 "perfect"

[h1]Deutsche Rezension[/h1]
Rezension der Version 9.0. Unterstützt auf Indigogo mit deutlich mehr als dem Verkaufspreis von 19,99€.
Transparenzinformation: Ich bin Moderator im CrossCode-wiki und verehre das spiel ein bisschen

[h1]Was ist CrossCode?[/h1]
CrossCode ist ein reißerisches 2D bzw. 2,5D Rollenspiel mit unvergleichlich guter Rasterkunst; angelehnt an alte 16-Bit-Klassiker. Es kombiniert ein Echtzeit-Kampfsystem mit knackigen (Zelda-artigen) Rätseln und einer packenden Geschichte.

Entwickler: Radical Fish Games — [url]www.radicalfishgames.com[/url] (Englisch)
Herausgeber: Deck13 — [url]www.deck13.com[/url] (Englisch)

CrossCode - Netzauftritt (Englisch): [url]cross-code.com[/url]
CrossCode - Enzyklopädie (Englisch): [url]crosscode.gamepedia.com[/url]
Netz-Demo (Englisch und Deutsch): [url]cross-code.com/en/start[/url] (benötigt einen HTML5-Kompatiblen Internetbetrachter)

Schwierigkeitsgrad: Moderat

[h1]Grafik[/h1]
Angelehnt an alte SNES-Klassiker, unvergleichlich detailverliebt mit Parallaxe und Zwischensequenzen

[b]Teilwertung: 10 von 10[/b]

[h1]Steuerung[/h1]
Das Spiel erlaubt es frei zwischen Nah- und Fernkampf, ausweichen, Spezialangriffen, Schild und Elementarangriffen zu wechseln, um die unterschiedlichen Gegner mit passender Taktik zu besiegen. Die Steuerung ist dabei so gewählt, das ein komfortabeles und schnelles wechseln der Angriffe möglich ist. Die Steuerung ist perfekt auf das Spiel abgestimmt und einzigartig. Probiere die [url=cross-code.com/en/start]Netz-Demo[/url] (Unterstützt controller mit X-Eingaben oder mit Maus und Tastatur spielbar; benötigt einen HTML5-Kompatiblen Internetbetrachter)

[b]Teilwertung: 10 von 10[/b]

[h1]Musik[/h1]
Die Musik, wurde von [url=http://steamcommunity.com/id/Intero]Intero[/url] komponiert und ist perfekt auf das Spiel und die Umgebung abgestimmt. Meiner meinung nach beinhaltet CrossCode einige der wohl besten Musikstücke die man im Videospielebereich findet. Wer gerne mal in einige Stücke reinhören möchte kann das auf Soundcloud machen: [url]https://soundcloud.com/interovgm/sets/crosscode-original-soundtrack[/url]

[b]Teilwertung: 10 von 10[/b]

[h1]Geschichte[/h1]
In diesem reißerischen Rollenspiel geht es um die [spoiler]Spielerin und Protagonistin Lea[/spoiler] die mit Hilfe [spoiler]eines künstlichen Körpers[/spoiler] an dem [spoiler]Echtwelt-Massen-Online-Gemeinschaftsspiel CrossWorlds[/spoiler] teilnimmt. Sie hat jedoch [spoiler]ihre Erinnerung verloren und versucht sie wiederzuerlangen[/spoiler]. Zudem ist ihr [spoiler]künstlicher Körper[/spoiler] aufgrund eines [spoiler]Technischen Problems (ein bisschen) stumm.[/spoiler]

[b]Teilwertung: ---------[/b]

[h1]Umfang[/h1]

Das Spiel ist in Entwicklung und hat damit nicht den Umfang des vollen Spiels. Trotzdem kann man viele Stunden spaß haben

Gesamtspielzeit - Geschichte: ~8h
Gesamtspielzeit - Missionen und Details: +45h

[b]Teilwertung: ---------[/b]

26174758.review:
TL;DR review: The game is good, and is worth 5 times it's purchase price. Highly recommended.

Crosscode is one of those special games you come across only once in a while. A small, obscure indie game that hides in the nooks and crannies of the internet, hoping to be discovered.

If I were to describe this game with a sentence: Imagine a game that combines classic 2D Legend of Zelda puzzle and exploration mechanics with top-down shooter combat, and MMORPG leveling and skill tree systems.

The game world takes place in an MMORPG called "Crosscode" but is in fact a single player game. The exact place you have in this world as the protagonist (Lea) is a mystery, and an intriguing intro sequence reveals that you may have quite the past to uncover. Suffering from amnesia, the only way to recover your memories is to play and advance through the world of Crosscode, fulfilling two purposes: Completing the game, and discovering the truth about yourself.

This game exploits the best elements of an MMORPG, and eliminates the boring parts they contain. Leveling up, finding hidden items, getting loot, destroying large amounts of enemies in a short amount of time, skill-based combat that requires finesse and precision, these are all fantastic elements in Crosscode. If you master the combat system, you can wipe out enemies vastly superior to you in level, and by investing in a variety of skills, unlocked through a skilltree, you can express yourself with battle instead of words, which you'll come to find quite valuable. *wink wink* 

Puzzle mechanics are not only smart and satisfying, making you feel like a smug little Sherlock, but they are just as fast paced as the combat, meaning that you'll never sit still and be bored out of your mind, or spend too much time walking around wondering what the hell is going on.

So please, buy this game. The developers deserve so much more than what they're getting. There's *passion* in this game. Just go. Buy it. Do it, do it now. Oh, and bring your gamepad.

26130729.review:
This review has a qualifier: I first found about it because you can play the demo in your browser. In fact, when you buy this game, the package you download is basically a browser baked to run this game. No plugins like Flash or anything like that - but written in HTML5 and JavaScript instead of something more standard like C++ or Unity.

But this review don't need no qualifier. Because this game is amazing.

First of all, it has an absolutely beautiful aesthetic. The 16-bit pixel graphics look stunning, and easily create a piece of a beautiful whole. Each and every animation looks fluid and natural - playing as Lea and exploring her different moves felt like experimenting with Mario's acrobatics in SM64 all over again. And just as amazing are the sound effects - things tap, ping, scratch, and pop in a way that just adds so much. My personal favorite audiovisual moment in the game is seeing and hearing avatars materialize - hearing that soft, otherworldly fizzle and seeing the blue, slightly teal patterns come together was love at first sight for me.

The gameplay is also pretty awesome. Your dual wielding of both a strong melee weapon as well as a slightly weaker ranged weapon (which itself can either be thrown slowly and accurately or quickly and haphazardly) makes for plenty of exciting combat experiences that always keep you on your toes, anticipating the enemy's patterns and watching for weaknesses. And the same tools also apply themselves very well to the far less combative puzzles, which feel like they take things common to games like Zelda and one-up them all over the place. I found switching between the two weapons difficult on keyboard and mouse (the system they use, in which you click close to Lea to swing your melee weapon and click far away to aim and fire your balls, can be finnicky to get right), but it became quite easy with an Xbox controller (which simply melees when you press RS unless you are also aiming with the right stick) and even easier with a Steam Controller.

The story of the inner MMORPG (CrossWorlds) that the characters are in is cheesy as heck, but the surrounding story of CrossCode itself, the single-player RPG you're playing, is very good. I can sense a bit of satire towards the MMO genre as the characters make various comments about CrossWorlds, such as Emilie's comment about how the players (who are essentially jacked into fully immersive rigs connected to their avatars) can adjust their sensors to decide whether or not they want to feel the cold of Bergen Trail. And beyond that, all of the characters are well written and have interesting stories to tell. I can't wait to see what else the game has in store for this aspect.

And again, as I mentioned before, it's designed to play in a freakin' [I]browser[/I]! The platform that has traditionally been the platform of serious business applications and .io games and banner ads is also completely and totally home to THIS thing! If you're feeling down about the state of the Internet and Internet programming, download and play this game. You'll feel much better.

Heck, even if you aren't, download and play this game. You'll feel much, much better.

25994161.review:
You know when you play one of those old school games, and you get to a mini-boss, and you say "Holy @$@#!" when a huge chunk of your life vanishes, or "BULL#@$#!!!" when you dash right off the edge of a cliff, even though it's not bull@#$@ because it's your own fault? You know those old action RPG style games where an hour into the game you look up and are confused because you thought you'd only been playing for ten minutes? 

..Yeah. Yeaaaaaaaaah. 

This is a fun game. The things that piss you off in them you love because the game tries to challenge you. It encourages exploration since certain puzzles and treasures require you to traverse multiple maps and zones to actually get to that fancy looking box you saw around the corner.  When a boss beats your ass (and they will, trust me.), it isn't "I was way too underlevel!" or "Wow, these mechanics are lame as hell." It's pure "...Okay, so when he does X I need to do Y.. I'm too slow with Z so I need to try W instead..." and so on so forth. When you win you feel rewarded. 

The challenges draw you in, and the story is pretty interesting so far already, and the game's still early access and has plenty a way to go. The music doesn't wear on you, and even having caught up to the current story I still find myself burning hours just trying to find MORE SECRETS and HOW THE HELL TO GET TO THEM. Plus I really like Lea. She's cute for a pixel chick.

Go check out the demo. If you like old school Zelda, or Secret of Mana, or even old school top down Contra, or any of those old school top down action RPGs, you'll love CrossCode.

25988572.review:
Where to start. This is my first review on steam, and this is the kind of game I've been waiting for, for a long time.

When I discovered Secret of Mana as a kid, I was hooked from start to finish. When I tried Seiken Densetsu III after it, same thing. I'm not sure how to explain what made these games so special to me, but never a game felt like these ones since. That is, you guessed it, until I tried CrossCode.

Yet, while capturing this nostalgia, CrossCode managed to shine in ways I never expected.

The combat. 
This isn't really a surprise, but the controls are tight and fighting in CrossCode is a real blast. Enemies can and will overwhelm you if you aren't careful. The skill tree isn't complete yet, but I can only see more awesomeness ahead.

The level design. 
Now I'm no expert, but it's always a pleasure to study the layout of each room to reach heights and find chests. The puzzles are - already in 0.8.1 - some of the best I've ever seen in this kind of game, and the platforming is top notch. 
I strongly advise to do all the quests in each areas as the later ones give access to interesting trials in previously unreachable rooms - I'm looking at you generator repair quest!

The setting and art. 
The Phantasy Star series instantly came to mind when I first saw CrossCode's trailer. I love the setting and music of these games, and the influence became even more apparent while playing. The story takes place in a MMOG, so you can often see busy other players running about, or having conversations with friends about some aspects of the game. This made the world that much more believable.

The story. 
Only part of it is available, but I'm really intrigued and can't wait to find out more. The feeling of leveling with a good buddy is the last thing I expected from this game, and it nailed it. Bravo.

Overall, considering early access, I am very optimistic. I haven't even touched the second dungeon because I am waiting for the story to be updated, and I already played this much.

If you relate to what I said, or just like good video games, I cannot recommend this game more.

I gotta say, I'm pleasantly surprised with this game.

This game is most definately NOT finished (v .8.2), yet, I only knew that really because the game is actually telling me where certain parts are actually implemented or not, and I would have not noticed anything til the game told me outright the story beyond a certain point is not yet complete.

Can't. Stop. Playing. [b]Help me![/b]

This game is just utter perfection! Like the characters in the game, I just can't stop playing it. There's so much to do, so much intrigue in the plot and the characters, so many tiny things to collect and massive areas to explore.

I'm often one of those RPG players who has to click on everything, do every sidequest, collect every item, find every hidden location etc, before I can move on with the story. And as of this review I've clocked 17 hours and I don't think I've even completed half of the story. Or half of the currently available sidequests and hidden items. I think I'll easily get 50 extremely enjoyable hours out of this, so that's my £15 well spent.

The combat is perfect: really fun, very immersive and super smooth. The enemies are extremely diverse and always create new challenges in each section of the game. The boss fights are epic and look absolutely beautiful for a pixel-style game like this one. The story is adorable and highly addictive (at least from where I've reached) and the characters are equally as interesting and diverse. The plot and setting is fantastic.

Welcome to Dark Souls meets Fable meets Helen's Mysterious Castle, in the future!
Very possibly the best game I've played this decade.


[u]PS.[/u] If you're not convinced by the 99% overwhelming positivity, [b]PLAY THE DEMO[/b]. That's what sold it for me. A perfect introduction and only a glimmer of what the game has to offer!

25940443.review:
This is a good game.

Contrary to what some of the reviews say, this game is somewhat of a slow boil gameplay wise. The story is neat if you're into .hack/sign-esque story with the whole trapped in a virutal world sort of thing. But it doesn't really show all of its cards until you reach the first dungeon of the game. There it will toss so many puzzles and neat mechanics it's like they were placing bread crumbs and then threw the entire loaf at you.

A game like this is good because of it's puzzles. I like the puzzles. They make you think. I like thinking. Once you get to the first dungeon, you begin to appreciate the time and effort these fellows put into designing this game. All of the puzzles are well designed, save a few which you can cheese  a bit.

The characters are endearing. I like Lea in particular. Though she lacks dialogue more or less, she makes up for it in her animations during dialogue sequences. The art team put a lot of work into conveying how Lea feels with only using one word. Since her vocabulary is so limited, it makes for some truly hilarious moments.

Aside from that, Emile is a neat contrast to Lea. I like to think of her as the driving force for the story. Without her, it feels like Lea would just not do things. She also has an animation that makes me think of that Futurama meme with Fry.

Now for gameplay. It's pretty slick. You can go from melee to ranged quite easily. I prefer mouse and keyboard since it makes aiming your projectiles a lot easier. You get a lot of customization for how you want to play. Eventually the skill tree expands and once you get elements the combat really opens up because you get something like an empowered mode when you pick an element. Picking a specific element boosts a lot of your stats during combat, but you can't keep it up all the time so there's a sort of balance there. Eventually, though skill unlocks, you can prolong the element a lot longer.

Now to the story. It is interesting since I like virtual reality games a la .hack/sign, but I'm not fond of the story structure. It's fine for some people for sure, but it's one of those stories where they don't tell you anything until the end. Everything leading up to that point is mostly fragmented memories. They even use the dreaded amensia thing, so yeah, not that great. Nevertheless, the pacing is good enough and they play a bit with exposition. It's not flung in your face. Everything can be found in the encyclopedia.

So I would recommend this game if you're interested in a pixel art action type of thing. Though the game has a demo, the game doesn't get interesting until the first dungeon where you have to think about manipulating your projectiles to solve puzzles.

25921919.review:
Hello,

I'm not very good at writing rewiews on the fly without talking with someone live but.. I really really love this game for a long time now and I feel it can use the support and deserves it.

First the game slipped past my radar, and I love action RPG's a lot. And this game? It really gave me that excited kid out of me again when I first played the on-website-demo. Right away the controls felt super smooth and super accurate. The story didn't have much back then and the game was split in half with a tiny but of story (tutorial) content and an exploration mode. Which was kind of an open world idea at the time I guess? Later on after I purchased the Steam version which had a few more updates they were tying those together nicely. It wasn't as open world as I expected but it's still very nice.

The game kind of let's you focus on 2 classes or playstyles. Maybe 3 if you chose for a hybrid such as myself. You can either chose to go all melee based or if you try to play it safe you can play range based. This through your equips which stats mostly either go towards a melee build or a ranged build. Besides that you get point to spend on a Final Fantasy X sphere grid like skill and stat boost system.

Now let me add something on the developers. In one word they're awesome. Let me explain what I mean... As most people following the Indie market know we've had a few terrible examples recent year. One of them that stood out for me was Mighty No.9 and their completely lack of transparency and contact with their backers. RadicalFishGames is like the total opposite. They are active about anywhere. Twitter, Reddit, as well they have their own forum. And on all of them they are very active and very friendly/open towards their backers. Bug reports, while sometimes made fun of, are taken seriously and fixed in the next update. Besides that I think every 1 or 2 weeks they also have a dev stream on Twitch. During those streams you can actually see them work on developping the game while they can answer questions directly to people asking in the chat.

Speaking of updates the game kind of has a linear development. Each several months there's a new early access update all backers get. Mostly there's a littlebit more story progression, and play/world wise you can progress a bit further. Among the lines of the story goes up to a dungeon/city/specific location but you can still play further. It just won't have any story etc. yet. Also each update you mostly get a few new skills and gears to play around with.

For now I think my rewiew is long enough and I really hope it will draw some people over the edge on trying this game. If anything try the demo at first! You won't regret it if you like these kind of games!

(P.S. I may edit the review here and there later in case things change in future updates. Not for the bad though!)

25907290.review:
Cross Code is a 2d action RPG with excellent puzzle elements wraped up in the guise of an MMORPG. If you're a fan of 16/32 bit era RPGS, you're in for a treat!

Completly blown away by the polish in every regard and to think this is only early access! I'll write a full review after release but I'm gonna name drop a few similarities to other games that should get you giving this a go (which you should!)

[b]Cross Code [/b] is a 2d action RPG with excellent puzzle elements wraped up in the guise of an MMORPG. 

[b]Story[/b] has a .HACK/Star Ocean kind of vibe, the writing is cracking being genuinely funny a lot of the time and protaganist Lea is a genius twist on the mute hero trope (Hi! Hi! Lea.) 
[b]Combat[/b] is a mash up of Enter the Gungeon + Secret of Mana with an emphasis on challenege that could scratch a Dark Souls enthusiast itch.
[b]Progression[/b] system uses a spin on Final Fantasy X sphere grid with emphasis on MMO style trading monster parts for gear.
[b]Puzzles[/b] get a special shout out as they're the best in ANY ARPG I've played since the Golden Sun series on GBA!.
[b]Art/Ascetic[/b] comes from the GBA/PSX era of sprite art backed up by portait art that's anime in style but almost as expressive as the famous french animations studios.

All in all, I'm having a blast with Cross Code and I hope Radical Fish gets all the success they deserve with this gem.

Crosscode is not a finished game yet (written just after the release of 0.8.1), but I already have faith that this game will be amazing, and here's why. Also, no spoilers below.
The game really shines in its combat and puzzling, which is what you're probably going to be doing for most of the game, but since these things are fun themselves, you can quickly see yourself just going on a killing spree because the fighting itself is just fun. The quick combined with the way that they designed enemies so that there's always a pretty skillful way to beat them is what makes it fun for me. This is not a game where you go grinding because you want a certain piece of gear (most of the time), but because grinding can be really fun, and this is what makes Crosscode one of the better RPGs. The Puzzle element of the game is also really interesting and they've kept adding new elements to the puzzles each temple (so far).
Crosscode really is a unique experience that I recommend to anyone who wants to pick up a game with a new twist on combat or one with a pretty good story... Actually, I'd just recommend it to most people really.
Have fun playing the game!

25646442.review:
Ordinarily, it's very difficult to recommend an early access title on steam. Crosscode, however, is an exception. 20 bucks might seem like a bit much, but it's important to realize that I got about 15 hours of gameplay playing the game straight through. I've clocked in about 34 hours at this point just sidequesting, exploring, and just doing whatever I wanted. 

As for the actual gameplay, I'd compare it to a more combat oriented 2D Zelda. The game also excels in incorporating puzzle elements, so fans of 2D Zelda games will feel right at home. For me personally, Crosscode has some of the best overall gameplay I've experienced in several years. 

I really don't want to give away too much about this game, but at least try the demo if you're interested. It's about 45 minutes long and helps introduce you to the gameplay and story a bit. Plus if you really like it but don't feel like losing your progress, you can actually skip this entire intro section as soon as you boot the game up. I can safely say that even as the product is now, it was well worth the 20 dollars I paid for it.

25534791.review:
Even though this game is in early access I've played it for +20 hours and I'm not done with all the quests and only did one dungeon (there's 2 available and they are planning to add 3 more mini dungeons) and I must say I love the heck out of this game. I CANNOT wait until the full release. It basically takes an MMORPG and takes out all the bits I don't like (how it's basically aimless apart from leveling up). If you take up all the quests there is minimal grinding and once you upgrade your items in the next town and do some side quests (some of them which have a story while some are basically just collect x amount of y), you won't believe how easy you beat the enemies you were dying over and over to just a few levels ago, making it much easier to progress or collect items you will need for trading, quests and selling. The controls are incredibly tight and satisfying, the zelda-like jump is flawless and if you fall it's basically your fault. 

The only thing frustrating about the game is that in one part of the game the platforms are sometimes too small and they are also "icy" (so slippery but sometimes also with ice growing out of them that you need to destroy...but it regrows very fast) so you basically jump onto them and slip right down into the abyss very easily, but I guess that's just platforming! The point is sometimes it's hard to get to where you want to go because of this, you need to be incredibly precise and quick. These places are also randomly placed, like basically you want to go through a door but in order to be able to do that you need to get on three little slidy platforms with ice growing out of them, you need to destroy each piece of ice after you jump on the prior platform and then destory the next, do a perfect jump and not slide off, and repeat this a few times and it's not even part of a puzzle. 

Oh and there's a lot of puzzles....a lot of classic ice sliding puzzles too...which sort of got boring after the 3rd one even though they do mix it up with additional features.

Pros: 
-Amazing soundtrack
-Quest system
-Feels like a real MMORPG
-Guilds! (I'm not sure if you will be able to select one other than the one selected for you)
-Trading
-Items give different stats, and sometimes may decrease one thing while increasing another compared to your equipped item, so choices to be had 
-Skill tree!
-Real time combat with special moves!
-Precise dodging/blocking (which is a lot of fun)
-So far great and interesting story (it's not done yet, I've read about 30-40 percent of the story is finished by now)
-Tight controls
-Minimal backtracking (mostly for quests, not frustrating as there is a teleport system)
-Very nice pixel art 
-And seemingly hours and hours of fantastic gameplay! 

Cons:
-Too many slidy puzzles
-Random annoyingly hard platforming which doesn't add anything to the game but frustration
-No multiplayer planned (which isn't a big con for me but might be for some)
-Game pauses when you open the menu to select an item but not while you consume the item to heal etc., you most likely end up taking more damage than you healed if enemy isn't focusing other party member as you are stationary while you use the item (for about a second or two), or if you didn't manage to go very far away from the enemy (most of them have a way of quickly getting back to you even if you run across the screen from them)

For the rest, play the game and see how you feel

I'm very picky when it comes to games and I have to say, I sit down and find myself being 7 hours into Cross Code without knowing where the time has gone, just like Emilie. 

For an early access, I'm incredibly hyped, 10/10, will check every day to see if new update was released.

25357418.review: Hi! This game takes all the best elements from the 16-bit era ARPG/JRPG and combines them into a 21st century package full of fun, challenge, charm, intrigue, and....balls. Great level design full of secrets, puzzles, and enemies. This game encourages backtracking, but in a good way. You don't even have to fight enemies if you don't want to. They are only aggro if you attack. Otherwise, explore to your hearts content, and  complete quests as you see fit. Then grind out some Flamin' Hillkats or Mad Bovines for items, exp and as a bonus... stress relief. It feels rewarding to use the many attacks and defensive mechanisms in the game. As a fan of Zelda, Secret of Mana, Chrono Trigger, this hits all the nostalgia spots with the fresh feel of a modern game. With a splash of tongue in cheek humor and really clever design choices it all adds up to a stellar game. If this tweaks your teats in the slightest then hurry up and buy this retro/modern masterpiece!

25280356.review:
[h1] CrossCode [/h1]
[b] This game is amazing! [/b]

Its most unique aspect is its basis. CrossCode is a singleplayer game, but you play in an MMORPG world. That means the developers went through the effort of naming characters to be realistic player usernames, and there are costant amounts of NPC players everywhere you go. Its pretty phenominal, and really makes it feel alive. Its actually pretty fun to play too. The progression can be a bit slow, but that's because of the strategy that is involved with combat. 
It's a worthy buy.

Here is why:

[u]Pros:[/u]
[list]
    [*] Classic MMORPG progression[list]
        [*]    - Perks to customise your fighting style (Defense, Health, Damage, Focus)
        [*]    - Skill Trees
        [*]    - Unique NPC recruitment system (Party System)
        [*]    - Crafting/Trading
        [*]    - Looting[/list]
    [*] Beautiful Graphics[list]
        [*]    - The pixelart used in CrossCode is professional. Sticks to all the rules.
        [*]    - Environemnts are breathtaking
        [*]    - Chat characters look great[/list]
    [*] "Challenging" Combat[list]
        [*]    - Fast paced - Ocarina style fighting (Patterns)
        [*]    - Lots of dodging (looking at you darksouls)
        [*]    - Special Attacks[/list]
    [*] Puzzles for days![list]
        [*]    - Parkour puzzles!
        [*]    - Timing puzzles!
        [*]    - Blast stuff puzzles![/list]
[/list]
[u]Cons:[/u]
[list]
    [*] Quests can sometimes be confusing/unclear
    [*] Character's weapons and armor don't change when equipped[list]
        [*]    - Also the items dont have unique thumbnails - just general to classify type
        [*]    - Kind of a bummer, it may be added later, but it would be nice to see that sort of detail[/list]
    [*] First 10 player levels are pretty slow[list]
        [*]    - Dont get me wrong, I had a blast, but it took me two hours to get to level 10
                  though its possible I just suck.[/list]
[/list]

And yeah, thats about it . . . So far I adore CrossCode and look forward to future updates!

25269195.review:
Wow!
I almost never buy games at full price anymore, but I had two friends recommend this game to me who have never talked to each other. Then I played the demo. ... Then I bought the game.
This is based off of just beating the first boss, which I literally just finished after playing for 10-ish hours. The game is mechanically incredibly solid, it's a cross of zelda, contra, and the Tales games basically. (I would reference chrono trigger but I haven't really played through it ...) There's a lot of depth, the game is challenging without being completely overwhelming [at least for me], there's a lot of puzzles and secrets. You generally don't have to fight most things in the game unless you want to. The game just feels ... solid. Like it came from the SNES and is a Nintendo title somehow.

I've had a lot of fun with this so far, and am very excited for the full release and plot to be fully fleshed out. :)

25158025.review:
Crosscode는 어느 날 가상 현실 게임 'CrossWorld'에 기억을 잃은 채 접속하게 된 주인공 'Lea'가 게임 속에서 잃어버린 자신의 기억을 찾기 위해 고군분투 하는 것에 관한 이야기를 다룬 게임입니다.
게임의 설정에서 큰 비중을 차지하는 가상 현실 게임 CrossWorld는 MMORPG를 표방하고 있는데, 이 설정을 게임 속에서 꽤 설득력 있게 풀어내고 있다는 점을 주요 매력 포인트로 꼽을 수 있습니다. 주인공 Lea의 직업은 Spheremancer로, 원거리와 근거리 전투를 겸하는 하이브리드 직업을 가지고 있고, 근접 전투를 선호하는 Pentafist나 마법을 사용하는 Hexacast와 같은 다른 직업의 NPC들과 파티를 맺어 게임을 진행하게 됩니다.
또, 게임을 플레이하시다보면 필드에 NPC들이 돌아다니는 것을 볼 수 있는데, 이러한 요소가 마치 싱글 플레이 게임을 멀티 플레이 게임처럼 느끼게 해줍니다. 전 '자신을 털어먹은 전설적인 토깽이를 잡아달라'는 퀘스트를 수행하기 위해 일단 다른 토깽이들을 쳐잡아 전설적인 토깽이를 잡기 위한 미끼를 얻고 있었는데, 주변에 저와 비슷하게 생긴 플레이어들이 돌아다녀서 '저것들도 나와 같은 퀘스트를 하는 게 아닌가' 생각이 들어 퀘스트 몹을 몰이사냥하곤 했습니다.
많은 게임들이 보여주는 오글거리는 전개가 없다는 것도 Crosscode의 장점으로 곱을 수 있겠습니다. 게임 속 등장인물들은 꽤나 그럴듯한, 있을 법한 고민과 갈등을 가지고 그것을 해결해 나갑니다. 우리의 주인공 Lea의 경우,  의사소통 모듈에 문제가 있어 특정 단어로 밖에 말을 할 수 없습니다. 처음에는 눈보라 회사의 돌 게임에 등장하는 안녕 로봇마냥 'Hi'  라고밖에 말을 할 수 없어서, 고개를 끄덕거리거나 내젓는 것으로 의사소통을 하는 모습을 보여줍니다. 게임 속에서 처음 만나게 될 동료인 에밀리의 경우, Crossworld를 너무 열심히 플레이하다 늦잠을 자버려서 스터디에 제대로 참여하지 못 했다며 투덜대기도 합니다. 이런 '그럴듯한' 설득력 있는 묘사들이 Crosscode를 플레이할 때 유저들이 게임에 쉽게 몰입할 수 있게 도와주는 장치라고 생각합니다.

http://postfiles6.naver.net/20160826_277/knight7537_1472201424853C6gpM_JPEG/KakaoTalk_20160826_174910717.jpg?type=w3
[게임을 하시다보면 이렇게 해맑게 인사하는 레아의 모습을 보실 수 있습니다.]

http://postfiles16.naver.net/20160826_63/knight7537_1472201425169quQLC_JPEG/KakaoTalk_20160826_174910033.jpg?type=w3
[또한 다양한 표정의 레아도 보실 수 있습니다. 표정이 풍부한 레아 넘나 귀여운 것...]

게임의 주요 목표는 네 개의 원소를 모으는 것입니다. 현재는 불의 원소를 얻는 과정까지만 거의 온전히 업데이트 되어 있습니다. 아직 게임이 개발 중이다보니 이 이후의 이야기는 추후 업데이트될 예정입니다. 그렇지만 지금까지 업데이트된 분량도 꽤 많습니다. 전 현재까지 업데이트 된 분량을 플레이하는 데 열 네 시간 정도 걸렸습니다. 언더테일 불살 엔딩을 보는 데 열 시간 정도 걸렸으니까 이 정도면 꽤 볼륨감 있는 스토리가 있다고 할 수 있을  것 같습니다. 차후의 업데이트까지 생각한다면 더욱 말이죠.

게임의 전투 시스템은 근접 공격과 원거리 공격, 그리고 다양한 속성(현재까진 불 속성과 무 속성밖에 사용할 수 없습니다)을 적절히 활용해 상대의 약점을 공략하는 방식의 플레이가 주를 이룹니다. 핵 앤 슬래시 게임처럼 막 팬다고 데미지가 들어가는 식이 아니고, 예를 들면 얼음 갑옷을 두르고 있는 적은 불 속성의 공격으로 갑옷을 녹여 취약한 상태로 만든 후 데미지를 주는 방식으로 플레이를 하시게 됩니다. 생각 없이 막 팬다고 깰 수 있는 구조가 아니라 추리력을 발휘해 게임을 플레이하도록 설정해놓아서 저는 이런 방식이 꽤 맘에 들었지만, 속도감 있는 플레이를 원하시는 분들에겐 마이너스적인 요소가 될 수도 있겠습니다.

아직은 얼리 억세스인 게임이지만, 현재까지 보여준 모습만으로도 충분히 기대되는 게임이라고 생각합니다. 다른 분이 리뷰에서 언급하셨던 것처럼 크로스코드도 언더테일 같이 흥했으면 좋겠습니다. 대규모 업데이트를 앞두고 있다고 하니, 업데이트 이전에 미리 사셔서 게임을 즐기시다가 업데이트 이후 새로운 맵과 스토리를 즐기시는 것도 괜찮을 것 같습니다.

이런 분에게 추천합니다 : Ori and the blind forest 처럼 전투와 퍼즐이 함께 있는 게임을 즐기시는 분, 도트가 너무 좋으신 도트박이 분들, 다양한 표정의 캐릭터를 보는 것을 좋아하시는 분들

처음 쓰는 스팀 게임 리뷰라 쓰면서 손발이 좀 부들부들 떨렸습니다. 네-코파라 리뷰를 쓰신 분처럼 위트 넘치는 리뷰를 쓰고 싶었지만 필력이 후달려서 그러질 못 했네요. 크로스코드는 제 리뷰보다 훨씬 재밌는 게임이니, 이 리뷰가 재미 없으시더라도 게임에 관해 미리 실망하지 않으셨으면 좋겠습니다. 이 게임을 플레이하면서 느꼈던 즐거움을 다른 분들도 같이 느끼셨으면 좋겠네요. 쓸데없이 긴 리뷰를 줄이겠습니다.

25090104.review:
I first heard about this game a year or two years two, but I never had the time to invest in it, that is, until a few days ago.

CrossCode is all I ever needed to relive my childhood from when I used to have an SNES back in the early 90s! It is definitely a blast from the past.

It takes every classic 2D game you hold dear and combines them with modern game physics. The overall setting and gameplay is amazing, and the plot is very intriguing. The MMOG ambiance really makes the world feel like you're in a living multiplayer setting regardless that it's singleplayer game, with believable characters who show emotions and disbelief very well.

It is already my favourite modern 2D game out there of that genre, perhaps even the best one I ever played. The sprites and all the animations are very well done and I am already having goosebumps and nostalgic vibes playing what seems to bring out the same kind of fun that I had a growing up as a kid. I'll be keeping an eye on future updates for this game and will recommend it to some friends for sure!

25085863.review: When finished, this game will easily be one of my favorites. I'm super pumped to see where they take this game.

25063006.review:
WOW!
Einfach nur WOW!

Was für ein Spiel... In jeder Hinsicht macht das Spiel unheimlich viel Spaß. Es hat einen sehr angenehmen "Flow". Man wird von Anfang an sehr gut mit der Spielmechanik vertraut gemacht. Das gelingt in Kombination mit der anfänglichen Geschichte hervorragend. Ich möchte an dieser Stelle natürlich nicht spoilern, aber eins vorab: das Können, die Fähigkeiten, die "Spielregeln" werden eng mit der Story verbunden erklärt. Selten hatte ich so einen willkommen, wohlfühlenden und interessanten Einstieg erlebt.
Die Dialoge sind klasse. Ohne Sprachausgabe, aber angesichts der vielen Dialoge ist das meiner Meinung nach besser als mit Sprachausgabe. Leider sind die Texte ab ca. einer Stunde Spielzeit nach und nach nur noch in Englisch (aber das ist ja auch die Early-Access-Version) - in der finalen Fassung natürlich nicht mehr.. Es wird viiieeel geredet (aber keinen langeweiligen Kram). Fans von Zelda und/oder Final Fantasy werden sich erfreuen. Sehr vieles wirkt vertraut von älteren Retro-Spielen, was aber nicht heißen soll, dass das schlecht ist. Das Spiel ist auf seine Weise trotzdem sehr eigen - und das ist auch gut so!
Der Wechsel von Action zu Erkundung läuft fließend. Die Kämpfe sind teilweise sehr herrausfordern und es wird in dem Spiel stellen geben die für absolute Freaks geschaffen sind. Es ist schön wenn man eine Quest schafft und hinterher noch einen drauf gesetzt bekommt die gleiche Quest ohne Schild und mit einem Zeitlimit zu absolvieren - mir fiel die Kinnlade runter, da ich die Quest an sich schon sehr happig fand -> Klasse, solche Momente! Davon gibt es sicherlich noch reichlich.
Was die Kämfpe angeht: sie machen uuuunheimlich viel Spaß! Da kommt wieder dieser "Flow" ins Spiel, den ich erwähnt hatte. Die Steuerung ist derart simpel, dass damit wirklich niemand irgendwelche Probleme haben sollte. Ich habe noch nie oder nur sehr selten so eine gute, einfache (aber dennoch komplexe) und flüssige Steuerung in einem Spiel gesehen bzw. erlebt. Super!
Die Grafik ist ebenfalls ein Augenschmaus - ja, ich meine das ernst! Wir reden hier schließlich von einem 2D-Action-RPG... Die Farben sind super, die vielen Details sind klasse, die Charaktere und überhaupt das Art-Design ist ein gelungener Mix aus Fantasy und Science Fiction. Toll!
Und zu all dem dann noch richtig coole Retro-Mukke im Hintergrund. Ich fühlte mich wieder wie ein Kind, als ich früher auf dem SuperNintendo solche Spiele spielte.

Meiner Meinung nach einer der besten Spiele in den letzten Jahren. Ich spiele es schon die ganze Zeit und denke ständig, dass die Eary-Access-Version hinter der nächsten Tür vorbei ist. Pustekuchen! Seit 21 Stunden ist noch kein Ende in Sicht und es gibt noch sooo viele offene Quests.
Einfach spitze was Radical Fish Games hier abliefert.

Absolute Kaufempfehlung!!!

CrossCode basically got good things in store for most people: 
Are you an explorative (j/a/mmo-)RPG player or the completionistic/character-building hack'n'slay fan? This could be your next favourite game! Do you prefer twin-stick shooters or rather character action games? Doesn't matter, CrossCode got you covered~ Or you like challenging puzzle-(plattformer-)games, but are seeking a new perspective on things? This might be the game you're looking for! (...Get it? Because it has a tricky top-down camera~) If you need a story-driven game, love sci-fi themes or just like or even hate anime tropes: CrossCodes world and characters keep you involved, or you can choose to just ignore them and let the gameplay do all the talking!

It's actually hard to think of a reason why you wouldn't give CrossCode a try and you definitely should, since there's even a free demo right under your nose! The only negative point that comes to mind is that you will have to go through a pretty linear, lengthy and text-heavy introduction/tutorial area of the game (which is unfortunately also the entire content of the demo afaik) until the world finally starts to open up for you and lets the player roam more freely if that is what you mostly care about. Other than that it comes down to what kind of player you are, since there's a chance you will either find the puzzles or fights a tad too demanding, but in that case you shouldn't feel bad about making use of internet resources to find some solutions or enemy weak points to get to the next chunk of your preferred content more quickly and less frustrated (you know, kinda like Dark Souls :^)) …at least until the devs decide to implement an ingame hint-system and adjustable difficulty settings~ (For now just be ensured that all fights are winnable even far below the recommended level and make sure to take all the sidequests to fasten up the leveling process in the background, before you complain about "The Grind")

Only thing left to say is that there are probably many people like myself, who have similar games from their childhood that they hold above all other (be it Secret of Mana, Terranigma or A Link to the Past, which are all without a doubt great timeless classics), but for me that nostalgic spot in my heart now belongs to CrossCode, even while it's still in early access~

24811642.review:
I have been playing this game for a while and it is definitely my favorite RPG in a long time.  The fighting is comprable to Ys: Origins in style and speed, though I would say CrossCode is a little faster and defniitely more in depth and challenging.  I suck with controller but I really like how they set up the mouse and keyboard (cursor close to sprite= melee, cursor far from sprite= ranged in that direction).  The extensiveness of the skill tree is impressive as well and I really like the concept of being able to "switch" your skill branches on the fly. 

Another really positive thing is the trading system.  You have to grind a bit to get trade items to trade in for higher weapons and armor, as opposed to just buying things.  I thought this was a great system and gets the player more involved in hunting for specific loot.

The storyline itself is phenomenal.  I hate spoilers so I will just say that it has almost a Sword Art Online feel to the story and the way they incorporate little references is a lot of fun.  

Sometimes in really intense battles you can get a little laggy (I have 16GB RAM, AMD Phenom II 3.2ghz X6 processor, and GTX 970 with 4GB VRAM with the game installed on a Solid State Drive so I don't think it is my build).  I haven't tried playing in any mode other than fullscreen at 1080p resolution though on a 56" Flat panel TV, so it may just be other variables.  

Speaking of, the artwork in this game is AMAZING!  The pixel art never looks choppy or lazy and the way they did the terrain makes it easy to tell where you are jumping to and from height-wise and directionally.  

The puzzles in the game are challenging but not overwhelming.  I would say they are similar to the puzzles you would find in Lufia II.  

Definitely check it out though, the game is on my top favorites list.  Hope you enjoy it as much as I am!

24718465.review:
CrossCode is a wonderful game, and it is absloutely worth playing. 

Even though (at the time of writing) the game is still in development, it's incredibly well polished. The developers put their attention to detail: the gameplay is fluid, the environment and soundtrack are beautifully rich, and the story is very engaging.

The game strikes an excellent balance between puzzles, platforming, and battles. The dungeons are filled with both challenging monsters and puzzles and progress smoothly, gradually teaching new mechanics without babying you the whole way through. But puzzles are not limited to just the dungeons; the fields are also filled with platforming puzzles that reward the player with loot bearing crates and new areas to explore. The battles are dynamic and somewhat faster paced, but not too fast as to make them overly difficult. And as you explore the skill tree, options for combat are diverse, but not overly complex.

There's also a load of wonderful humor and charm throughout the game, from dialogues and character backstories to hidden references to other games and media.

However, don't just take my word for it… Try out the demo for yourself!

24576766.review:
Итак, что же такое Crosscode? Это великолепный сплав экшен-рпг и пазл составляющей, при этом не забывающий о сюжете. Хоть игра еще не закончена, здесь уже есть чем занятся и на что посмотреть. Пройдемся по пунктам:

1. Графика. Пиксельная, но довольно приятная на вид, немного схожа с RPG maker играми. Но при этом все движения плавные и динамичные. Особенно радуют портреты персонажей. Учитывая почти полную немоту главной героини, ее эмоции в разговорах передаются этим самым портретом, и отлично я вам скажу передаются! Иногда просто на смех распирает с  некоторых мордашек. Хочется пожать руку художнику.

2. Геймплей. Рпг составляющая выполнена очень и очень неплохо. Шмот, прокачка, билды - все это на месте, и довольно разнообразно. Хочется немного прикопаться, к тому что ну очень неудобно крафтить новый шмот (а точнее менять у торговцев на соответсвующие материалы), можно посмотреть, что именно тебе нужно для крафта только в городе, у соотвествующего торговца. Так что лично я на это дело забил, играть это мне, нужно сказать, не мешало.

3. Боевка. Это наверное одно из самых главных и притягательных в Crosscode. Динамичная и ураганная боевка идет резко в разрез, к тому, чего ожидаешь увидеть от подобной игры. Чтобы победить приходится уклонятся и быстро бросаться в атаку, пока "окно атаки" не закрылось. А разнообразие билдов только прибавляет вариативности в стретигию боя.

4. Пазлы. О них много писать не буду. Здешние головоломки можно сравнить с Порталом. Не сказать, что легкие, но и не настолько сложные, чтобы лезть в интернет за их решением. Нужно лишь немного приложить голову. А также по всей карте спрятаны контейнеры с разнообразными плюхами: от расходников до легендарных оружий; Некоторые из которых достать труднее, чем решение многих обязательных пазлов, но в отличие от них это не так уж и обязательно (если вы конечно не манчкин)

5. Сюжет и персонажи. Последнее по списку, но не по значению. Сюжет в игре довольно таки хорош и в некоторой степени оригинален. Главная героиня, Лея, потеряла память, и теперь должна отправится в ММОРПГ в реальном мире, в котором люди играют за специальных аватаров. Звучит немного запутанно, но на деле просто. Персонажи хороши как на подбор. О главной героини, вынужденной изображать эмоции практически без слов я уже говорил. Второстепенные персонажи, а также наша первейшая подруга Элиминатор, тоже вызывают в основном положительные эмоции.

Подведем итог: Игра очень и очень хороша, она уже сейчас, в раннем доступе, способна увлечь на многие часы игры. Нисколько не жалею что купил ее 
9/10

П.С Для меня остается загадкой, почему эта игра так непопулярна?

I don't know where to start with the compliments for this game.
I first played it when it was first released in the web browser when there was only a short story when compared with the depth of crosscode's storyline now. It has made some amazing and vast improvements to the game which include from creating an adventure mode which brings the whole game aside from the previously linear storyline which also hold many sidequests for you to spend hours of your time having fun with, new and awesomely animated abilities that bring exitement to the allready engaging combat system, and more additions to the world map in adventure mode which get updated (I would say every 3 - 4 months maybe) that bring a singleplayer game (so far..) into a simulated npc multiplayer world that acts like they are part of the game from thier own view.

24520031.review:
Not likely to change anyone's decision, but I'll mention this is my first review. I did not expect what I found at all. This game is too well done to let it fail; so I will do what I can to promote it.

This review was written as of  build 0.7.1. Game/story only goes up to, not including, the second dungeon.

TL:DR

Pros:
- Well drawn/animated
- Challenging combat and puzzle sections.
- Relatable realistic character interation.

Cons:
- At build 0.7.1, there isn't a whole lot of story yet. It took up 12 hours at this point with minimal side-questing, so I won't say it's short, just incomplete.
- A bit grind heavy when getting items to trade with. There are some traders that trade for the basics, but it still requires some other items to get them. More common items, but still. Keep in mind you don't have to trade. You can find equipment in the wild if you search the areas at more than a simple glance.

Full Opinion:

Downloaded the demo first to have a look. It seemed like a decent retro-style action/adventure that might be fun for a few hours. I was utterly blown away by what I found. The tutorial is a short 10 minutes or so explanation to just give the most basic parts. The combat is fairly simple, but the abilities you learn are well done and fun to use. The enemies are implemented in a way that you will have a hard time if you just run around hitting the attack button. Personally I always feel most games are a little too easy these days, so that's a plus to me. The puzzles are varied, sufficiently chanllenging, and introduce new ideas without burying you in tutorial. The new ideas are added without warning or explanation. You'll just walk into a room, see a switch or button you need, and ask yourself "How do I get that? Maybe I should try this new object over here? But how does it work? Hit it? Shoot it? Fire? Slide on the ice?" As for the story, there hasn't been much developement at this point. There are two main plots. The plot for the MMO is a generic "gather the elements" type of quest, but they have handled it well so far (more or less paying homage to how MMO's often are and how players would act toward them) and have spoken of a far deeper narrative beneath it. The plot outside of the MMO (How the herione got there and why) hasn't moved much just yet. Personally, I find the character interaction to be a shining example of how to flesh out character traits without over-playing it. You don't need slapstick gags or some running joke to make them memorable. Between that and the well drawn character portraits for these sections, the story segments are honestly a joy.

24410428.review:
In short: This game is amazing, and you should be buying it right now. Even it's in incomplete state, it's a masterpiece.

Detailed review:

Graphics 10/10 - CrossCode has a beautiful 16-bit art style. This really comes to shine in the gorgeous close-up portraits of the characters seen during dialogues. Not only that, the world is also amazingly beautiful with small details everywhere that really make you think the devs care deeply about the looks of their game. If I only cared about the visuals, then those alone would've made me buy the game.

Music 9/10 - Not a lot to say here, the music is just all around nice. And there's a lot of unique pieces heard in different areas of the game.

Combat 10/10 - Combat in this game feels really fluid and every hit feels impactful. There are many ways to utilize your base kit - throwing balls, fighting melee, guarding, and dashing - and your talent trees and equipment offer a lot of customization. On top of that, there are 4 elemental attack modes.

Puzzles 10/10 - Probably my favourite part of this game. The puzzle design in CrossCode is just genius. Never did the puzzles feel unfairly hard or frustrating, but they always offered a fair bit of challenge. Currently, there are 4 proper dungeons that combine puzzles and combat together. Some enemies are puzzles themselves - you need to figure out a way to beat them, just going in and fisting everybody is not the solution. Key parts of the puzzles are the ball throwing mechanic and different elemental interactions.

Story 10/10 - The story is probably my second-favourite thing about CrossCode, although it's nowhere near complete and all the big twists are yet to happen. There's just something about it that makes me want more every time the new story segment ends. The colourful characters, the humorous dialogue; it's just all around very light-hearted and not too serious.

Amount of content currently: I got about 14 hours playing the story from start to finish, completing most of the side quests and doing all 4 dungeons. I had, however, already played through the dungeons so I knew exactly how to do the puzzles, and didn't spend as much time as a first-time-player would've spent doing them. Currently, if you do all the content in the game, collecting the hidden treasures and completing all the side quests, I think you could get around 25 hours. This number is obviously going to change when more content gets added (the game is around 2/3 done I think) but already, it is easily worth 20 bucks. 

Also: as you can see I have over 80 hours of playtime on CrossCode which just goes to show that the game is so good I'm willing to play it multiple times from the beginning even though it has pretty much no replayability value as of yet (that will change when they add the NG+ mode).

24232561.review:
Really promising. Note that this is still in EA, so it is NOT complete! If you want to play a demo, there is one available on the official website. 

I backed this game on Kickstarter with 60 Euros based entirely on the demo - it was THAT good. Now that an EA build has released, I'm quite happy to say that I'm enjoying where the game is headed. The systems in place are looking really polished for what is essentially a pre-alpha build, with less than a quarter of the intended content available (based on the fact that you unlock only one of the four elements available in the game in the current build, 0.7.1), and the gameplay is really smooth. Reminds me of Ys, though more exploration/RPG focused and less so pure-action as Ys games are, so maybe more LoZ. LoZ style game with Ys style combat might be a good way of describing it.

Pros:
- Aesthetically pleasing. Usually I don't like the 8-bit or whatever style, but the pixel art in this game is gorgeous.
- Great gameplay; actions feel responsive and tactile, rather than sluggish or delayed. 
- The story is intriguing so far.
- Characters are great, smug faces are 11/10.
- Puzzles are suitably difficult without mind-bendingly obscure, though some of the more precise puzzles can be a bit frustrating at times.
- Exploration is rewarding.
- Characters actually run around instead of walking, thank GOD. Speed feels fast enough to be fast, but slow enough to be precise.
- I really enjoyed the universe of the game ("MMORPG" set on a real planet), though it might not sit with everyone. The 4th wall breaks aren't obnoxious and are well paced, IMO.
- I also like the character level progression system in the game, though some people might find it restricting for a SP game. 

Cons:
- You may not like the number of (very precise) jumping puzzles there are in the game. There are a LOT. 
- The art style sometimes makes it hard to judge elevation between platforms, which is mildly annoying but not painfully so.
- The rare-drop system feels mildly forced. I would rather 'rare' drops intead drop every X number of monsters, which allows the player to farm for guaranteed drops rather than needing to charge up the battle meter etc etc. I think currently the drop rate isn't bad, but finding that one rare drop for a quest is always a pain in the bum.
- Quest system is MMO-like, which may turn you off. Talk to X, get me Y amount of Z, etc. I personally don't mind it as long as it's not annoying (get me FIVE HUNDRED RABBIT TAILS!). The quests encourage exploration, so for me this is a plus, but for a lot of other people they might find the sub-questing tiresome or annoying, considering the game is a SP game!

If a dev reads this, I also think they should implement a hotkey system where you can bind certain menus to other hotkeys on your keyboard. It's annoying to have to go through multiple menus to access details on side quests, rather than having a separate button for it to flip in and out to read quickly. 

Overall, I definitely recommend you at least check out the demo, and if you don't subscribe to EA, at least give CrossCode a follow. I'm looking forward to the completed project, and until the full game releases I'll probably try to stop thinking about it so I don't ruin it.

24127308.review:
「こんなゲームを待っていた！！」

2016年サマーセールで購入しました。
Ver.0.7.1をプレイ
公開されているストーリーのクリアまで12～14時間程度

このゲームを一言で表現するなら
「ドイツ人が英独語圏に向けて全力で作ったJRPG」
「２D版ゼノブレイド+イース+MMORPG風味」
「ありそうでなかったSFC風ARPG」
といったところでしょうか

＜良かった点＞

・美麗なドットグラフィック
→海と雲、青と白のコントラストや紅葉、荒涼とした岩山や雪山、
砂埃の舞う砂漠に緑溢れるオアシスなど初見で綺麗だなと思える景色が広がります。

・軽快な操作性
→動かすだけでも楽しいくらいにキビキビ動きます。
箱コンに最適化しておりレスポンスも素晴らしいです。

・秀逸なマップデザイン
→２Dマップでありながら立体構造となっており、一見到達出来そうもない場所でも、
工夫と閃きで到達可能なように作られています。ダンジョンのパズルも歯応えありです。
適当に散歩するだけでも楽しいです。

・徹底して親切なゲームデザイン
→当方の英語力は中学生レベルですがプレイ自体に支障はありませんでした。
段階を追ってアクションを習熟出来るように考えられたチュートリアル、
行き先はSTARTボタンを押せば表示されますし、
街中で受けるクエストも条件を満たせばその場でクリアとなり、報告の必要がないものが多いです。
敵に倒されたり、奈落に落ちてもペナルティは少し前の地点に戻されるくらい、
戦闘が終わればHPは自動的に回復し、大半の敵はこちらから仕掛けなければ戦闘になりません。
逆に連続して敵を倒し続ければボーナスが貰えるようです。
マップでの素材集めやレベリングによる育成要素、アイテム図鑑やモンスター図鑑に用語集、
このゲーム日本人が作ったんじゃね、というくらい親切な設計になっています。

＜悪かった点＞

・相応の英語力が無ければストーリーの把握が困難
→プレイ自体に支障はありませんが、さすがに会話や用語集などは厳しいです。求む！日本語化！

・パズルやアクションで難易度高い要求をされる場面がある
→敵が強い場合はレベリングで何とかなりますが、ダンジョン内でのパズルは
閃きや純粋なアクションスキルを要求される場合があるので厳しい人もいるかと。
攻略サイトもありませんし。
幸いミスしてもペナルティは僅かなのでトライ＆エラーで私は何とかなりました。

・音楽のループ部分がバグる
→おま環でしょうか。音楽のループ部分で二重に鳴ってしまう事がまれにあります。
放っておけば治りますしプレイ自体にも何ら支障はありません。

・果たして完成するのか
→このゲームに限らずアーリーアクセス全般に言える事ですが。
Ver0.7.1時点でもストーリーの中盤に入るかどうか、ぐらいに感じられます。
元々2016年正式リリース予定だったところが現在は2017年予定になっているようです。
風呂敷を広げすぎな部分も散見される上に、非常に手間の掛かる作り方なので
一抹の不安を感じざるを得ません。現状頻繁にアップデートは行われています。
頑張れ！RadicalFishGames！

＜まとめ＞
世の中に溢れているSFC風RPGとは一線を画す存在です。
このゲームからは開発者の溢れんばかりのゲーム愛を感じられます。
最新のRPGのシステムを搭載しそれをドット絵で表現する、個人的にはこれがツボでした。
このゲームを構成する要素に斬新な点は殆どありません。しかし、それぞれを極限まで
完成度を高め上手く組み合わせることにより唯一無二のゲーム体験を実現しています。

まさに「ありそうでなかったゲーム」なのです。

そして個人的には

「こんなゲームを待っていた！！」

24108351.review:
TL;DR

PRO
Plot
Fast Paced Action Combat System, focused on dodging and good aim
Rewarding grinding and farming
Enemy AI will kill you if you spam balls, stand still or try to run away
Metagame (game within the game) atmosphere (take that, Shakespeare)
Good characters , drawings and dialogs
The pixel art is reeeeally good, lots of expression for each character, really well done, and the music still makes me think I'm playing a fantasy MMORPG
Parkour
Mad html5 programming SkillZ m8
Emilienator

CONS
Lack of personalization (everything is plot-bound)
The shop/craft system can be confusing at first (cause the big number of recipes and ingredients)
but you'll eventually understand everything and can keep track of every trader in the trader book
I hate rabbits now

Do you kwnow that feeling when you acquire some games in a bundle and you treat them as "collaterals" because you just want one or two specific games? I'm very glad that CrossCode came to me this way
At start I thought it was the usual rpgmaker 2k jrpg on steam (2 the moon, I'm not talking about you, stop fussing), but that's not the case... the game engine is developed in html5, there are no turn based fights, but evrything is done real time, it's a really fast paced action rpg, but if you're looking for the usual button masher, this is not the right stuff for you: every fight, even against the most harmless looking one, will have to be planned beforehand.

But let's start talking about the plot: I have yet to reach a far point, but the story gets me in a good way; you impersonate a game avatar, Lea, who has lost her memory and she's searcing for it a game universe set on an island in the real world.
The only thing that so far I didn't like is the class of your character, which is bound by the plot for some reason (I have yet to discover it). Lea is a spheromancer, who is able to rapidly cast projectiles while rolling away to safety, or comboing with a quite strong melee attack, a shield and a large number of skills that you acquire by spending cp in your skill tree.
The skill tree is not that difficult you have to choose between some basic passive feats (increased damage, defense, elemental resistance...) and active skill, like a stong projectile that can hit multiple enemies, some dagame reduction buffs, melee attacks... you can quite personalize your fighting style.

Unfortunately, this is the only way of personalization that I found in the game, you can't choose your class, you can form a party choosing between some online friends, but I still only have one, but you can't modify their skill tree or equipment, which is ok, because who can actually look into a friend skill tree or inventory in a MMORPG?

And that's what I thing is one of the major point of CrossCode: the setting.
It really feels like I just start playing a MMORPG again... the game world has everything, it's really well done: the Hub, hunting grounds for beginners, mob respawn, people running around doing things (it's a very populated world) that behave like real players, you can guess which NPC is acting like a real NPC or as a "real player", some players setting shops in the wild and stuff, even the dialogs between other people. I really liked the MMO atmosphere.

I still have to talk about the fitghint system: as said, CrossCode is a fast paced action RPG, you can basically play with a controller or with the mouse+keboard combo. I uses the second one, and I must say that it's really well done, the programming is awersome, I can say that because myself is in a love-hate relationship with html5...
Basically you can do 2 types of attack: a ranged one and a melee combo of 5 hits. As ranged, you can spam an unlimited number of projectiles in a spread that reduces over aiming, or charge a shot that will bounce against walls 3 times and that will set your spread to minimum, while you can hit everything in front you in a not so small radius with the melee attack, stopping your enemies blocking them from attacking you. Everything is done with the left click (click far and you'll cast energy balls, click near your character and you'll perform a melee attack)
With the right click you'll perform dodges while moving and use your shield while standing still. The game is really focused on dodging , because your character is quite frail, but incredibly fast, but you still have to guess the timing correctly, or you can see a large fraction of your hp bar flying away with a single hit.
while performing each of these action and pressing space, you'll perform a special attack (you have to buy and select them in the skill tree) Each skill consumes a sp point, which charges over time (you have a max of 4 sp points: 2 that are charged everythime, while 2 start to charge only in combat and will deplete over time after you finish), so no mp potions for you this time. 
The combat system is really fun, enemies AI is really well done, there's a large number of enemies in different groups, and you'll have to think a different strategy to approach each different mob party, because they are very strong, hit very hard and will try to dodge and pursue you, some of them have shields on their body that will reduce the damage from the front. This makes grinding not so annoying, also because you'll get a "drop rank" that will deplete over time, which is important because it will increase the drop rate (which is very low, 12%-20% at D drop rank) and increase the rarity of drops. Everytime you stop fighting, you drop rank goes back to the lowest level, but this will permit you to regenerate your hp bar. Acquiring an A rank can be quite difficoult, but some drops are only acquired at that level.

Which reminds me of the shop system. You don't actually buy from shops, you instead craft your items by spending drops and money. This makes farming and drop rank essential in your explorations (you won't go past the noob area with the starting equipment). There's a lot of merchants around the map, each one will sell you a few number of items (which can be weapons, consumables or higher tier ingredients), a lot of items have a different recipe for each trader, but you can find everything in the trader book in the menu. So you can have fun going window shopping looking for the cheapest recipe for the same item.

What to say anymore about CrossCode... It's a really fun, rewarding game, quite different from your usual 2D RPG, a really good experience, It says early access, but it doesn't feel that way (I discovered that was early access 5 hours after playing the game, and I was still in the noob area) 

If you don't wanna spend the full price, wait for the sales, I personally found this game in a bundle, and I'm glad I did c:

Such is the polish of this game that, despite being in early access, one could well be forgiven for not realizing that fact right up until reaching the most recently added region and dungeon, or even up until the end of the game. The gameplay is great, the sound is pleasing, the story is engaging, the artistic direction is gorgeous, and even with an issue that dropped my game to playing at 1/2 to 3/4 speed on many larger maps (Don't worry, I haven't seen others encountering it), it was a truly excellent experience.

23842138.review:
Warning: Lengthy Review, the shortest part is literally what this game is constructually below:
This game is a -masterfully- crafted Action RPG with Platform and Puzzle Elements emulating an Action Dungeon Crawl MMORPG.

You play as a girl named Lea and she comes into the start of the story with both amnesia and loss of speech.
As you've entered the game, you start to feel a sense of possible deja vu, as if you've seen this before right?
Well as you progress through this game, you start to see elements and aesthetic choices that remind you of games from different eras- a little bit of phantasy star, some Secret of Mana perhaps and just to drop the bomb- It basically feels like dot hack, yes; as in the anime and multiple simple game series.

The story to this game is a lighthearted and enjoyable tale as far as it's progressed, you run into very bizarre and admittedly infantile characters as you realize that you're in an MMORPG- Sorry, MMOG game with what seems like dated online gamers in a cartoonishly futuristic setting and game in a game. This game knows its flaws and runs with them wildly into something that becomes charming and "fantasique".

The actual dialogue to this game for the most part is pretty stereotypical in that of RPG to the point that it feels as if it's all set to be a satire of the subject(s) being observed and I for one am enjoying that.

Regardless of these matters, this world respects me and I respect it as I wander through this large world to explore and be mesmerized by it's visual bounty. Huge mountain tops and sky islands a plenty and the very NPC characters are as lost and befuddled as you are as you try to comprehend and understand what exactly you've delved into.

I don't wish to spoil anything major, so I'll give you what at least the demo will tell you if you choose to download it.

The summarization of the plot as far as I know goes along the lines of this: You are a special character in this world, but your memories have become lost with an unexplained reasoning and those memories may hold the very answers to why a particular "blue individual" has appeared and you're left asking the questions: "Who am I? Who was I just before this all started? Finally, just how much of an adventure am I in for?".

The story aside, the next best thing has to be controls and combat.
You can play this game with Controller or Keyboard with absolute ease; you use both ranged and melee combat to carve your path in this world. This game also features a level tree system similar to that of Path of Exile where everything branches out in segments and sections- but this game takes it a step further with a feature not yet included in the game, which you learn about just a step after the demo, thus I will not spoil it for you. It also a fantastic fusion of barter and traditional economic systems in order to gear yourself out- Oh, I forgot to mention that you do get to equip your character out in a lot of different kinds of equipment to properly suit your style of play for your character. The trading system works super well in both complimenting its eastern inspired grind fest as it usually requires items from creatures or environmental drops in order to properly progress your character by your own accord and you'll definitely need to do so based on your own skill level with this game's enemies; which in my opinion have a really strong difficulty curve that you can ease into, but definitely will take a proper length amount of time to master.

You really get that feeling that you're playing a form of RPG as the game incorporates a lot of staple pseudo RPG systems that you find across anything that melds the two worlds into one, such as dot hack did with examples including the "Direct Link system" (aka the Member Address system in dot hack) for getting in contact with friends in certain times of the game (which at least implies there may be times where characters you meet up into with can be unavailable for helping you throughout the game's main story plot.) as well as being able to message them.

Of course there's also with this patch that I'm writing this review on that they added what's called the "Trader Book", which allows you to keep track of any trader you've met in the game in a listed catalogue, then it even tells you about what items they trade you for AND what materials it takes to trade for their items respectively, very progressive of a system as well as a progression oriented design- Kudos to the developers on simple things like this.

So with the combat, story and controls explained; I guess I should delve into the graphical aesthetics opinion portion of this lengthy review.

I truly think the graphics of the game look really nice, they're a great homage to a time of games that took finesse and diligence to craft properly and this team has it down to the a T. They understand in order to appreciate this art form that you need to make the entire view and scope of it all to be as filling and substantial as possible, but without it trying to make everything look TOO busy. The color palettes they use are nicely contrasting and bright to convey the form of world that they've created and their aesthetic is just appealing enough to where anyone can enjoy it- as if of that to watching cartoon characters on TV, considering how expressive they are.

The bosses and character animations are easily a technical design delight as they're very fluent and easy on the eyes.
The sprites are simple, yet elegant to behold for the first time every time as you don't quite know what you'll encounter as you progress onward. The few bosses I've encountered thus far as been pretty nice to look at- first example being the crab boss encounter on the cargo ship in the earliest part of the game. That crab boss set a really decent bar of what to expect in the graphics department as well as the animation as they deployed a lot of well practiced techniques in their contrasts, dithering and light source ability in unison with decently fluid animation to give it a proper sense of Life to what they constructed.

To keep things flowing and going, I do want to say one thing about level designs.
They do a pretty good job so far in puzzle work and level layouts- though I haven't explored enough of the game to realistically comment on how well they actually HAVE done since I've barely gone past Bergen (Post Demo Area).

*EDIT*: After playing through to the posted end of the current content in 0.7.1, I will gladly say that the dungeon designs are rather decent thus far. The first dungeon experience I was given to quest through was a very satisfying and interesting bar to set for the difficulty of future dungeons. I found myself trying my best to find creative solutions throughout the layouts and puzzles given, meanwhile I was at least interested to look for all the treasure- yet It did not make me feel compelled to find ALL of it immediately, so I would be able to come back at a later time to search and scavenge. One thing that needs to be said is that the boss fights scale up in difficulty pretty well and feel rewarding for getting through the puzzles and then finally defeating the boss of the realm before you. They are definitely doing everything right with this so far and hopefully get to see how bright the future will be in this regard as patches and content installments continue to come.

Easily so far- this game has a SOLID 9 to 9.5 out of 10 due to the game being incomplete, but what they've shown so far is easily worth commending admiration and attention to a great cause. This game is a near immaculate example of what an Early Access game should be and to strive for being. Radical Fish Games has easily opened my eyes a little more on what passionate projects are becoming to be and warming my cold jaded heart.

23776138.review:
Version 0.7 at time of review.

[u][b]Pros:[/b][/u]

[b]The dungeons.[/b] The puzzles are some of the most creative and fun I've experienced, with fresh mechanics, intelligent solutions and no hand-holding.

[b]The music.[/b] In truth, not all the tracks are amazing, but even those that aren't are still quite good. The sound design is also above average.

[b]The characters.[/b] Very likeable characters with lots of depth and personality. The interactions between characters feel very natural and not forced in any way. Fantastic humor as well.

[b]The bosses.[/b] I don't want to spoil anything, but you won't find any cheap tricks or quick time events here. Just fast bosses that take skill and strategy to defeat.

[b]The story.[/b] In its current form CrossCode has a suprisingly gripping story, with the potential to become something very special if they flesh it out. It truly feels like the first three chapters of an epic novel. My one worry is that, as we are already at version 0.7, the story will end up compressed and truncated.

[b]The UI/Controls.[/b] It looks great, it's very fast and well thought out and it doesn't get in the way. I play using an Xbox 360 pad and I have no complaints about the controls.


[u][b]Cons:[/b][/u]

[b]Grinding.[/b] This may not be a negative for many, but I feel the level grinding gets in the way of an otherwise well-paced game. This may be negated in the final version with greater enemy variety and more interesting quests which make leveling more interesting.

[b]Platforming.[/b] Many of the map areas have multiple elevations which are difficult to discern, meaning you will plunge into the water or fall to a lower elevation without meaning to. You will then have to backtrack, which in some cases takes a few minutes. Very frustrating and deters from exploration.


Overall a fantastic game that I will be watching very closely. If the devs give it the expansive story and scale it deserves, I am confident it will be among the best 2D RPGs around.
