23494094.review:
This is a diamond in the ruff indie game with developers who are upfront, honest, and very active. You can easily tell this game is a passionate labor of love for them. With news updates and new game content being added regularly. They even live stream often as they are updating, so you can see the game being enhanced in real time. If so you so desire. 

The game itself plays like Zelda: Link to the Past or a Ys game, but with a little more in the melee combos/combat dodging department and a higher focus on physics base range combat. You can aim and ricochet shots to hit attack openings. This feature also is used a lot in the game's puzzles.

The story kind of has a metagame within a game vibe going for it. Basically, you play a character that is playing a simulated MMO. But of course their very special within the game world their playing. The game even has simulated teams mates that banter, etc. Similar to the .Dot Hack and/or loosely Sword Art Online series of games.

Overall the game has phenomenal 2D physics, inventive fast based melee combo combat with range puzzle elements. It also runs very smoothly on about any remotely current PC or laptop. It is really worth a try for anyone who likes the top down 2D RPG hack and slashes of the 90s. For full disclosure, I originally got this game in a bundle a few years ago on the cheap. When it first went into early access. But I have played many times throughout its development and still really enjoy it. So, I would have been willing pay full price without issue.

23487975.review: phantasy star online on crack. nice music tho really fits the game

23454742.review:
CrossCode is a fantastic game. It reminds me of Golden Sun, one of my favorite games of all time. The graphics are simple but smooth. The story is engaging, and I enjoy a lot of the humour in the game. The soundtrack is very good, although like many RPGs, entire areas have one soundtrack that just loops, and some are better than others for listening to for a couple hours on end, but it can't really be helped.

The combat is good- and a big part of that is how you get punished for dying. You effectively don't- you get reloaded to your last save, which is the autosave that happened when you walked into that room. I think that's important, because the game is very skill based when it comes to more difficult fights. If you don't know the mechanics of a boss or a new room/enemy, you can get punished hard and quickly. And that's good that the game can challenge you like this and be fast paced in its combat, because it fits the style of it.

While it's difficult to judge, I think the puzzles overall are good. There are a lot of puzzles in the game- even just small ones like "How do I get a floor higher in this area so I can get the chest?", not just dungeon puzzles that encompass a whole room. It's difficult to judge because there were puzzles that I got stuck on when the solution, obviously, was right there on the screen. So I want to say the game has bad or frustrating or difficult to figure out puzzles, but at the same time, I have to weigh the fact that I'm an imperfect human. Of course there would be puzzles I would get stuck on! Some people found those puzzles easy, and other puzzles I figured out my first time stumped others. So I think overall it was mostly me not applying good problem solving techniques. The majority were enjoyable, or just challenging enough to where even if it took 5 minutes instead of 30 seconds like I might expect, it felt good to beat it, not frustrating to spend so much time on it.

Pro tip- always work backwards for puzzles.
Always.

The game is unique in a couple of ways. As of the most recent version, a lot of enemies in the game (I think all but two) are non-aggressive. So when you walk into an area with enemies, the health bars will be blue, and you can run right past them, or into them, and it doesn't matter. If you attack an enemy, you get it's "group" to attack you. In other words, an area's enemies are not all going to attack you if you attack one enemy. Enemies do respawn, but not instantly, and not when you leave and enter a new area. I believe it's time based. This is important for another way the game is unique- it's not just a combat driven or story driven RPG. Like mentioned when I wrote about the puzzles, the game has many, and many small ones outside of dungeons, for example. Not constantly getting attacked when switching between two areas trying to figure out a solution, or just having the enemies in the one area the puzzle is in respawn quickly and attack you is important to the game, because almost all areas in the game of some form of puzzle/parkour element to it. Again, it reminds me of Golden Sun.

The characters have a lot of character. They'll speak when they don't need to or it's not pertinent to the story, because in in the game world, they're regular human beings of course, not just cogs in the machine that is the protagonist's storyline. That's really cool. I feel like the writing is very good overall and mimics what a person might actually say relatively often. The story so far is good because of the characters. The story is interesting because of the characters. When you've watched hundreds of movies, play hundreds of games, or what have you, you realize that pretty much everything has been done when you generalize plots. What are most RPGs? Go find something that's long lost, go save a person you care about or a country or town or whatever, go stop the bad guy trying to awaken an evil power, etc. CrossCode is unique in that in CrossCode, you play a character who is playing a game called CrossWorlds, along with everyone else you meet, is in the CrossWorlds universe. That's new to me. What saves the parts of the story that is pretty generic- go grab the ancient thing no one has been able to before, is that the writing is good, the characters and expressions are good, the names for things and puzzles and actual gameplay is good. It makes the plot an acutal thing to enjoy and get invested in, instead of having it be this out of context, "Oh, it's another game where you go grab the ancient power. That's new..." story.

While currently short in story, (2-3 hours for me on my first playthrough to get through it), it did take me a healthy 17ish hours to get through the gameplay that there is so far. And for that matter, that's without story adding time to it. I've played games for less than 17 hours and thought they were good, so even though it's not finished, I'd still recommend it, it's still a great game, and the Developers are pretty interactive with the community and update about every 2-3 months- but the updates are big, for example, the last update brought about 6-8 hours of gameplay into the game, because it was the entire second dungeon and the surrounding area. One last note- there are two dungeons currently in the game, and there will probably only be 4-5. There are 4 elements you need to obtain in the game, and right now both dungeons contained one, so the game might be about halfway over gameplay wise. Although I wouldn't imagine you would just get the 4th element in the 4th dungeon and have the game end very quickly after that (which is why I said 4-5 dungeons), the game would still be about 35 hours with only 2-3 hours of story and the gameplay finished if it DOES end pretty much right after the 4th dungeon. And for that matter, if the 3rd and 4th dungeons and areas of the are about as long as the first two. Given the story will be carried throughout the whole game, I expect the game to be about 50 hours, but that's a total guess. Either way, 35 hours is pretty much the minimum, which is definitely worth the $15.99 I paid for it, and would have gladly paid $20.00 for it too. Also, keep in mind that that would be if you played through it once. I've played through it twice for a different build as it is an RPG with a skill/talent tree!

Okay, imagine the following scenario. A man you don't know at all (me) is sitting at his computer, playing CrossCode. Because it's $20.00 (though I got it for $15.99), and I've played it for 30 hours, that's about 66 cents an hour. When I played this game, I played it for about 5 hours straight through dinner and didn't even realize- that's how engulfed I was in the game. If I never played this game again, then I would have paid that 66 cents/hour for the game relative to how much entertainment time I got out of it. So imagine now that a man who isn't even aware he's played CrossCode for an hour is approached by another person. This person comes to the man at his computer and says, "You owe me 66 cents for the last hour you played."

23446912.review:
I bought this game because it seemed to have a vaguely "PSO" feel despite being a top down action RPG.

The most important detail of this game is that no matter what you are doing in it, you don't feel bored and even legwork doesn't feel like "a chore".  It is consistently engaging at all times.

I have enjoyed the gameplay, dungeons, and puzzles more thoroughly than any classic "Zelda" type game, which I would consider this products closest relative.

The gameplay is a mix of Ragnarok Online, Platforming, and Zelda.  There is amazing depth to the abilities and their use, and fights are engaging because of specific ways to handle each enemy.  You gain the ability to "swap" to entirely different skill trees in real time, affecting the element of your attacks and current stats.  You essentially create your own classes around these features.

The puzzles are very logical and do not have "vague solutions", bringing consistent entertainment to someone who likes to stop and think.

Highly reccomend, best single player game I've played in about a year.

23389022.review:
Achei a "Radical Fish Games" explorando a internet, e felizmente me deparei com um dos melhores jogos que eu já joguei! Sou desenvolvedor de Games Indies, e de vez em quando procuro referências para estudar. Pesquiso desde jogos clássicos até os que ainda estão em desenvolvimento (como este aqui). E toda vez que vou conversar com algum outro colega game designer eu apresento o "CrossCode".
Bom, agora o porque ele é tão bom assim?
Conseguiram explorar de forma criativa os recursos de um Pixel Art, RPG, Top Down, Hack n Slash, entre outros!
- Jogabilidade:
O game apresenta muitas características do game "The Legend of Zelda´s series", como o sistema de pulos, que quando você chega ao fim de uma plataforma que está em cima, por exemplo, o personagem pula automaticamente. Ou seja, você em si não pode controlar quando quer pular ou não, porém pode ter certeza que toda vez que chega ao fim de algum terreno, o mesmo automaticamente saltara. Outra característica semelhante aos de Zelda, é o sistema de exploração, você pode ir e vir para qualquer lugar do cenário quando quiser, deixando assim a linearidade costumeira dos jogos hoje em dia de lado.
Os sistemas de batalha são bem intuitivos, tanto pelo teclado/mouse quanto pelo controle, as lutas são bem dinâmicas, utilizando ao máximo dos recursos Hack n Slash para efetuar batalhas frenéticas. 
Também possui um sistema de quest´s secundarias, que deixam você sair um pouco da história principal e explorar um pouco mais do mundo e ganhar mais itens e leveis.
O jogo foi desenvolvido utilizando com recurso a engine Impact, que te dá liberdade para desenvolver games para HTML5, PC´s, Consoles entre outros. Que também atribui tanto pela jogabilidade do game quando atribuir novos recursos que transformam um game de pixel art em algo mais atual, sabendo equilibrar bem entre os recursos.
- Arte:
É tudo muito bem desenhado, eles exploram conceitos de pixel art ao máximo. Os personagens são muito bem desenvolvidos, e eles conseguem atribuir características especificas a cada um.
- Enredo:
A história do game é bem interessante, e vou ter que me segurar aqui com os Spoilers!
O enredo principal do game gira em volta do mistério da origem de "Lea", que é a protagonista do game, ela não tem memorias de sua origem que ao que tudo indica, é algo relacionado a outro personagem misterioso que você controla no “prelúdio” do game.
O mundo é uma espécie de MMO, mas o ambiente do game não é virtual, e sim uma espécie de região administrada para que os avatares do game possam explorar no “mundo real”, pode ser um pouco confuso falando por aqui, mas no jogo ficou muito bem construído.

- Música:
Todas as músicas foram criadas pela equipe, e que ficaram muito boas, realmente quando você começa a jogar e escuta a música do menu inicial, você sabe que está realmente entrando no mundo de “CrossCode”.
eles sabem fazer o bom uso dos SFX.

- Outros pontos a serem destacados:
A equipe pesquisou muito bem antes de fazer esse game, pode-se perceber vários elementos positivos do mundo dos games que eles souberam aproveitar;
Eles utilizam bem a estratégia do protagonista mudo para que o jogador possa se projetar dentro do personagem (Como Chrono Trigger, Zelda, Etc...), porém, mesmo com este recurso, eles conseguem dar uma driblada e dar certos pontos de conversas com a personagem que ela tenta responder com pouco recursos, acrescentando assim personalidade a mesma e uma dose sutil de humor bem colocado;
Eles sempre estão atualizando o game, e fazem questão de compartilhar isso com o jogador! Logo no menu inicial, você pode ver as últimas alterações que eles fizeram, e dá pra perceber que eles escutam e muito os jogadores, principalmente para alerta de bugs e etc... pois muitas das mudanças são feitas por sugestões.

Enfim, estou adorando poder ver o rumo que “CrossCode” está tomando, esse é um jogo que vai entrar pros clássicos de Indie Games, nota 10/10!!!

23205146.review:
- Gorgeous, deep pixel art.
- The dialogue and story are great, unlike many indie games which have unbearable dialogue
- Fresh mix of action / RPG elements.
- Fun level design that encourages exploration
- Exciting combat that does not get stale or boring. 
- Soundtrack is reminiscent of many classic RPGs, but with a modern sound. Very very good sountrack and sound design
- Elements combine to make you feel like you are really playing inside the CrossWorlds MMO playground!

One of the most fully-featured, fun, and worthwhile "early access" titles I have ever purchased. 
With an extension of the circuit "skill" upgrade tree and more movesets this game could very well be an instant classic. I do not think I have ever been so impressed with an early access title. They are often underdeveloped, with no clear direction. This game feels like a solid, complete idea. The only things that are missing are elements of the idea. The games theme, direction, and design are tied together in a unified and beautifully done product. The developers have truly created something that is a great addition to the RPG genre, it is incredibly unique and refreshing. It scratches every itch we RPG players have- except for maybe some sort of crafting system, but honestly the game doesn't NEED anything. It could be a nice addition though. I am so very excited to see what direction they take from here, and look forward to any future titles done by Radical Fish.

Grade:

Audio           -            9.5/10
Graphics      -             10/10
Gameplay/Physics -  10/10 (indeed" buttery smooth" as described!)
Mechanics/RPG     -  9.5/10
Controls         -          10/10
Completion  -            10/10  (one of the most complete early access titles ever, aside from the storyline)

23045696.review:
Crosscode is a game that I decided not to back initially, because I thought the project had unrealistic goals.  Upon revisiting it in the demo and pre-purchasing, I think I can safely say that I was not only wrong, but that is the only project I even remotely regret not backing.  This is what I think an indie game should aspire to be: a passion project that has standout and unexpected production quality.

Describing Cross Code is difficult, because almost no one has played any of the games it most resembles.  Alundra, Terranigma, Secret of Mana, Shining Soul, Robotron, Gunman Clive... probably the closest well-known parallel is Zelda, and this ain't no Zelda.  In short, it's a top-down fast-paced action game with SNES era style graphics, "phantasy star" sort of character design, large puzzle sections and some quality of life improvements from modern games.  I'd say the closest new game in function is Hyper Light Drifter (which is quite similar), although the two games greatly differ in tone with Crosscode being much much lighter and transparent about its premise, but much less stylish and ambitious in that regard.

I don't want to just gush about this, so here's what's bad:  Flavor-wise the story and setting are busy and inane: People are playing an MMO as hard-light beings on a real-life alien planet, and you're injected into things as an outsider with likely special capabilities as well as amnesia and limited speech capabilities.  Some people are obstensibly people in the cities, so it's impossible to figure out what are questgiving ai characters and inhabitants of the cities which is fairly irresponsible given the MMO players are basically operating killing machines.  It's dumb, but it lets the game be a game and do whatever it really wants to.  In line with this, some of the characters are kind of annoying as well, in particular anyone who can't help but mix in words from other languages in nearly every single line of dialogue.

In addition, puzzle-and-action hybrids often have a lot of issues regarding their audience.  Although I for one love the mix, you force action lovers to do puzzles in order to play more of what they like and vice versa, and the game is linear.  In particular, the dungeons are very very puzzle heavy almost to the point of exhaustion, and the rest of the game is somewhat light on them (although the mix is worked in much better as of the latest overworld area).

Somewhere between bad and good is the music.  Most of the tracks are forgettable and a few are very unappealing short-loop midi-quality stuff.  On the other hand, the newest town theme and especially the boss theme are fantastic.  When you fight a tough opponent you will find no fault in the music for getting you psyched, and that's really what I'm looking for in this type of game.

Speaking of bosses, let's get into the good stuff.  The bosses themselves are pure pixel porn and must have been ages to animate given their size, and they are a joy to fight with their gimmicks and weaknesses- and ability to sometimes cover up their weakness or turn your exploitation of it back at you.  In particular, the duel against a foe of similar abilities is a blast because his AI is shockingly adept for this kind of game.  In addition, certain special encounters against regular enemies are made much more interesting with strange arenas or mixes of opponents.  Healing is tricky due to a delay but very helpful in some particularly deadly fights.  It's obvious that in most cases, these guys know encounter design inside and out.

Part of what makes bosses so fun to fight are the controls.  I cringed when I saw that the bumpers were going to be the main attack and dodge buttons, and that the right stick was used to aim shots, but actually it works very well on a 360 controller.  The bumpers depress pretty quick, allowing you to really tear into stuff- but it is tiring over a long play session.  Everything is fluid, from dodging to attacks to blocking to using special moves.  I didn't suffer any slowdown at all compared to Hyper Light Drifter, not that my computer is top of the line.  Pretty exceptional, really.

On the subject of slowdown, in the overworld areas it's pretty amazing just how much stuff is going on.  Despite the goofy setting, the illusions they use to convey a living world (mainly resting avatars and huge number of "travelling" players) are really good without interfering at all.  The towns feel populated, which is rare, and the trading mechanic supplements the cash shops really nicely in my opinion.  You can also jump all over the place, even if it's always going to be tricky figuring out elevation in a 2D game.  Still, you can jump on just about everything in a very golden-sun style of conspicuous parkour in order to find out-of-reach treasures, and for me that was just a joy.

Almost exclusively the puzzles are excellent.  They are unfortunately linear, but make up for it by teaching you constantly.  Each dungeon so far has two gimmicks that each engage differently with most or all of your abilities you'll have up to that point, and serve a purpose in fights.   Many puzzle rooms also contain additional goodies for going the extra mile as well.  A few of them, however, require fairly precise timing or aim (or both) and I can see some players getting stuck.

In short, I think this is a standout title and am greatly looking forward to its release- and would encourage anyone not disinterested due to the style or other negatives to do the same.

23021040.review:
One of the greatest action-RPGs I've ever played.

[list]
[*]Graphics: 10/10, gorgeous pixel art and colourful world.
[*]Music: 10/10, really solid chiptunes and instrumental tracks.
[*]Gameplay: 10/10, moving the character around and battling creeps is super satisfying and smooth. Really smart use of mechanics for puzzles as well. FFX-esque skill tree and hundreds of different pieces of equipment. Oh, and platforming. Lots of platforming <3
[*]Story/Plot: 10/10, futuristic setting with the trending "MMORPG simulation" anime archetype really well done. The characters are depicted exquisitely, with lots of charisma.
[*]Duration: 10/10, over 20h required to 100% all of the current content at the time of writing this review (which is like HALF of what the whole game is gonna have once it's finished).
[/list]

Overall: 10/10, you should definitely buy it or at least add it to your wishlist and get it once it's finished. Can't wait for more content updates!

23019319.review: Very fun, neat world and concept, and good characters.

23017665.review:
[h1]Basically? Yeah- totally worth the buy even in it's current state. This "JRPG"'s progress is glorious.[/h1]

Unlike most Early Access games on Steam, this project is full of amazing gameplay mechanics and beautiful pixel art- all of which can be followed on their regular Twitch Dev livestream. This genuinely is one of the best "retro" games on Steam. If you enjoyed old 2D games action/RPGs like Secret of Mana and the like, then you'd get a kick out of CrossCode.

[h1]With a little more detail?[/h1]
[b]Graphics[/b]
Brilliantly done pixel art animations that display the world and battles with great detail. Somewhere between classic SNES era sprites and modern "retro" popular releases. And with new content arriving semi-frequently, they often go over old art and revamp them with even higher quality- also giving a reason to go back through the game to appreciate its assets.
[b]Controls[/b]
Moves like that of an SNES era action RPG, but more fluent with it's Controller Support, dodge/dash system and 8-way run freedom. Basically how you'd expect a 2D overhead Kingdom Hearts to perform.
[b]Audio[/b]
What you'd expect of a fantasy sci-fi "retro" game, well performed music again like those of the SNES and Genesis era. The music fits each scenario well, and again like Kingdom Hearts, flows nicely in-and-out of Exploration and Battle to continuously give an action packed experience all 'round.
[b]Content[/b]
Continuously added content since the game is still in development but with plenty of material to enjoy already, from free-exploration secrets treasures and powerups hidden throughout the world, challenging quests from NPCs, and very well designed Dungeons that offer a great challenge for both battle and puzzle lovers- the kind that you'd expect in the great 2D Zelda releases.


With tons of content being added regularly, buying this game to support the progress of the immediately gripping sci-fi fantasy world story is one of the best things you can do- and you won't regret it.

22862380.review: This game caught me off guard. What at first glance may look like standard RPG Maker fare is actually something quite different, and very refreshing. [i]CrossCode[/i] is probably best described as a mix of SEGA's classic [i]Phantasy Star[/i] series of RPGs - including its groundbreaking MMO spinoff [i]Phantasy Star Online[/i] (which very obviously informed [i]CrossCode[/i]'s scenario and design) - as well as HAL Laboratories' somewhat obscure Super Famicom hack 'n' slash title [i]Alcahest[/i], to which [i]CrossCode[/i] bears likeness in its fast-paced combat and movement system. The look and feel is quite authentically that of an early 32-bit era game, still resorting to tile-based 2D graphics, but taking advantage of the "new hardware" for large sprites, zoom and lighting effects, and other shenanigans. All of that, combined with a so far very solid narrative and set of characters, makes for a game that is most definitely worth keeping an eye on. The price tag may be a bit steep for some, but it can be found on sale and in bundles quite regularly, and there's also a free demo available, so there's little reason to not at least give it a try.

22455901.review:
素晴らしいゲームです。
難点を言うならば、序盤のチュートリアルが長めで、まだストーリーの実装が序盤までしかないというところくらいでしょうか。

ゼルダライクな謎解き中心のアクションゲームに見えますが、どちらかというとアクション要素のほうが強いです。
敵を倒すことによって得た経験値によるLVアップとポイント振り分けによってスキルを取得するスフィア板のような成長要素があります。
LVアップやアイテム収集などでフィールド上の敵と戦う機会が多いゲームですが、ザコとして登場する敵達にも細かく弱点や隙が設定されており、単純にフィールドで戦闘をしているだけでも非常に楽しいです。

また、ゲーム内に見える段差などはほぼ全て飛び降りることが出来るようになっていて、移動自体が非常に爽快です。到達が困難な場所にNPCやチェストが配置されていたりもするため、その場所に行くにはどうすればいいのだろうか、と考えさせられるなど、フィールドや街全体がパズルのようになっているのも楽しい。

僕は英語あまりわからないのですが、そんなこと関係ないです！　このゲームは面白い！
なにより美麗なドット絵、音楽、軽快なプレイ感覚など相まって一度ハマったら抜け出せない！
早く次のアップデート、次のダンジョンきてくれ！

2017年正式リリース予定らしいですが、それまで待つなんて勿体無いです。今すぐ遊ぶべきではないかと思います。

22153475.review:
Cross Code, while early in developement, is no doubt promising in all aspects. 

The controls are fluid, making travel fairly quick and enabling fast-paced, challenging combat. 
Special abilities that can be "Switched" out of combat allows you to decide what way is best to take on a group of enemies, before you attack them.
Elements (and shields/guards) allow for unique weaknesses in most enemies to be discovered, both in common enemies and in bosses. 
The storyline (so far) is gripping and will leave you with question after question.
Stats, level, and equipment will only take you so far. Personal skill will be the deciding factor for higher level enemies, large groups of enemies, and bosses. 
The artwork is absolutely fantastic. ABSOLUTELY. FANTASTIC.
Combat made fun by unique arsenal of powers where you develope your own style.
Combat made fun by smooth controls and fast-paced action. 
Platforming is a large part of exploration and treasurehunting where a fall doesn't lead to a loading screen, but instead an instant nearby respawn.
Puzzles are unique and involved as they play on the game's combat and elements for different affects in some cases. 
I cannot stress how much I like the combat in this game. 

Seriously, buy it.

It's a great game, and some of the most fun I've ever had for 20 bucks. I'd happily pay more for it.
Even though it is early access, and it is lacking in story, and it is lacking in areas to explore, it's well worth your money and the wait. 

Just play the damn game.

21854037.review:
[i](Edited for my final impression on my early review of the game!)[/i]

CrossCode is a fast-paced 2D retro RPG game where you start playing as a 'jack of all trades' character in a MMORPG world and your main objective is to master all 4 elements and solve the mysteries. So, how well does the game runs in terms of its presentation, gameplay, story?

[u]Pros:[/u]
+Vivid and beautiful graphics with smooth 60 FPS animation
+Soothing and exhilarating soundtrack and perfectly syncronised audio
+Simple and easy-to-learn combat mechanics with many combos that can be freely executed
+Variety of puzzles you can solve that is not too challenging but not too easy as well
+Very well designed world environment that allows to traverse around easily
+Nicely written and interesting plot with a mix of futuristic sci-fi and dungeon crawler fantasy

Okay that's quite a lot of good sides there but what about the bad sides? Well, to be honest, I don't find any problem during gameplay and I actually enjoy it despite being early access but there are very few that I want to point out.

[u]Cons:[/u]
-Some battles can be frustrating at first and the first challenge starts very early
-You need a lot of info on the environment around you and it takes time in order to get from one point to a desired point
-Might experience lag in some points
-Game contents are still small right now

The game is written in HTML 5 instead of C++ or Python but it runs as .exe so I can't tell whether the game runs natively or still relies a lot on a default web browser.

So, is the game finally worth it to buy and play at this point? This game has many potentials here at its beta stage, but unless you're willing to support the developers, I'd say you have to wait until the game is finish developed, polished and ready to be publish as a full game.

21830115.review:
《CrossCode》是一款結合角色扮演以及平台解謎玩法的 2D 平面動作冒險遊戲，整體來說玩法就是融入《Legend of Zelda 薩爾達傳說》探索要素和《Ys 伊蘇》動作成份的作品。故事劇情講述科學技術發展日新月異的人類創造出一款與現實社會共存的 MMOG （Massive Multiplayer Online Games），本作分為現實世界與遊戲世界兩大空間，現實世界就跟字面意思一樣，是人們生存的空間且有生老病死的概念存在，遊戲世界則是註冊玩家可以透過傳送虛擬身份 Avatar 進入的第二世界，如果用現今已存在的網遊題材作品來比喻《CrossCode》作品內的遊戲世界，那絕對不會是裝戴虛擬實境裝置的《Sword Art Online 刀劍神域》，而是將玩家本身傳送到跟現實世界無異的大陸闖關冒險的《Greed Island》。

既然談到本作擁有許多網路遊戲要素存在，那就不能不提到《CrossCode》世界觀獨特的遊戲規則，同樣擁有許多職業，同樣需要透過打怪與過任務升級角色能力，與其他作品最大差別在於比起讓玩家無腦農怪升級，製作團隊更希望大家專心解謎，所以遊戲中會有不少解謎關卡，就連脫離新手訓練最後試煉都要玩家在類似《Portal 傳送門》的純白實驗室中解謎，需要動腦思考才能解開機關但是不至於會難到無法通關。看到這裡大家應該會很興奮吧？一款使用 16-bit SNES-style （十六位元超級任天堂風格）製作而成的網路遊戲，有任何不入手遊玩的理由存在嗎？有鑒於近幾年廣泛流行的 Hype 文化，筆者必須跟大家說出事實，事實就是《CrossCode》並不是網路遊戲，僅是採用網路遊戲題材的單機遊戲。


女主人翁 Lea 主要職業是被喻為最弱職業的 Spheromancer （事實上擁有客製化天賦樹，後期可能成為玩法最豐富職業一角），此職業戰鬥方法分為近戰和遠程兩種模式，近戰模式主要攻擊手段是揮舞雙刀劃出圓弧砍殺敵人，遠程模式細分為普通射擊、瞄準射擊、以及蓄力射擊等三種攻擊，其中蓄力射擊的反射特效是順利通過解謎關卡的關鍵。由於遊戲機制不鼓勵玩家衝向敵人就是一陣無腦亂砍，不管是小怪或是頭目都會有極高攻擊力，還擁有免疫硬直和減少傷害的霸體特效，抓準時機閃躲攻擊才能順利過關斬將。


製作團隊在環境細節方面處理得十分細心，玩家會隨著劇情面識新夥伴，剛進入新手村時就會碰到一名同樣是新手的法國少女 Shizuka ，他的同行友人已經是所謂高端玩家，簡單向兩人介紹哪裡可以購買裝備與接取任務後，玩家就能邀請 Shizuka 一同組隊打怪（Shizuka 還會跟 Lea 抱怨說一直重複打同種怪物有點無趣）。除此之外還能在城鎮廣場、中央市集、野怪區等地方看到四處林立的露天商店，虛擬玩家也會帶著夥伴來回奔波，雖然知道他們只是 NPC 不過還是讓筆者回想起十五年前台灣網路遊戲剛興起的那段黃金歲月。


本作目前仍處 Early Access Alpha 早期測試階段，兩小時就能跑完故事劇情，儘管主線劇情還未完成，玩家還是可以在當前版本接取支線任務，提升角色等級探索高等區域地圖，如果要過完所有支線任務，保守估計要花費十小時左右的遊玩時數。關於何時會完成遊戲推出正式版，官方說法是將在二零一七年春季完成這部作品，同時最近一次更新日期是三月七號，不僅展示全新地圖還預告將釋出元素武器要素，總而言之《CrossCode》是部非常值得讓人期待和等待的獨立遊戲，如果想支援製作團隊就趕緊購買本作吧！


優點：
+十六位元復古畫面風格，讓骨灰玩家找回初玩超級任天堂的感動。
+戰鬥時動感十足且操縱手感極佳，不輸其他知名動作角色扮演遊戲。
+採用網路遊戲題材，打怪練等、學習技能、接取任務等玩法應有盡有。


缺點：
-目前遊戲仍未完成可玩內容不多，除此之外遊戲性方面沒太多問題。


結論：想支持製作團隊就不用吝嗇直接購買本作，這款遊戲值得你我等待。


網誌圖文好讀版：
http://mgrim214.blogspot.tw/2016/03/crosscode.html

21381628.review:
Oh boy, Crosscode, where to begin? :) This is a great game that i bought during a sale (25% off) and i don't regret a thing!
If anything, I'm just waiting, nay, drooling for more content. 
Well, with that out of the way, what can you expect from Crosscode?
First off, the Music. Ahh. Nice. The music is Beautiful, and reminds me of Snes classics like Chrono Trigger,
Secret of Mana, Secret of Evermore and Illusion of Gaia, and just a bit of Megaman and Xenogears as well :)
As far as gameplay goes, I got used to the controls in almost no time. The controls were smooth and fluid, which is something I like in games like this.
As a side note: I use the keyboard and mouse, but aside from any technical issue, I think you would find it easy to use a controller. Also, an FYI, to use Melee attacks, keep the target cursor near Lea when attacking
(This is for the keyboard and mouse)
Now, The Story. So far, There isn't much yet, as you might notice from other reviews, but, what there is of the story
is really interesting so far. At the moment, the story goes as far as the beginning of bergen trail, and a fight with 
another character. after the fight, it wraps up, and you can either do quests or explore all the areas available right now.
The graphics are as advertised, and again, remind me of the snes era games. Nice.
Finally, the Big Question. Is it worth the price? Short anwser is: Maybe. As i mentioned before, i Don't regret buying this game one bit. i'm glad I decided to buy it. but some things work in my favor. 
1- I got it on sale, that's always nice(15 bucks instead of 20)
2- I grew up playing these kinds of games. This might seem strange to put in, but there is something to be said for nostalgia when it comes to games. on the other hand, if you never played a snes before, this might your future nostalgia ;)
3- I love the music. No Really. I Love it. When it comes out as a soundtrack, or perhaps on bandcamp(you can check it out on soundcloud right now) i will definitely be buying it.
4- That story. Grahh. Want Moar!
Anyway, the long and short of it is, If Crosscode were complete right now, it would be more then worth that 20$ price
Right now, it might be a little hard to say(since i'm stingy) but honesty, I don't think you'll regret it. 
At least until you need an update for the story. XD

21213326.review:
A truly amazing hidden gem. I'm amazed that I didn't find out about this game last year, I absolutely love it! If you are interested in this game, I highly recommend playing the demo first. I thought of buying it based solely on the reviews. trailers and screenshots, but experiencing the demo is what sold it for me.

   The graphics are in a wonderfully done 16-bit style that reminds me a lot of SNES RPGs like Breath of FIre II and Final Fantasy III/VI, and it honestly feels like true pixel art. Nothing ever moved or rotated such that the pixels rotated as well, which is what can hurt games in this style, in my opinion. 

   The sound design is really good, and everything feels like it has impact and right for the situation. The music is also very Kingdom Hearts-esque, which fits this game very well. 

   The gameplay is a very interesting mix of a twin-stick shooting, RPG elements, platforming and puzzles, but the game doesn't feel like a perverbial Frankenstein's monster. Everything is designed around the movement and the combat mechanics, and it introduces a lot of different puzzle mechanics around them, and it all works really well! 

   Even though it is only in early access, the RPG mechanics that are there are very easy to understand and use, and I'm very excited to see what new things are added in the future. As of version 0.5, the party system also has a lot of potential. The AI needs a little bit of fine tuning, in regards to the various command settings, but overall it works pretty well. 

   I also really enjoy the story and setting of this game. As I progressed, I became more interested in finding out about the world and the many different characters. All of the main characters so far have very unique and memorable personalities, and the conversations between these characters made me more interested in them. One of my favorite mechanics in regard to this was how the dialogue you can hear just passing by various people can sometimes hint at important information. During the window where these hints are up, you can begin a conversation with them and gain some new information which can either help you on a quest or find out more about the world. I am definitely excited to see how this plays into the rest of the game. 

   So, if you're looking for something new and unique, I highly recommend checking out this game. Although $20 might be a bit much for a game that is in early access, after playing the demo, I was totally willing to pay it if it meant I could support the developers of this amazing game!

21203261.review:
CrossCode is a treasure.

I [i]could[/i] talk about how great the visuals, soundtrack, dialogue, etc. are, but instead I'd like to focus on two specific parts:
[olist]
[*]The game design is stellar.  The combat is ultra-smooth and frenetic which is aces, but the true standout here is the levels and encounters. In the first dungeon alone there is [i]so much[/i] good synergy between Lea's moveset (melee, dashing, hopping on things, throwing balls) and the dungeon elements. It's the sort of design that makes the player feel impossibly clever when they figure the puzzles out. If the next three (implied, but hopefully more) dungeons have the same level of polish and thought, I will be very pleased. Plus, Lea doesn't take forever to push boxes in box puzzles around, so CrossCode has that going for it. 
[*]Somehow, through clever dialogue and character portraits, I now care deeply about a character that can only say two words.
[/olist]

Sure, it's Early Access, so it's not completely done. Based on what is already in the game, though, I hope to see much much more of CrossCode when it's finished for realsies.

21115266.review:
Acheter cettte démo, car franchement, le jeu en vaut la chandelle.

Tant par le gameplay car par le scénario ( encore asser court au moment de la publication ), CROSSCODE est un rétro rpg d'une sublimité inégalé. Le système de combat en temps réel est tout simplement jouissif ; corp-à-corp, distance, esquive et bouclier sont vos armes pour vous défoulez sur ce qu'il se trouve sur votre chemin, le tout d'une fludité et dynamique endiablé. Assimilé un arbre de talent, vous pourrez apprendre des compétences de combat appelez ART qui enrichirons votre manière de vous battre ainsi que différents talent allant du bonus à l'attaque d'un certain pourcentage à l'amélioration des effets de soin prodigué par certains objets, que vous pourrez utiliser durant le combat. Vous disposerons donc d'attaques spécials pour vos "armes" sus mentionnée plus haut. Et vous aurez le choix ! En effet, il y a plusieurs ART que vous pourrez choisir en montant de niveau, et les changer pour les adapter à votre style de jeu.
Qui plus est, 4 éléments seront disponnible au fil de l'aventure pour combler la diversité du gameplay. Lors de combat, vous pouvez passer d'attaques normals à des attaques enflammées ( ou autres, par encore dévoillées ) qui débloqueront alors de nouveaux coups spéciaux. En effet, les diffèrents éléments possèdent eux aussi leur propre arbre de talent, et donc la possibilité de changer les ART pour le mode feu.

Le scénario quant à lui est asser original : le jeu se déroule sur une planète, que des développeurs ont térraformé pour y installé tout un univers de MMOG. Connecté depuis chez eux, les joueurs se retrouve sur cette planète sous forme d'avatars et y jouent comme si ils y étaient pour de vrai, ressentant la moindre sensation. 
Vous incarnez donc Lea, une sphéromancer, qui à son réveille à perdu la mémoire et avec l'aide de certaines personne va chercher à comprendre ce qu'il lui est arrivé...

Il y aurait beaucoup de chose à dire sur ce jeu, mais je pense que le mieux serait encore que vous le testier par vous même. Acheter le pour soutenir les développeurs et parler en autour de vous, car cette perle deviendra un diamant lorsque le jeu sera entièrement fini.

20993495.review:
this game is great, can't wait for the full release!

0.6.1 patch UPDATE
okay, so now we have two dungeons, three functional towns, and a whole bunch of other space.

positives
-music is catchy and fits with the areas that they're assigned to! battle music could use some work, but the ambient music is spot on for the most part
-graphics are clear and crisp, making the fast gameplay easy to read, avoiding frustration from an abundance of effects and stuff like that
-puzzling is for the most part enjoyable. Personally, the ice temple was impressive to me, it offered a wide range of different puzzles from the standard "reflect the light" kinda puzzle to more complex movement based puzzles
-combat is fun for the most part, although some enemies are really annoying in the later parts of the game. Everything from the end of the ice temple and before (about 80% of the game at this point) was fun to fight and had dynamic systems which rewarded certain playstyles.
-movement, like combat, is fluid and responsive. The movement, in tandem with the ambient music and the graphics, make exploring the world a joy.

negatives
-enemies post ice temple are idiotic. Flying enemies that you can only hit once every 25 seconds completely ruin the pacing of the game and there needs to be either a way to ground them (that is more obvious if it's already in the game) or just be removed outright.. 
-the story really needs to be reexamined. Initially when crosscode came out it kinda seemed like it was going to be a cyberpunkesc gamem, but now i'm not so sure... the beta/alpha has next to no story exposition after the intro/first 3 hours, so honestly i can't tell if they just intend to leave it completely sparse or if they are going to fill it in.. I really hope they consider hiring a writer or actually putting a story in, because as is the "hehe we're an mmo aren't we so witty?" exposition is going to be unpalatable if there isn't a REALLY dark cyberpunk undertone to it with actual death and despair.. I understand that the dev team aren't writers by profession, but this game would be such a waste if they ruined it with a shitty story. also, we need cooler characters. stop with the cheese. cheese is only good when there are actual characters there to respond to it.. Like, the first mission of the game is in a traditional japanese style fortress, and it's AWESOME. Then it hits a really high note, aaaaaaaaand then exposition falls off the face of the (cross)world.
-the trading system is also kinda dumb.. it's kinda based on a component system (with a gold system on the side), so you can go out into the world and get components from the enviornment and mobs ala a real rpg, and then you can trade those up for better components at specific vendors to trade to OTHER vendors to get equipment. Functionally, what happens is you have to 1. find an item that you want to make, 2. memorize the components required, 3. find the vendor that will synthesize the higher componenets required, 4. memorize those requirements, 5. go out into the world and find all of the components.. it just takes a while and it's a huge pain in the ass, but i can see the potential for some hidden vendors/equipment creators that could potentially make it cool. Honestly, i wish they would add stuff to the map showing where vendors are and what they sell after you discover them. Then have a little intro to the system at the start of the game where you have to go through all the steps.
-some gear effects need to be explained in the synopsis section of the game

~~~
So in closing, it may sound like i have issues with this game, but honestly it's just because I love it. It has such potential, and I really do have a lot of faith in the developers because they seem like genuinely passionate people. The game itself is easily worth 20 dollars, so please give it a shot! i hope they fix the stuff that i brought up, because if they do crosscode could probably be up there with some of my favorite games! also, devs, please release an ost when the game "comes out!" please an thanks!

20772256.review:
While somewhat unfinished, what it is currently is an entertaining and unique RPG combat and puzzle game. 

+The combat mechanics are very fun and satisfying, and work very well with the lovely art style and movement system.
+Challenging & entertaining puzzles that fit into the world very well, & really wrack the brain.
+Plays very smoothly, and not really like any other top-down pixely RPG games out there.
+Interesting universe that brings me back to Spy Kids 2, where stuff happens in a videogames.
+The music is nice.

-It's still not quite finished, but is still being updated & has twice as much content than when I originally wrote the review.
-The isometric layers of the environment can get confusing and stressful at times. Trying to platform around to get secrets & sometimes even required items is a very stressful puzzle when you can't quite tell if you can make a jump, knowing that if you miss you will have to walk back three screens to try the jump again.

Overall it is quite a pleasant and promising game. Great gameplay, graphix, and sound. Even when I was grinding for money, loot, and xp I had fun. The only thing the devs really need to do is keep on finishing and adding things to the game, and fix the ocasional bugs and spelling errors. I felt that even in the games less than finished state, that it was a very entertaining and almost zen experience. This game is definitwely worth checking out if you enjoy Virtual Reality & Sci-Fi themes, & also enjoy pixely action RPG's that don't use boring old turn based combat.

20656422.review:
As of this writing, Crosscode is still in Early Access; so many elements of the game are likely to change in the coming months. 

What's there is amazing. The art is unbelievable. It's pixel-art by choice, not a needlessly restrictive throwback or cash-in. It's what I wanted the future of gaming to look like in 1994, before 3d and FMV came along and messed everything up. 

The music doesn't quite hold up its end of the bargain, but there are great tunes scattered about and it's never a problem--it just doesn't quite match the perfect neo-16-bit splendor of the visuals. 

Gameplay is reminiscent of underrated classics such as Terranigma, Beyond Oasis, and Landstalker; though with an interesting ricocheting ranged attack that changes things up a bit and provides for some cool puzzle-solving opportunities.

The writing and story are fun, though the tutorials are a bit wordy for my taste. Depending on the length of the finished game, this may not be an issue, but in an Early Access mode that only lasts a few hours, it's a bit of a drag.

Excellent groundwork has been laid, now let's see the follow-through.

20425082.review:
Crosscode is raw, distilled RPG gameplay.

The game simply delivers. The art is gorgeous, the music...decent. The story is serviceable, the setting being a Virtual RPG world overlayed onto real life. This setting allows for great visuals, although the story itself isn't particularly fleshed out as of yet (early access).

Combat on its surface is an easy to grasp point and shoot/melee system, but the skill required is surprisingly high due to difficult mob attack patterns, and a hard to master dash and shield system. The combat is just fun. There's no reason it should be this fun given how it isn't something particularly new, but it manages to take something old and make it feel fresh. It's something you have to play with to understand. And when you do get the hang of it, the flow of combat is fantastic.

Turns out, there's nothing particularly unique about Crosscode. It's an RPG with puzzles, quests, some storyline, and pixel art. All of these have been done before. But somehow, Crosscode polishes these old tropes into an art. It's a game that doesn't look like it should be this good, but everything comes together to turn out to be a perfect RPG experience.

Edit: Still Good.

[h1]Review For CrossCode[/h1]
Review by: [url=steamcommunity.com/id/dehu92]DEHU[/url]

- Good Gameplay
- Fully controller compatibility
- Great Story so far

[h1]Cons :[/h1]

[h1]Review :[/h1]
Crosscode, An RPG made with HTML, CSS and JS.
The game might be in Early Access but it's a pretty good game, if you like action based RPGs.

The plot is very simple, you are an Avatar in a digital world and you do quests and stuff like that.
First part of the game is a tutorial that helps you with the basic controls and gives you an idea of how some of the puzzles works.

When you level up you can use your points in your skill tree. The skill tree can give you moves and bonus stats like HP, ATK, DEF and Focus.

The game is in Early Access so there aren't that many quests to do, but a huge world to explore.
I would recommend buying this game since it shows so much potential and how fun it acutally is.

20364277.review:
Wait until it's finished. It's got the basis of what might be one of the greatest indie hits of all time, but for the moment it's just a cool engine with a few towns in. The quests seem random and overwhelming and experimental, the story ends 15 minutes into the game for the moment (they're working on it), and there's no telling how long the game will be when its done. 

The combat is super cool however. It feels so damn rewarding and the talent-system is so engaging its incredible. I only wish there will be more sick and awesome spells, and that in the end there will be a story worth following, epic loot worth striving for (atm its just empty stats that seem to do very little to how you play. Gear doesn't feel rewarding to equip at all, and the menu is a hassle to get through cause they all look the same) and something to tie the world together so it doesn't just feel like different levels of a platformer and more like a coherent world.

20269409.review:
I'm honestly blown away by what I've currently experienced. This game is shaping up to be a masterpiece. It has been years since I've played old RPGs such as Final Fantasy or Chrono Trigger etc. One reason for this was because I had gotten tired of the usual RPG formula: complex story, boring combat (I like faster paced combat), and a tendency towards grinding. One game in particular that I played a bit more was the Gameboy Advance version of DBZ The legacy of Goku 1 & 2, because it didn't have the rigid combat format of other RPGs. It was an Action RPG which made it quite refreshing to play.

CrossCode has done a simply amazing job at bringing action, rpg elements and a damn good story to the genre. I can't wait to see where this goes and I have very high hopes.

At its current state I'd say it's worth a buy just to experience the combat. Seriously if you enjoy and RPGs and/or 2D action games this one deserves your time and money.

20205888.review:
The gameplay is fun, the controls are very fluid and responsive, and the combat feels like a twin-stick shooter like Smash TV mixed with an old-school RPG. It also makes me unreasonably happy that the devs follow the "show, don't tell" way of introducing new mechanics. For example, in the newest dungeon, the Bergen Temple Mines, the entire area revolves around ice physics. In one room, you can't go anywhere because a pillar blocking one way, and there's a force field blocking the other. If you try shooting the pillar, you learn it can move around on the ice, until it hits a wall. Later, you find another room sealed off with a bomb near a rock with a pillar behind it. Here, you learn bombs can move pillars, and is key in progressing in the room. The only time the game outright tells you how to progress is at the very beginning when the girl giving the tutorial straight up says something like, "Okay, you can charge your shot, and when charged it ricochets." Beyond that, it feels like the devs put a lot of heart in to the game, the puzzles are interesting, the towns are fairly large and feel busy, and they put in a couple of fun references to other things, like the Giga Spiral Drill (said to be able to pierce through the heaven itself) and some other references I'm sure went over my head.

It's very nice visually, screenshots do it no justice, you really have to see the game in motion to have an appreciation for it. The music is very Kingdom Hearts-like, which is a plus in my book, and your shots make a very satisfying "thwack" when it hits something.

One thing I DON'T like about the game is some of the platforming. On one hand, it's nice that you don't have to keep mashing the jump button to get up on ledges, but on the other hand, one example I can think of is in the Bergen Temple MInes, where I fell off quite a number of times trying to do a simple jump because I couldn't control when I jumped, and jumping at angles generally feels weird to me. And even then, it was only the one time that really stuck out to me, and by and large it works fine, it's just a personal gripe.

Another thing I don't like is that the game is incomplete. Which is why I bought another copy to give to a friend who I showed it to, so he could also get hyped for future updates and so I could throw more money at Radical Fish Games.

Final verdict: "I'm throwing my money at the screen and nothing is happening!"/10 I highly recommend it, even in it's incomplete state, if only to support Radical Fish and get the word out of what I hope will be the next big name in Indie gaming.

This is really, really good so far.

I'm currently going through my backlog in alphabetical order, seeing what's actually any good, usually doing about 10-15 minutes per game to get a feel.

I ended up being hooked on this one until "the current end of the plot" (hence the kind of short playtime). Don't let that deter you. The journey there is inventive, the systems here are wonderfully implemented, and the world is gorgeous. In the very first level, the foliage reacts to my character running through it. It's the little things.

I just personally want to go back to this as the story would intend, so I'm happy waiting it out for the next major update. I did do a short "quest" that's just outside of the ending area, and that introduced a new mechanic, so I'll be pleased with more like that.

Gah, it's so good though.

19834496.review:
It is such a fantastic game even if it is still in beta. The prolouge draws you in quickly, the game teaches everything so well, and it's has a really unique fighting system. 

Your character evolves in dramatic ways as you level up, getting new special attacks that you can use to combo into your regular attacks while meticulously dodging in between enemy attacks. It's super smooth, I love 2D games with tiny cute sprites, and the environments have great matching atmospheres. Their latest installment of the new dungeon shows that they really want to challenge players with something different. 

I look forward to more content, all the while I will enjoy my new heat tree which is super neat and fantastic and just another great evolving point of the fighting system. Hooray!

На сегодняшний день присутствует около 10 часов геймплея, из которых сюжета примерно на час, и он обрывается в самом начале - просто вводная миссия и знакомство с одним персонажем, далее разработчики честно сообщают что остальной контент активно пилится. 19695317.review:
Although the story part hasn't as much kicked off as gently nudging the ball forwards a couple inches, I really like the direction it seems to be heading. It feels like it's combining the spirit of both Ghost in the Shell and the .hack// series.

The pixel art is simply gorgeous, and the in-game physics are surprisingly advanced and well established for a game like this. Seems like it could just as well be made into an actual MMO.

The gameplay is somewhat like a hack'n slash RPG with ranged combat and puzzle solving. You laso collect lots of loot as quest rewards, killing monsters and trashing plants. Much of this loot can be used to craft items at vendors.

My only gripe is that there does not seem to be much of a penalty for falling down pits or into water (You can't swim, but there's a reason for it which you will find out while playing) only loses you a few health points and instantly respawns you right where you fell in.
I think it should be a bit more punishing. Perhaps losing a third of your HP when falling in water would be sufficient (it regenerates fairly quickly out of combat) It wouldn't be insta-kill, but you wouldn't be able to hold the move button and fall in a hundred times before dying like it is now. Make it seem like a risk instead of a nearly non-existant inconvenience.

While I'm disappointed at the lack of story content in the game right now, I realize this is an early access game, and I will be waiting eagerly for future updates.
For now I will advice everyone to buy this while it's still in a special promotion offer. Or, you know, wait till it's over and buy it then to give the devs more money to finish it faster.

PS: While the story is short for now, you can still explore the world and do side quests and upgrade your character. So it's not like all we can do is sit and wait for more content.

19688084.review:
CrossCode is equal parts Metroid, Zelda, and Final Fantasy, even a little reminiscent of Scurge:Hive (plug: if you like the others, check it out).  Overall great fun, especially for a demo (usually, hopefully, a dev's "best foot forward").

Pros: 

- Clearly a lot of thought was put into designing the main cast; not just in looks but in characterization as well.  Each one's clearly unique and has his or her own attitude and way of speaking (or not ;).  The nameless masses are less visually impressive, but still usually have interesting things to say.  
- Likewise, the backstory is detailed and pretty well thought-out, and the dialog is pretty consistent so far, not to mention incredibly witty.
- Awesome awesome awesome "16-bit" graphics.  There's a lot more sophisticated effects than Mode 7 at work here, but it still has the look:  an elegant style from a more civilized age.
- Gameplay is very fluid, especially important when combat is king and timing is everything.  
- Challenging puzzles that make good use of the abilities you're given.

Cons:

- K&M controls were a little awkward, mostly trying to track a target with the mouse while also dodging enemy attacks.    (Hope it's better with a gamepad, because this would make an awesome handheld game (e.g. on the Shield or even PSVita).
- Three different types of in-game dialog.  I understand they're for different purposes (cutscenes, in-game conversation, and "overheard" conversations) and so basically necessary, but could they at least use the same key(s) to continue?  In particular, G is used to continue in the latter two, and MouseLeft is (of course) your attack button; but for cutscenes G is the Skip button, while MouseLeft continues the conversation.
- It's SHORT!  I'm definitely looking forward to seeing the rest.  Now, I bought it in a bundle, so I've probably already got my money's worth, but I'd probably drop $20 on a copy to give away once I've got an idea of what's in store.
- Tutorial did not run with the obvious joke about "a girl who can handle balls". ;D

Wishlist:

- Multiplayer.  I mean, it IS an MMOG... simulator.  But it would be nifty at least to be able to "join" other players' games in progress, à la Borderlands.
- Voice acting.  Stretch goal, I know, but it could be great.

19577419.review:
This isn't going to be a particularly long review, but I'm going to try to highlight the best things about this game that I've seen so far.

Gameplay: Gameplay is challenging, action oriented, and has a good deal of depth, with close combat and ranged attacks joined by powerful abilities, fluid and fun movement, dodging, and blocking to provide a robust game experience. A+

Art: Charming retro art that doesn't have the "Love me because of nostalgia" vibe. The developers are amazing at this kind of art, and the love and detail put into this game is clear. A

Sound: The music does get a bit repetitive at times, but is cheerful enough and in keeping with the graphics. The sound effects could use a bit of variety, but they serve well enough and are quite functional. While you'll be listening to a ton of the same stuff, it's solid, and my only complaint is the scarcity because I would love more (and I'd buy the soundtrack).  B

Story: Still in progress. The developers are putting content ahead of story in their priorities, so there's still quite a bit to play even though the story (more of a prologue at this point) only runs about an hour. The dialogue is tounge-in-cheek and often parodies videogame cliches, but does so without being too heavyhanded and I find it quite amusing. If the story is writen as well as the dialogue is, I forsee the outcome being quite good. ?????

Systems: I normally don't take note of a game's systems like UI because normally I just suffer through mediocre menus, only noticing when something is so painfully tedious that it requires extra effort. However, the UI of Crosscode is exquisite, with clear markers of what's happening when, items sorted neatly, and quick, easy to navigate menus. If every RPG had this menu system, I would not complain. It is wonderful. A++++

I have no complaints with this game in its current state. It is in early access (0.4 at the moment) and I expect there to be plenty of room to grow- and that's apparent. This will be one of those games that I check out every time a major update gets pushed out. I have no concerns for the future of the game because a wonderful foundation is in place, and as long as the developers manage to keep improving (the last time I played before Early Access was an early beta demo that only had the first few stages in, and I was hooked then) it will be great! The only danger I see is the chance of grind in the future; it's already a little bit grindy (since it's styled like an MMO, with MMO style quests and drop rates and leveling and all that entails) but if the gameplay is as solid as it is I will at least enjoy it.

Overall: Undecided. I am very optimistic, and would enthusiastically recommend it to anyone who enjoys action combat, RPGs, and puzzle platforming. There is a lot of potential here, and as long as it doesn't get botched I see it being a wonderful game. Likewise, my few complaints may be addressed in the future, so I don't want to leave any negative feedback that doesn't accurately reflect a later state of the game (since I'll probably forget to update this). Tentatively: A (9/10)

18984153.review:
I came about CrossCode as a web-based game, completely designed in HTML5, and therefore featured on Chrome Experiments. Back then, it wasn't even an RPG; it was basically a simulation of the aiming engine, a clone of the early tutorial now present in the current version of the game. As little of a resemblance that web-version has with the current state of the game, it did show the talent and ambition of the developers, and what has been added since is astonishing.

Astonishingly good. Although there are some loose ends in the story still, this is due to the fact the game is actually in Early Access as of writing this review. And already now, it's worth the $20.

Why? Well, first of all, the game looks extremely polished already. The pixelated sprites 'fit' each other, controls have been neatly arranged and the game mechanics up until now have been executed to near perfection.

These mechanics are quite plentifully present, actually. Every enemy has specific attacks and weaknesses, and even different 'evolutions' of itself. The attacking system is as elegant as it is challenging; WASD to move, left-click to hit, right-click to dodge/block. That's it. The maps have been built in such a way it is relatively easy to traverse through for a quick sweepthrough, but provides quite the challenge when going for the semi-hidden presents scattered all over the maps.

Now, of course, as it is still in development, the main plot of the story is finished in roughly half an hour. After that, you're kind of being released into the world, in order for you to explore on your own. Quests can be completed, ranging from collecting items to beating enemies. Because of the layout of the maps, some of those can take some time; not in an annoying way though, as you're mostly being busy trying to work out how to get to a certain ledge.

The only negative in this version is that the 'open-world' feeling of the game is somewhat limited. This is caused by the facts that certain buildings aren't visitable, some paths are blocked, and the world is consisting of only 5 maps (a city, 2 trails, the tutorial map and the main hub - these are rather extensive, though!). I'm not only expecting, but quite frankly plain confident the devs will be able to make that point go away.

The game is already a blast to play through, and with the constant stream of content updates, it'll only get better.

In short: Buy it now. This might be one of those underestimated games, deserving a lot more exposure.

18950014.review:
This is an early access review, so the completed game may differ wildly from what I have seen.

First, the game serves as a massive homage to the 16-bit era of games. It has smooth controls, an easily intuitive UI, and doesn't burden you with massive complexity in terms of gameplay itself. While the current story is limited to the opening bits and one dungeon, it still gives you a great deal of room to explore and play with the game's mechanics.

In terms of the game environment and the bits of story seen, it takes influences from throughout the era, with a few from other eras to better flesh out the story. The world's details are reminiscient of the later 16-bit era games, with great attention to detail, colorful environments, and excellent pallete layering to give a perception of depth. This gives the game's aesthetics a very nostalgic feel without bringing up the era's limitations.

The music, of course, is and is not 16-bit. It is 16-bit as it uses the synthesized sound we remember, but isn't in the fact that it uses modern sound drivers which perfected the digital music compression started in the era. This isn't an insult to the 16-bit era of game music. Many of the best and most beloved video game musics were dome in the 16-bit era (anyone else remember Aria Di Mezzo Caraterre aka the song during the Opera Scene from Final Fantasy VI?).

The game is a complete homage to an era of gaming. An era where video games began to become more complex, an era where games came into their own, and an era which shaped the modern era of gaming.

18882774.review:
This is a wonderful, if currently incomplete 2d hack and slash style rpg. The 8 directional controls are smooth as silk, and the combat system is a challenging but well balanced blend of ranged and melee, against a variety of enemies with equally varying behaviors in an interesting world with a refreshing plot and setting.

The game also manages to incorporate a 3d enviroment where you can hop up onto ledges of varying heights and leap across gaps to parkour and make use of the terrain to survive against enemy ai of higher levels. 

Quick reflexes on the keyboard and mouse are required, but the controls are instinctive and easy to use. (Mastering them, on the other hand, is a different matter :D) 

When I first found this game for free online in its original demo form, I was very disappointed to find it was only a demo, and was afraid that it would never go anywhere. But then, months later low and behold I found it on steam, and didn't hesitate to buy it. I was overjoyed at the progress that had been made, and eagerly look forward to seeing future updates.

18864493.review: This game. Oooooh, this game. Even in it's uncompleted state is near a masterpiece.  I'll try not to fanboy about how "Unrivaled in awesomeness, DUUUUUUDE" it is. So, beginning the review, as well as spoilers. Crosscode is an amalgam of Kingdom Hearts style gameplay and atmosphere, an MMORPG, Zelda style puzzles, and a Megaman Battle Network (Which is a massively under-appreciated series.) aesthetic. As gameplay starts, it introduces you to a vague character in a vague setting on a vague quest. The first part ends with a death-scene of a character you don't know at all, and switches scenes to a fututristic setting with a girl floating in stasis , whom you can only assume is yourself. And if you had any doubts about this game (Which I'm sure you would, considering the very vague beginning), they're near immediately flushed away by a short but effective tutorial leading to your first boss fight. You're then told about the setting of the game, being a futuristic MMO that directly plugs your five senses into the game, and that you're a player who logged in, and for a yet unexplained reason, forgot everything. Picture the Matrix, but optional, and with less brain jacks. The game also very cleverly integrates the silent hero trope, with the fact that your voice synthesis is malfunctioning. A common problem, it seems.After dramatically escaping the cargo ship that nobody knows why you were on, (and a Naruto poser) you arrive at the entrance to the first dungeon, Rhombus Dungeon(Or whatever it's called). Going through the dungeon there are several puzzles for you to solve with your throwing-balls. You then shortly arrive at a beautiful town, all yours to explore! This is where the story stops. As you may have noticed, this is early access, and is in beta. The next part of the story is almost here, but for now, we can grind levels, do quests, and listen to the guy telling us to "become water" by jumping into the fountain. I urge you to buy this game, as the developers benefit from it, and can crank out more game more efficiently, and continue to make us all happy with this rising star of an indie game.

18316335.review:
CrossCode is a wonderful experience.

I could really let this stand like this and stop, but I guess I'll have to explain first.

In CrossCode, you play as Lea, an amnesiac player of the popular MMORPG "CrossWorlds", a game that takes place in the real world (Thanks, science!). Since you'd obviously want your memories back, you'll have to play the actual game, too. And thus, Lea is thrown into CrossWorlds, with no memories, and no language to use to speak, since her speech module is broken. Well, at least at first.

Over the course of the, relatively simple, but engaging, story, you'll meet plenty of memorable characters - from edgelords, to tanks, from glass cannons, to helpful other players -, some of which may even join your party to help you during battle - even though in the current version, this feature is only available with one other player.

In order to regain your memories, you have to play CrossWorlds, and for that, you have to travel across the lands and gather all the elements and become the Avatar- scratch that, and figure out the mistery behind the ancients, an ancient (Duh.) civilization that lived on this planet long ago. The world of CrossWorlds is beauti- and colorful. You will see frozen mountains, deep jungles or ancient ruins. The variety of locations and enemies is certainly there.

Speaking of enemies - let's get to the gameplay. The gameplay is actually rather simple. Click close to Lea for a melee attack and far away from Lea for a ranged attack. Right-click let's you evade or guard, depending on the input. And holding the spacebar will unleash one of your powerful special attacks. The combat is fast, precise and fun, but also rather challenging, especially when it comes to the huge bosses inside the dungeons. 

Besides the typical combat, you can also solve different puzzles. These range from simple button-pressing to block-moving or arranging a certain path so your projectile can hit the switch. The easy controls make these puzzles quite entertaining.

The soundtrack of CrossCode is simply beautiful. I don't think I have to say any more than that. It's just wonderful.

Overall, CrossCode is a small, simple, but very fun game. You can have fun for many hours with the current version. However, be aware that this is not the finished product - the story doesn't even go to the second dungeon, and many locations are still not done yet. But that what is there is polished and entertaining. 

You definitely should give CrossCode a try.

18166986.review:
2017/2/27 バージョン"0.9 Final"にアップデートされたので改めてレビュー。
(v0.2.2-2 betaの時点で一度レビューを書きましたが、変更点が多く情報が古かったので改正)

ストーリーモードに関しては発売当初から全くと言っていいほど進んでないのですが、
メインであるExplorationモードは順調なアップデートとマメなバグfixを繰り返し
システムは改良されて、とても良い方向に進んでいます。
バージョン"0.9 Finalの時点でもかなりのボリュームがあるので
雰囲気が好きで購入を迷っている方がいらっしゃるなら今が買い時だと思います。

Explorationはストーリーとは関係なく、こちらはMMO RPGの世界に飛び込んだプレイヤーの話で、クエストをこなしながらレベルを上げCircuitsと呼ばれるスキルツリーで自由にスキルをアップグレードし、プレイヤー好みのキャタクターに育てられるのが一つの特徴。
近接や遠距離攻撃、属性を使ったものなど様々な戦い方ができるので敵との戦闘はとても楽しいです。細かい事を書くとキリがないので詳しくは動画などでご確認ください。

最後に一言
発売当初はNPCも少なくて一人で冒険している感じが強かったのですが、
今では街やフィールドを多数のキャラクターが行き交うようになりMMOらしい活気があります。
さらにNPCプレイヤー二人を含めた3人でのパーティプレイが可能になりました。
おおまかに攻撃や回避、プレイヤーと同じ敵を狙うといった指示が出せるので敵との戦闘は今まで以上に面白くなっています。クエスト周りの利便性やテレポート機能なども以前より使いやすくなっていて、システムはほぼ完成しているのでは？と思ってしまうほどです。
今の段階でも十分なボリュームですが、ゲーム内のワールドマップを確認する限りでは
かなりのスペースがあるので、いい方向に進んでくれると信じて開発チームに期待しています。

*For it to be finished yesterday

17429903.review:
"CrossCode is a poster child for why independent games matter more than ever in a market where AAA relevance is dwindling. It's destined to become a cult phenomenon, reverently mentioned in the same company as Cave Story, Braid, or Fez. I'm highly looking forward to it and you should be too."

So I summarized the first (and currently only) review I ever thought worth writing over a year ago. 15 months on, it's truer than ever. In the intervening time, among plenty of other great independent games, we saw the absolute juggernaut that was Undertale blow up the internet. And at the risk of drawing parallels between two VERY different games ("indie" isn't a genre after all), CrossCode deserves that kind of recognition.

CrossCode is not the best game you'll ever play. Its story and characters are fun and infectiously endearing, but they won't redefine the way you think about narrative in games. Its art and music are lovingly crafted, but so are a dozen other great (and not-so-great) pixel-art games. The puzzles are smart and the fast-paced combat is insanely fun and suitably challenging, but it probably won't supplant your favorite ARPG. CrossCode is reminiscent of a lot of things, a synthesis of elements both nostalgic and modern that you've likely seen many times before.

What CrossCode likely IS though, is the best game you've never played. Because it's been fairly sparsely covered during its early access period, it's flown under the radar for a lot of people. And because that synthesis of elements is so well tuned, you'll wonder how you missed hearing about such a well-made game for so long. Almost every aspect of CrossCode feels really, really good to play, not just in an acceptably non-distracting sort of way, but dripping with love and care and attention to detail. The extreme ratio of positive reviews isn't a fluke or vote gaming by a hyper-devoted fanbase. Lately, it's people finding the game wondering if an early access game can really be THAT good, and discovering to their delight that yes, it really can be.

CrossCode is aiming for official release some time in the first half of 2017, and the amount of progress that the development team has made since the early access launch last year strongly suggests this is a realistic goal. Even if you don't want to spend money on an early access game right now, do yourself a favor and follow it, because you're probably going to want it when it's finished.

This is one of the most polished 2D action RPG games I've ever seen on STEAM. It is basically what the Megaman RPG  for PS2 should've been instead of A traditional turn-based system.

Gamers familiar with Illusion of Gaia, Megaman, Contra, Zelda and Chrono Trigger will feel right at home with this gem. Their influences runs deep in this game, but what is so profound is how completely original this game is. It is inspired by classic elements of old but it doesn't by any means try to make you feel like you're playing an old school game. The feel, the story, the unique character design has a feeling all on its own and that is what drives this very fun experience. This game comes HIGHLY recommended, please support the developers and spread the word about CrossCode. 

+High quality 2D Sprite work and animation
+High quality and catchy music
+Battle system is challenging and fun, punishes you hard for mistakes you make.
+Full RPG system you'd expect from a Japanese RPG including equipments, items

-Early Access. Hope it doesn't stay there for too long.

Hi! Now has come for a review update: Version 8.3:

Nothing can describe the length of detail, and scale of what this game was to what it will become.  If you hadn't had a chance to look at the news feed for this game, you will know that this game deserves your time and attention (try the Demo, it won't bite ya :D ).

The developers have devoted a great amount of attention not only to their supporters, but also to everyone who either had questions or concerns about the actual progress of the game, and when it will be fully released (especially when they have been doing this for over a year now (at least)).

Indie games take time, especially when a group doesn't have the kind of capabilities that major game companies already posses. So they rely on us to offer feedback, ideas, and other inquires we as players would like to experience in a game.

Although the story hasn't quite gotten developed yet since the story (as of Ver. 8.3) is about half way there, and the characters are developing slowly (at least for me it is). Cheers!
